PROCTEXT.PARA: Madam SPEAKER (Hon. Joan Child) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Yesterday the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) raised as a matter of privilege reports in the Melbourne Sun and the Brisbane Courier-Mail of 17 November purporting to reveal recommendations of the forthcoming report of the Joint Select Committee on Telecommunications Interception. The honourable member presented copies of the articles in question and referred to a similar article in the Burnie Advocate of the same date.

INTERJECT.PARA: In order for precedence to be accorded to a motion in respect of a complaint, two criteria must be satisfied. Firstly, a matter must be raised at the earliest opportunity and, secondly, the Speaker must be of the opinion that a prima facie case of breach of privilege has been made out. Clearly, this matter has been raised at the earliest opportunity. May's Parliamentary Practice states:

The publication or disclosure of proceedings of committees conducted with closed doors or of draft reports of committees before they have been reported to the House will, however, constitute a breach of privilege or a contempt.
That is from the twentieth edition of May, page 154. House of Representatives Practice states:

. . . the publication or diclosure of evidence taken in camera, or the publication or disclosure of draft reports of a committee before their presentation to the House, constitutes a breach of privilege or contempt.

That is from page 660 of House of Representatives Practice. There are a number of precedents in this House and in the House of Commons for the unauthorised publication of the contents of committee reports or proceedings being raised as matters of contempt.

I have considered the remarks of the honourable member and examined the articles in question. Whilst there are differences between the articles referred to, there are many similarities. The articles, on their face, appear to reveal the private deliberations of the Committee and the substance of recommendations to be made to the Houses. It is clearly impossible for me to reach any conclusion as to whether in fact the articles do reveal the private deliberations and proposed recommendations of the committee. In the circumstances, however, and on the information before me, I am of the opinion that precedence to a motion in respect of the matter is warranted. I am prepared to accept a motion on the matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the matter of the printed references to the proceedings and prospective recommendations of the Joint Select Committee on Telecommunications Interception in the Sun News-Pictorial and the Courier-Mail of 17 November 1986, and similar references in other newspapers, be referred to the Committee of Privileges.

In moving that motion, I have examined all of the issues associated with this matter. Yesterday, as I indicated in this House, three newspaper articles were brought to my attention. They were in the Melbourne Sun News-Pictorial, the Brisbane Courier-Mail and the Burnie Advocate. Since that time other newspapers that contain similar reports have been drawn to my attention. Those newspapers were the Hobart Mercury, the Adelaide Advertiser and the West Australian, all dated 17 November. In addition, two other articles, also purporting to reveal the substance of the deliberations of the Joint Select Committee on Telecommunications Interception have been drawn to my attention. Those articles appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald dated 18 November and the Weekend Australian of 15-16 November, in one edition-I think in Melbourne.

I am concerned and disappointed that, although the Committee was able to deliberate for a fairly long period and in accordance with the Standing Orders, right towards the death, as we were about to make certain recommendations and hand down a report, the whole of the deliberations fell apart. I think that this really does reflect poorly on the question of privilege and what that therefore attracts to it within the House. A very close working relationship had been developed among all Committee members. A major issue of concern-that is of telecommunication interception-in the wider community was under very close examination. Therefore, I am most concerned that apparent reporting has taken place which talks about deliberations of the Committee-deliberations which had not been concluded. It also mentioned recommendations or dissents from recommendations which had not, in fact, been made.

I believe, therefore, that the information provided to the particular journalist in question and subsequently in some of the other articles is misleading and in fact goes a long way to misrepresenting the views of those members who have worked so hard and so conscientiously on the Committee in question. I hope that members of the Privileges Committee take the matter all the way to try to nail the particular individual who has misrepresented the views of the majority of the Committee members-in fact, all the views of the Committee members-and has purported to represent the views as a Committee as a whole. I hope that this reference to the Privileges Committee leads to finding the person responsible and some positive action being taken.

—One would expect that the member who had raised the matter of privilege would be prepared to speak to it in the event that he did get the response that he got.

Will the Attorney-General dissociate himself and this Government from the disgusting attack made by Senator Walsh?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is in the nature of Parliament that members of Parliament are free to make whatever comment they like within the bounds of guaranteeing that people who are impugned have the right of reply. In this particular case, I do not think what the Minister said is new matter. —Nearly blind and in retirement?

—Yes, even in retirement one is not silenced. We make no comment as to who might have been responsible for the interpretation of them. But the facts are that, as a result of those interpretations, there was a massive evasion of tax. —You are on a question of law.
—Order! The honourable member for North Sydney, having asked his question, will now heed the answer.

—Let me make it clear. ANSWER.PARA: The honourable gentleman was anxious to say that what Sir Garfield might have said in the 1970s could still be the interpretation of the High Court. That is not necessarily so. One of the problems with the administration of justice is that we have to guarantee that judicial comments are not brought into contempt. But, from the point of view of fair and valid criticism, they are not above that. That is the issue.

It certainly does not carry the issue any further by having comments made when justices are in retirement; I give the honourable member that. But, from the point of view of whether they should be made, that is a matter for the Minister. On the basis of whether they can be answered, of course, that is a matter for Sir Garfield Barwick.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Prime Minister aware of suggestions that the Australia Card is inconsistent with the removal of unnecessary government regulation? Will the Government consider abandoning the Australia Card proposal in light of these suggestions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Stirling for his question without notice, particularly as I had the opportunity at the weekend of being in his electorate and seeing the magnificent job that he is doing there. As far as we are concerned, the stated policy on government regulation is that this Government will remove unnecessary, growth retarding regulation.

—We get the substitute of hollow noise for thought. Let me just give by way of example the fact that after 7 1/2 years of neglect by the mob opposite we, for instance, have brought in a national food standards code which has removed the unnecessary duplication of regulation around this country and it is estimated by the industry that it will save this country $50m a year. That is an example of the sort of practical approach to deregulation followed by this Government.

ANSWER.PARA: To some extent the test of unnecessary regulation will be whether the regulation serves some useful social purpose. In that respect it is crystal clear that the Australia Card serves a very useful social purpose. That social purpose is to avoid the continuation of tax avoidance and fraud in the social welfare system-a subject on which the Leader of the Opposition pontificates but on which he does his best in this House to stop our efforts.

All members of this House will, no doubt, recall that yesterday in this place the Leader of the Opposition sought, unsuccessfully, to create a conflict between the Australia Card and the removal of unjustified regulation. In that sense I suggest that all honourable members would have considerable interest in a question asked of Mr Howard last year and his answer to that question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you got it there?

—Yes, I will share it with honourable members. On 15 September last year Laurie Oakes asked the Leader of the Opposition a question. The question was very specific because it came after the Leader of the Opposition had indicated that he supported the idea of an ID card which led the perspicacious Mr Oakes to address this question to the Leader of the Opposition:

ANSWER.PARA: If you support deregulation how can you support an ID card?
That is a very specific question and this is a very specific answer by Mr Howard:

I don't think there is any inconsistency, I mean the United States has had a social security card for generations and yet the United States economy is the most deregulated economy in the world. I don't think there is any conflict at all.

Yet the Leader of the Opposition was in this House yesterday trying to suggest that there was a conflict. That is yet another example to add to the long list of the Leader of the Opposition's abandoning of his principles for purposes of political expediency. There was the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax, the assets test-all of those things-and most recently we have his cynical opportunism on the issue of the merger of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and the Special Broadcasting Service. I note that the Leader of the Opposition's cynical grab for votes on this issue is coming undone. I would love to have seen his reaction to the announcement in today's copy of Australia's most influential newspaper, Il Globo, which nails him fair and square. It attacks him for his position, for his opportunism on this, and states very succinctly:
John Howard's position is obviously contradictory.

It is little wonder that people now are beginning to laugh with round contempt when they look at what was stated in the pamphlet entitled `meet Australia's next Prime Minister', introducing people to John Howard. What did the pamphlet state?

TALK.START.PARA: —Listen to the hollow and sparse hear, hears. The pamphlet contains a description of this man of principle, the man who does not go for expediency. It states:

ANSWER.PARA: his forthright and direct approach to issues reflects his belief that it is more important to do what is necessary and correct rather than simply what is popular, easy or acceptable to special interest groups.

It is little wonder that the Federal Treasurer of the Liberal Party of Australia, Mr John Elliott, has had something to say on the subject of the Leader of the Opposition and an alternative. Have honourable members not seen this? Let me share it with them. In the Sunday Press, the Federal Treasurer of the Liberal Party is quoted as saying:
I've got strong views about the way this country should be run and a change of government wouldn't put it right.
The Opposition hasn't got anything different to offer.

They are the words of the Federal Treasurer of the Liberal Party. Do not let the honourable member for Kooyong think that he has an unimpeded run to the leadership because the Federal Treasurer was asked whether he might be available for the job. He said `not just yet' but he is keeping his options open. He said that he could not take over the job yet. He said: `Not right now. I've just had next year's VFL fixtures and I've got to work on rescheduling all my business trips to London'. So when he has finished rescheduling all his business trips to London, he might think about having a shot at the leadership of the Liberal Party. The simple fact is that the Federal Treasurer of the Liberal Party has joined the growing ranks of the Liberals who have abandoned the Leader of the Opposition because the Leader of the Opposition has abandoned all pretence to principle. He has become the cynical opportunist par excellence. The simple fact is that the Leader of the Opposition is a man alone; he is a man who has lost his principles, his integrity and his credibility. TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order, Madam Speaker. Could the pamphlet from which the Prime Minister was quoting be tabled for the amusement of the House as a whole?
—Indeed, with all the appropriate parts underlined.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security and I seek a relevant answer to it. Is it a fact that the Director of Public Prosecutions in his annual report for 1985-86 has reported that many serious cases of welfare fraud are not being referred to the DPP simply because they have not been investigated, that a large group of welfare fraud cases are investigated neither by the Department of Social Security nor by the Australian Federal Police and that this unsatisfactory state of affairs can only undermine the deterrent value of prosecutions? I ask: Firstly how many such cases of welfare fraud remain uninvestigated? Secondly, what is the estimated loss to revenue? Thirdly, why has this scandalous state of affairs been allowed to continue for the last 3 1/2 years? Fourthly, how will the introduction of the identity card make any difference to welfare fraud when so many serious cases are not even investigated?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to get another question from the honourable member for Richmond on the identity card, albeit linked to the most recent report of the Director of Public Prosecutions, because if there is one thing that everyone in the House is clear on it is what the real view of the honourable member for Richmond is with respect to the identity card.
—Don't tell another lie.
—Order! The honourable member for Richmond will withdraw that comment.
—Madam Speaker, I withdraw that word and ask the Minister to quote accurately my views on the identity card.

—I can understand the sensitivity of the honourable member because on a number of occasions within this Parliament, publicly, he has made clear his position with respect to the identity card. He has also made it clear that he believes that the matter of social security fraud and overpayments ought to be of prime concern to the Government, and he has returned again and again to that question. The Prime Minister draws my attention to several quotations from the honourable member for Richmond on ID cards. The honourable member for Richmond on 8 June 1985 said:

ANSWER.PARA: The introduction of a national identification system, using ID cards, offered benefits to the Australian people, which outweighed any civil liberties considerations.

So let there be no question about it; his position is perfectly clear. He knows that the question of the identity card is crucial in terms of the Government's approach to overpayments and social security fraud, particularly fraud. Take, for example, just one case of a major fraud that occurred this year involving an amount of $400,000 and which resulted in a prosecution. Fortunately, as a result of action taken by the Department of Social Security, most of that money was recovered. That was a substantial amount. The person who committed that fraud manufactured 55 separate identities.

TALK.START.PARA: —And you found them without an ID card. How amazing. You found them, so you can do it.
—Order! I had to speak to the honourable member for Barker yesterday, and I warn him again. He must heed the Chair.

—He was able to carry out that fraud because he was able to manufacture or have manufactured substitute identities which were convincing enough for him to receive various payments. Whatever else might be said about the ID card, it is an extraordinarily high integrity instrument in terms of establishing the identity of people. While many overpayments may occur that do not involve the question of identity, there is no doubt that in many, and perhaps the majority, of major frauds the question of identity is quite crucial, and there is no doubt in my mind that the identity card will be very relevant.

ANSWER.PARA: The early part of the honourable member's question went to criticisms by the Director of Public Prosecutions. Mr Temby made a number of suggestions, one of which had to do with the training of field officers which originally emanated from the Department itself. He also drew attention-remember that this is his 1985-86 report-to a problem with guidelines with respect to the investigation of fraud as opposed to the relative responsibilities of the Department of Social Security and the Australian Federal Police. That is an issue that the Government has been addressing. Indeed, it is about to release guidelines which will make it clearer where the responsibilities of the Department of Social Security are appropriate and where the responsibilities of the Federal Police are appropriate in terms of the investigation of fraud.

That proposal is not new; it is one that was brought to the Government by a relevant interdepartmental committee on which Mr Temby was represented as investigating that issue. As a result of that, the Government will make decisions in terms of whether it is necessary to refer additional cases to the Federal Police for investigation. As people would know, and indeed as the honourable member for Richmond knows, currently smaller cases of misrepresentation are investigated within the Department, and what are referred to the Federal Police tend to be the more systematic cases which involve large amounts of money. The relevance of the Director's report really goes to the need for clarifying guidelines. That is something that the Government is addressing, and I expect that new guidelines will be announced in the very near future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Special Minister of State been drawn to the annual report of the Director of Public Prosecutions and in particular to the comments concerning welfare fraud? QUESTION.PARA: Opposition members-Didn't you hear the last question?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me give some more facts. In New South Wales in the last financial year the AFP investigated more than 3,800 cases of fraudulently negotiated cheques, from single sums of $150 to the multiple offences exceeding $14,000. In 1984-85 the Department of Social Security issued 53 million cheques, of which only 17,308, or 0.03 per cent, were referred to the AFP as possible frauds. In the same--

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, there is no problem.
—Be quiet, John. Go and drive your Rolls around the House, or something. No wonder the honourable member is crooked on the fringe benefits tax; I can sympathise with him.

ANSWER.PARA: In the same year the total value of welfare payments was $14.1 billion, while the value of the cheques referred to the AFP was $2.7m. The fact is that, unless the Opposition believes in great big government or a police state, one does not have to go on employing more and more police in response to every problem.

Late last year Mr Temby made a study tour of Britain and the United States of America. He commented when he returned that there was significantly less enforcement activity in respect of fraud in Britain than there was in Australia and that in the United States of America the potential for fraud on some large scale security type programs is not as well appreciated as it is in Australia.

As with everything else that honourable members opposite left us to do, the Government is conducting an inquiry into fraud against the Commonwealth, which deals with the matter raised by the DPP; that is, what the relationship should be between the Department of Social Security, the AFP and, indeed, Mr Temby's office. Mr Temby himself is a member of the steering committee supervising this inquiry, as are the AFP Commissioner and the Secretary to the Department of Social Security. The report of this study, expected, as my colleague said, early in the new year, should provide a sensible basis for any further action.

The Government has also introduced legislation to prevent this very type of fraud before it occurs-and at least on this the honourable member for Richmond agrees with us. I refer to the introduction of the Australia Card. At least one person opposite agrees with the Commissioner of Police that these moves are absolutely essential.

It should be of some interest to honourable members opposite to know that 88 per cent of the Australian people believe there should be some sort of identification system. Sixty per cent believe it should be the Australia Card. Only 7 per cent of the Australian people believe in the stand the Opposition is taking-that there should be no identification at all. If honourable members opposite are serious in any way at all, when moving around this country, presenting themselves as representatives of the Australian people, allowing social security and other types of fraud to occur in this community and not doing anything about it, they will be overwhelmingly defeated on this as well as a lot of other issues. There can be absolutely no doubt about it.

The only reason that Opposition members find themselves opposed to the Australia Card is the fact that they are in opposition and that we are doing this and not them. There is no intellect, there is no honesty, there is no decency in the stand they are taking. It is just another one of those wobbly decisions that honourable members opposite make in their party room at a time when they cannot present themselves as a proper alternative to govern this country. Honourable members opposite will get done on this issue, just as they will be done on all the other issues on which they take negative stands.

If honourable members opposite are serious in talking about this question, why do they not line up with the law enforcement agencies which say that they need this card? They say that they need it to do their work. Have a look at the evidence of the AFP. The AFP says it would like the Australia Card. These are the sorts of things that the Opposition ought to be looking at, rather than wobbling around in the party room trying to find some position which will attract a few votes.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister for Health agree with security experts that the integrity of an identification system is only as good as the integrity of its weakest link? I remind the Minister that he explained yesterday that clause 36 sub-clause (2) of the identity card Bill states:

Again, it is a process that we use for another vital document in this society-the passport. We use very much the same process of verification there, for a high integrity document, and we have every confidence that those members of the community who would be entrusted with the appropriate identification and verification of the Australia Card-the photograph, the signature and the identity-can be relied on, as they have been relied on by all governments in relation to another high integrity document, namely, the Australian passport.
—Are you going to publish a register of community leaders?
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will cease interjecting. He will heed the Chair's warning.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Social Security inform the House of the progress made by the Government in dealing with welfare fraud?

QUESTION.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question and I understand the discomfort of the Opposition. It is possible, and indeed worthwhile, to answer such a question in the Parliament because the message does not seem to have got through to the Opposition, although I believe that it is getting through to the Australian public, that this Government takes questions of tax and social security and welfare fraud very seriously. ANSWER.PARA: Another majority benefit would be a reduction of fraud affecting government outlays, especially social welfare payments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Then why don't you?

—The Leader of the National Party asks me why we do not. Let me run through some of the measures that we have taken this year, in order to remind the House of how seriously we have taken the matter of social security fraud. Earlier, during the answer of the Special Minister of State, I heard some interjections referring to the question of cheques. Who introduced the system of direct deposits as a measure designed to remove fraudulent dealing in cheques? It was also this Government which announced earlier this year the social security amnesty, which was a very successful enterprise despite the great deal of criticism that it received from the other side of the House. As a result of that, we were able to save $20m.

ANSWER.PARA: We have taken a number of steps, which were announced in the course of the Budget Speech, for reviewing the long term unemployed and, as a result of adding a number of staff to the Department of Social Security, we have introduced a considerable additional number of checks on people receiving unemployment benefits. We have also introduced a new approach to the administration of the supporting parent benefit. It is unfortunate that, despite the steps that the Government is taking, the Opposition constantly misrepresents those steps in the form of Press releases that are put out by members of the Opposition. We have just had a question from the shadow Minister for Health. On 11 November he put out a Press release saying that the Government had eliminated the work test. That would have to be regarded as an outright lie. He said that we had not enforced Commonwealth Employment Service registration--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member will withdraw that comment.
—Well, certainly it was a total misrepresentation of the Government's position.
—Order! The honourable member will withdraw, and then he may continue.

—I withdraw. The shadow Minister said that we had not enforced Commonwealth Employment Service registration, in the very month that we announced that people who were not registered with the CES would not get their benefits. He also said that we had done away with personal lodgment of SU-19B forms or income statements for the unemployed, at the very time that we are making such statements compulsory and requiring personal lodgment for the first time for some years on a universal basis.

ANSWER.PARA: When it comes to the question of fraud and overpayments, we are constantly assailed by the inability of members of the Opposition to convey in their Press releases even some basic understanding of what the Government is doing. Of course, what this gets down to in the end is the Australia Card, because that is the question that in many ways will be the touchstone of the Government's position, the clarity of the Government's position, with respect to its commitment to reducing fraud and overpayments. The position is that members of the Opposition have moved to an opportunistic situation in which they no longer are prepared to say what many leading members of the Opposition really believe. Let me make it clear that, whilst the Government has taken a number of steps, we believe that the Australia Card is an additional step that needs to be taken if we are to complete our overall strategy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Health to his statement during Question Time yesterday that `a security device will be attached to the backs of particular batches of cards, again to prevent forgery'. Why is the digitised strip to be attached to the backs of only particular batches of cards? What proportion of cards will have a digitised strip? Will not the failure to attach a strip to all cards undermine the integrity of the card? Given that this security device will not be readable, will banks and other financial institutions have to acquire machinery for the purposes of validating the ID card? If not, what mechanisms will be put in place to prevent a forged ID card being presented for the purposes of opening an account to conduct a quick laundering operation in the process of organised crime?

—First of all, the honourable member has misunderstood what I said yesterday. The digital strips will apply to all cards and the security device will be on all cards. What I did say, however, is that that security device would not be the same on every batch of cards. In order to have as highly protective a mechanism as possible there would be different security devices on different batches of cards. One of the things I am saying is that that security device is just one of a number of protections in relation to the card. The authority itself will be able to read that card, pick up that device. It may not be possible in every case to immediately identify a forged card if it should turn up, but over time the device provided will protect the system against fraudulent cards just as it protects the present system against fraudulent bank notes. I made the point again yesterday that there is a range of protections, unlike any other card that we have in this society. The additional protections are digitalised photographs, which will be virtually impossible to alter, and digitalised signatures. There will also be identifying information on the Register if there should be some problem of contradiction between information supplied and that on the card. There is a whole range of protective devices which I believe will ensure that the card has the same integrity at least as the high integrity currency of this country.
—Has the Minister for Primary Industry seen Press reports of how the proposed Australia Card might affect farmers? Can the Minister advise the House whether those reports are accurate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did see the report and I guess that my comments are more in pity than in anger because members of the Opposition obviously cannot resist the same old scare story tactics that they have been employing here. The whole assertion is demonstrably false. Clause 43 (2) of the Bill requires production of the card once only for all transactions through a particular marketing authority or produce agent. I repeat that where farmers are required to produce an Australia Card, this will be a once only requirement to enable the authority or agent to record the number. Subsequently transactions with that authority or agent will not require the production of a card. If one thinks about the administration of the interest rate subsidy scheme for drought, revolving the wool funds or giving money back for any purpose through the wheat fund-we recirculated $100m recently-having an identification card would be an enormous benefit to the authority concerned. With all the other things in train now, such as the computer aided livestock marketing and Ausmeat, a simple identification card would be an enormous facilitation to the primary industries.

ANSWER.PARA: Farmers living in isolated areas-this follows from other questions to the Minister for Health-or farmers who could not reasonably be expected to attend the office of the marketing authority or produce agent will be able to sign a certificate of identity which will enable them to transact business with a marketing authority without physically presenting their cards. Further transactions can then be conducted over the phone or through the mail. The same thing applies with respect to other people. The Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia has said quite bluntly that he supported the Australia Card in the past. He said:

The use of plastic cards for an effective means of identification would streamline the collection of tax revenue, imposing a greater accountability on that small minority of taxpayers who sought to evade their responsibilities to the community.
I can only say that this recent change of heart fills me with pity rather than anger. I think it is a sorry day when he sells out on principles.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Health. Is it a fact that the identity card system cannot assist in the detection of the cash economy transactions where there is no requirement for the issue of group certificates, tax stamp sheets, et cetera, and where there is no documentary record of the cash transaction? Do the cash transactions excluded from the ID card system include all householder transactions under $10,000 including the employment of gardeners, painters, plumbers, electricians and other household handymen?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I explained again yesterday and I point out again for the honourable member's information, we did not say that the Australia Card will solve all of the taxation problems that this country faces. I admitted that its impact in relation to the cash economy would be mainly of an indirect form-that is, the argument that significant amounts of money in the cash economy usually come into the financial system at some point in time or, as I say, into the purchase of land and houses, which is why we are requiring the reporting of those particular events. Because the Australia Card will be able to trace this flow of money coming from inex- plicable sources, it will aid the whole audit process and have a major impact in relation to the indirect economy, but it will not solve all the problems we are facing in the taxation economy.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, when this Government made the decision to move down this path, it had to balance out all these issues. I ask the members of the Opposition simply to give some consideration to what the Age said this morning; that in tackling a very difficult issue such as this we have to secure a proper balance. What the Age said deserves repeating. It states:

On balance, we believe, the honest citizen and conscientious taxpayer has much more to gain and little to risk through the introduction of the Australia Card and its strictly controlled identity register. Mr Howard's contention that the proposed identity card meant treating ``all Australians like cheats and criminals'' is nonsense. Only cheats and criminals have reason to conceal or falsify their identity when it is properly required for taxation and social security purposes, and they are robbing the community of hundreds of millions of dollars a year.
That is the balance this Government has struck and will stick to.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Housing and Construction. Are savings banks fulfilling their lending commitment to the Government at current housing interest rates?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes. The savings banks are fulfilling their commitment to the Government. For the information of the House, total housing lending during the month of September was in excess of $1 billion and that included a figure of $710m from savings banks, up by 11 per cent for the month. Lending by permanent building societies was up by 8.4 per cent to $200m. That means that during the month of September the savings banks were lending at an annualised rate of $8.5 billion, whereas their commitment to the Government through the package was to lend $6 billion or more.
—How about interest rates?

—Obviously interest rates are the key to future lending levels and the key to future housing activity. But I am very encouraged by the recent downward trend in bank bill rates, which are now at 16 per cent, down by 2.5 per cent from 18 1/2 per cent 10 weeks ago.

ANSWER.PARA: My attention is drawn to the fact that the National Australia Bank yesterday announced that its new loans to non-customers would henceforth be at the rate of 17 1/2 per cent. But I ask the House to note very carefully that over 80 per cent, according to the National Australia Bank's spokesman, is currently being lent and will be lent at the rate of 15 1/2 per cent. That means that the action of the National Australia Bank should not be seen as the first step towards general increases in the savings banks rate but rather should be seen merely as a means of stabilising that bank's particular lending portfolio.

The National Australia Bank's profitability figures released the other day illustrate that it is not exactly in deep trouble. For instance, it returned a yearly profit of $304m, which meant that it is able to announce an increased dividend of 29c a share. I make the comment, in passing, that as the National Australia Bank is one of those corporations in Australia that frequently make calls to the Government to exercise restraint in spending and calls on the workers of Australia to exercise wage restraint, since it has been able to increase its dividend from a profitability for the year 1986-87 of $304m, I also call upon it to exercise restraint on housing interest rates.

Arising from what I have just said, let me make three points: Firstly, if the National Australia Bank's action is a move in a campaign to force an eventual rise in the 13 1/2 per cent regulated savings bank rates, that campaign will not succeed because the Government is committed to the maintenance of the regulated 13 1/2 per cent rate. Secondly, as I have said--

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems to me that the Opposition has a lot to say about our policy. This comes from an Opposition that does not have a housing policy and does not have a policy about anything at all that I can observe-no policy at all. Let us look at what the Australian had to say the other day. It stated:

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Howard's party needs desperately to have a solid identifiable alternative policy that has been well explained to the voters. It will go nowhere while it flounders around aimlessly failing to project a leader and the policies that are needed to back up that leader.

As far as housing policies are concerned, the Opposition has nothing to offer the people of Australia. I might just say that, if any person in his right mind is inclined to take the 17 1/2 per cent loan offered to non-customers by the National Australia Bank I am puzzled. They should look around at what is available from other banks and other permanent building societies in Australia because, as I have shown, the savings banks and building societies in Australia, particularly in New South Wales, have ample money to lend at the current rate of 15 1/2 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Minister for Health that, as Mr Meagher, Queen's Counsel, the former counsel to the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union has stated categorically, moneys in the cash economy are not put in the bank and are never declared. Does the Minister acknowledge that, in the cash economy, moneys used for purposes such as the acquisition of antique clocks or other objects d'art, as well as everyday household purchases which do not go through financial institutions, can never be detected?

—With reference again to the cash economy and to the Costigan report, Mr Costigan was so convinced that much of the money he was searching for could be traced through the banking system that he made a series of recommendations suggesting quite massive identification procedures in relation to bank accounts.
—Mr Costigan has come out against the Australia Card.

—Mr Costigan disagrees with us on the Australia Card but there is no doubt that he believed that much of this black economy money did find its way into financial institutions and he proposed quite elaborate identification procedures in relation to bank accounts.
—Order! The Minister for Health will cease for a moment. I have twice asked the honourable member for North Sydney to heed the Chair. If he continues in the way he is going I will name him.

—A number of reports have also recognised the way much of that money goes into real estate. It is for that very reason that we are introducing the new reporting procedures for tax in relation to real estate purchases accompanied by the Australia Card.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. In light of the Pacific Rim Conference which started in Perth yesterday, will the Minister advise the House of recent developments in Australia's trade with nations of the western Pacific region?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was very pleased to be able to be in the electorate of the honourable member for Perth yesterday and to participate in the opening sessions of the PACRIM Conference which I think will go down as one of the most significant conferences dealing with investment and trade in our region. It is a very great credit to Western Australia, and particularly the Western Australian Government, that they had the foresight to put together that conference. There are nearly 400 delegates from a large number of countries. I suppose that the most significant point about the composition of the delegates is that not only were important people from countries of our immediate region there, for instance, China, Malaysia and a large number of other countries, but also a very large number of delegates from countries outside the region, particularly the United States of America and Europe because, of course, the United States and Europe, and in particular the companies there, recognise the importance and the dynamism of our region and the important part that Australia has to play in it. I was, therefore, very delighted to hear the statements of the Chairman of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd who spoke at the opening session. As reported today he said:

ANSWER.PARA: Australia had become attractive for foreign investment.
This is what Sir James told the conference. He said:
. . . the depreciated dollar and the recently relaxed foreign investment guidelines make Australia a more attractive venue for overseas investment.
Calling for more investment into Australia, Sir James said:
There would seem to be mutually beneficial opportunities for such investment at present, particularly in export-oriented manufacturing industries.

I therefore was a bit surprised to read the comments of one of Sir James's directors, one of his most recently acquired directors on the board of BHP. Yesterday John Elliott reportedly said, in the midst of a large number of other political statements about the Government:
I assume he means Elders IXL; maybe he meant BHP as well, but I would be very surprised, given the comments of Sir James--
have discouraged major international companies from making new investment in Australia . . .

That seems to be a quite extraordinary attitude for someone who occupies the kind of position he does in business, but perhaps less surprising when one considers his political affiliations. But, so intrigued was I by his statements that I decided to refresh my research of what John Elliott had been saying about export opportunities in Australia. I recall that on 14 August he was reported as follows:
Mr John Elliott told Australian businessmen yesterday that they have enormous and sudden new opportunities for exporting . . .

He went on to tell the forum that, because of the dollar's depreciation, Japanese and United States companies suddenly had put Australia on the list as a potential off-shore manufacturing base. A little less than two weeks later he again entered into the fray on this issue and said something quite contradictory. He said that Australia would be the last place that his company would want to invest. At the end of the month, just a little less than two weeks later, when he was participating in the Australia Japan Business Co-operation Committee, he made this statement at the end of that meeting:

Following the decline in value of the Australian dollar Australia is now a very cost efficient country in which to manufacture. The food processing sector in Australia is a large and efficient industry which presents attractive opportunities for investment. Japanese companies looking to diversify some of their manufacturing of domestic production to other countries were well placed to take advantage of this situation as Australia has freed up its foreign investment policies.

When one tries to link these four statements, the first and second of them encouraging people not to invest, the third and fourth encouraging people to invest and pointing to the very strong features of the Australian economy, one has to speculate about why there would be this massive inconsistency. At first I thought that it may just have been that he had been lured under the spell of the Opposition in its deliberate attempt to denigrate this country, its campaign of economic sabotage in which it is so gleefully indulging whenever it gets the opportunity. But then the Prime Minister reminded us today that Mr Elliott has very little to do with the current Opposition. So there must indeed be some other reason for that behaviour. I contacted the Bureau of Meteorology and I discovered that the negative statements about Australia, the statements in which Mr Elliott discourages people to invest, coincide almost precisely with the days on which there has been a full moon in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do.
—Please proceed.

—Both the Sydney Morning Herald and the Australian of today's date contain the statement that the question I asked the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) yesterday was a dorothy dixer. It is very hard to find a definition of the phrase `dorothy dixer'. The Parliamentary Library could find only one definition, contained in the University of Queensland's Dictionary of Australian Politics. It says that a dorothy dixer is a prearranged question. The question I asked the Prime Minister was not prearranged; he had no notice of it at all. It is not my practice to ask such questions.
—Order! The honourable member has made his personal explanation.
—The question was totally without notice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do.
—Please proceed.

—Yesterday during Question Time the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), in answer to a question from the honourable member for Prospect (Dr Klugman), suggested that I misrepresented factual information when I took up publicly in recent weeks the issue of economic hardship facing many single income middle class families in Australia. The Minister suggested that I had based my research on the assumption that higher income families deserve a generous standard of living while pensioner families should be allowed merely a survival existence. He suggested that I had cooked up my research, implying that it lacked integrity. Finally, he alleged that the motivation behind my research was entirely punitive towards people on very low incomes. This attack on me by the Minister follows other misrepresentations--
—Order! The honourable member will get to the point of the misrepresentation and not debate the issue.

—I will. I did not cook up research or attempt to misrepresent facts. My information was based on research by the Institute of Family Studies, which the Government endorses, and it also endorses the former Social Welfare Policy Secretariat, as well as the Parliamentary Library from which my statistics were gained. The Minister challenged both the motivation and the accuracy of that research.
—Order! I believe the honourable member is now getting beyond his substantiation of the misrepresentation.

—I have one concluding paragraph. I consider what the Minister has done to be very unfair, unhelpful to public debate on the issue and inappropriate in this place. I therefore seek leave to table my statistics and brief supporting notes which indicate all assumptions.

PETITION.TITLE: Closure of Post Office Agencies
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we strenuously object to the proposal that many Post Office Agencies are to be closed. They provide a network of offices with postal and agency services to residential areas and small communities.

They serve a community need and we would be seriously inconvenienced if forced to travel further to purchase postal items or collect parcels. It would be an unnecessary expense particularly for pensioners without their own transport.

We maintain that the purpose of Post Offices should be to serve the public for the variety of services they offer. They are a community centre particularly in country areas and if necessary they should be subsidised to retain them.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House should take all possible steps to prevent the closure of post office agencies and that the network should be extended, with the Agency services they offer expanded.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale,Mr Ian Cameron,Dr Harry Edwards,Mr Hawker,Mr Nehl,Mr Ruddock,Mr Shipton and Mr Slipper.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will: Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum''.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Charles,Mr Hawker,Mr Reith and Mr Shipton.

PETITION.TITLE: Radioactive Substances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth. We most strongly oppose the process of Food Irradiation by radioactive Cobalt 60 or any other radioactive substance.

We oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process by State Governments. We express our deep concern at this attempt to extend the use of radioactive substances and exposure of workers to radiation.

We call on the Government to immediately ban the importation of radioactive Cobalt 60 or other radioactive substances and to immediately disallow the regulations that permit the irradiation of food here in Australia.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Ms Jakobsen,Mr Kent,Mr Milton and Mr Staples.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
We, the undersigned, are deeply concerned at the impact of the new Fringe Benefits Tax on the following grounds:
1. Its severe and damaging effect on business confidence, investment and incentive, especially in the rural, mining and small business sectors.
2. Its capacity to seriously worsen unemployment through the additional costs it imposes.
3. Its extremely negative impact on the competitiveness of export industries at a time when the nation desperately needs to improve its trading performance.

4. In that it may compel many honest and decent citizens to defy the Tax in order to preserve their livelihoods, their businesses and the jobs of their employees, thus causing hardship, the breakdown of respect for the law and discord within the community.
We therefore most earnestly petition you to repeal the Fringe Benefits Tax legislation forthwith.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
