2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
The Union Jack-itself the creation of 3 Christian crosses-represents the nation's historical origin, and the source of its language and law.
The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House will propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian national flag remains sacrosanct from change''.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Extradition (Foreign States) Act 1966
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the humble petitioners have grave concern about recent changes in the Extradition (Foreign States) Act of 1966 which deny basic rights which have been a cornerstone of the English and Australian law for over seven hundred years. We are speaking of the right to be presumed innocent until proven guilty and the right of an individual to defend himself against his accusers. This concern has come to light during recent extradition proceedings against Messrs, Hempel and Etheredge in Western Australia.

We are concerned that because judicial protection of these basic rights has been excluded from the Act refugees, migrants, Australian overseas travellers, and visitors are at risk when they have been to (or come from) countries where the norms and practices of human rights and civil liberties are below traditionally accepted Australian standards.

We, the undersigned petitioners, therefore urge the Government to re-examine the Extradition (Foreign States) Act as amended in 1985, and amend the current Act so that the rights of the accused are once again judicially protected in Australia.

In addition, we urge the Government to refrain from entering into any further extradition treaties or proceedings under the current Act until the process of re-examination and amendment of the Act has occurred.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Government should cancel the Fringe Benefits Tax they intend to impose on businesses throughout Australia because:
1. The tax discriminates against charitable organisations, sports clubs, private schools and religious organisations;
2. The tax will mean employees around Australia will suffer reductions in their renumeration packages;
3. The Bill places another impossible burden of paperwork on small business;
4. The Bill is absurd in its application to Government employees, who now constitute 32% of the workforce.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Small Businesses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the intention of the Hawke Government to unionise independent contractors, sub-contractors, the self-employed, partnerships, sole traders and family businesses will:
Remove the freedom of independent small business to:
(a) set their own prices
(b) work their own hours
(c) control their own businesses
(d) negotiate their own contracts; and
will create impossible working conditions which will include the payment of:
(a) union superannuation
(b) compensation
(c) payroll tax
(d) annual leave loadings
(e) public holiday loadings
(f) PAYE tax deductions
(g) limited incomes
(h) inflexible awards and conditions; and
(i) fixed hours of work.
We the undersigned call upon the Government to restore incentive and opportunity to the Australian economy and to abandon these coercive measures.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances and Spouse Rebate
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
Graduated family allowances are of important assistance to families with more than one child.
All family allowances, whether for one, two, three or more children, have not kept pace with inflation.
There are suggestions that all family allowances should be paid at the one flat rate. This would severely disadvantage families with more than one child.
There are also suggestions that the dependent spouse rebate be reduced or removed. This would represent another blow to the family unit.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should:
ask the Federal Government to increase the value of existing family allowance payments, and
reject any moves to change the payments to a flat rate or to tamper with the spouse rebate;
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Bill of Rights is a dangerous piece of legislation which gives us no new legally enforceable rights;
That the Bill of Rights leaves out vital rights such as the right not to belong to a trade union, the right to own private property, the right to a private education;
That the Bill of Rights gives dangerous new powers to a Federal Government Commission to investigate in private, without legal representation and with criminal penalties for refusing to co-operate;
That the Bill of Rights deals with our rights; therefore we, the people, should say whether we want it by a referendum.
Your petitioners therefore pray that you will oppose the Bill of Rights, support Liberal amendments to improve it in case it is passed, and pledge to repeal it should it become law.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fuel Prices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That the Hawke Government should;
1. Pass on the full benefit of lower international oil prices;
2. Not increase or extend fuel taxes, and
3. Maintain its tax cut commitments.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Hawke Government honour its commitment to the Import Parity Pricing policy.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in the light of the Labor Government's failure to act to correct the many anomalies in the Assets Test on pensions brought to its notice, the Labor Government's legislation should be repealed before it has an unduly unfair impact on pensioners.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately seek the repeal of the Labor Government's iniquitous and unfair Assets Test.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Economic Justice for Families
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled:

Your petitioners call for Government intervention to provide economic justice for families and humbly pray that whatever action possible be taken to provide some price control in the following areas, which most directly affect the family budget:
food and other essential items
petrol
rent and bond levels.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the failure of the Government to honour its election promises to pensioners.
In particular those promises relate to the following commitments:
1. That within three years of its election to office, a Hawke Labor Government would raise the level of the standard pension to 25% of Average Weekly Earnings;
2. That the lag time between the announcement of the Consumer Price Index figures and the subsequent adjustment of pensions would be reduced to one month, and
3. That the disproportionate tax burden borne by low income earners would be lifted.
None of these promises has been honoured to date.

Your petitioners are extremely angry at the failure of the Government to live up to its commitments and as in duty bound will ever pray that these serious omissions will be given the attention they deserve.

PETITION.TITLE: Matters Affecting the Ethnic Community
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled, the petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth opposition to cuts in English as a Second Language (ESL) teaching, the scrapping of the Multicultural Education Program, the amalgamation of the Special Broadcasting Service (SBS) with the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC), and the abolition of the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs (AIMA), as announced in the Federal Budget of August 19, 1986.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Government will review and reverse its decisions on these matters.
And your petitioners, in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Identity Cards
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that we strongly oppose the introduction of the `Australia Card' or any other form of National Identification Numbering System.

We believe that the introduction of a National Identification Numbering System is not only totally unnecessary but is a severe threat to our civil liberties and privacy. We condemn the Government's actions on this matter, particularly as no reasonable nor responsible justifications for the proposal have been forthcoming from the Government.
We humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should reject any proposal for a National Identification Numbering System.

PETITION.TITLE: Summerland Point Post Office, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
1. That the Summerland Point Post Office recently closed at short notice by Australia Post should be reopened.
2. This Post Office has serviced a community consisting mainly of the aged and young families with small children who are now faced with a five kilometre journey to the nearest Post Office.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should ask the Minister for Communications not to deny the 800 permanent residents of Summerland Point on Lake Macquarie the use of a Post Office.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The Hawke Labor Government's productivity- superannuation accord with the ACTU and its support of the superannuation claims of the trade union movement will create an imbalance in industrial power and distort the future development of the Australian economy.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Reject the superannuation claim of the trade union movement, and allow superannuation to develop without trade union domination.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain electors of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the Bill of Rights Bill, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Amendment Bill and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill, if passed by the Parliament, will undermine the human and civil rights in Australia; will attack the institution of the family in our country, and will destroy States Rights and the federal nature of our Commonwealth.
Your petitioners humbly pray that:
The Parliament rejects these Bills; abolishes the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and moves to withdraw ratification of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: English as a Second Language Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Honourable Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth:

By cutting ESL funding and eliminating funding for community languages and multicultural education you have attacked tens of thousands of Australian children. You have condemned these children with limited English to gross educational inequality and very dim prospects for their future.
On behalf of these children we call on you to remove this new discrimination which your budget has guaranteed by immediately restoring ESL and Multicultural education funding.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Capital Gains
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:

That the Capital Gains tax penalises small business, discourages long-term investment, hinders capital formation and wealth creation, has contributed to Australia's economic crises and contains many anomalies.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately repeal the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Capital Gains) Act 1986.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Horticultural Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned, are deeply concerned that Australia's important horticultural industry is being severely disadvantaged by unnecessarily rising production costs.

Many Federal and State Government regulations, excessive taxes and charges are damaging the ability of horticultural growers to maintain supplies of food and plant production to Australian families at a realistic cost. Widespread unemployment will result if horticultural producers are further depressed.

The undersigned humbly petition the Parliaments of Australia, its States and Territories, to take all measures within their powers to reduce the burden of imposed costs and regulation, allowing Australian horticultural growers to develop production potential so the nation, as a whole, can share the benefits of the resulting growth and prosperity.
Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Amalgamation of Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Special Broadcasting Service
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth:

We the undersigned residents of Australia deplore the decision by the Federal Government to amalgamate the SBS with the ABC. At present there is no guarantee that the principles of multicultural broadcasting will be maintained at any level of the ABC administration. An independent and strong SBS should be retained. We therefore pray that the amalgamation of the ABC and the SBS be opposed.

PETITION.TITLE: Housing-related Poverty
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of citizens of Australia shows that-
Approximately 100,000 Australians live on the verge of homelessness, dependent on government resources to survive, or sleep out of doors or in refuges.
Over 700,000 households, or in excess of 2 million Australians are living below the poverty line after paying their rent or mortgage costs.
In addition, there are thousands of households with special needs, such as the disabled, who are not well catered for in the private sector but who nevertheless require suitable housing.
Waiting lists for public housing have almost doubled in the past five years to 146,000 by June 1985. The list is expected to grow to some 250,000 by 1990.
We therefore ask that the Australian Government, as a highest priority:
undertake a campaign to bring the issue of poverty and, in particular, housing-related poverty, to the attention of the Australian public
increase expenditure on public housing through the Commonwealth State Housing Agreement, by at least 15% annually in real terms
increase rent relief payments for those on low incomes in the private rental market
use its influence with State and Territory governments to encourage them to increase their expenditures on public housing.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Test Ban
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
This Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that-

(1) A cessation of the testing of nuclear weapons would break the cycle of research, development and deployment of nuclear weapons and prevent the acquisition of new and ever more lethal weapons of mass destruction. It would thus be a major and significant step towards ending the arms race and beginning the disarmament process; and
(2) The Soviet Union has extended its unilateral moratorium on nuclear weapons testing until 6 August this year and has again invited the United States to cease its nuclear testing program.
Your petitioners therefore urge the Australian Government to put the strongest pressure on the United States Government to join the Soviet Union's nuclear test ban.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: International Year for Repairing the Earth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out:

That, for our survival, an effective Worldpeace Initiative needs to be established which will work towards mutual understanding, world disarmament, economic well-being for all and full employment. This Initiative will help to ensure a sustainable society conserving natural resources, and revitalising soils essential for growing a plentiful and healthy food supply and tree cover for the needs of present and future generations. By working for these objectives, Australia can set an example for the rest of the world.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will:
1. Propose to the United Nations General Assembly that 1989 be declared International Year for Repairing the Earth.
2. Implement action programs leading up to 1989 which will include:
(a) Actively supporting the International Year of Peace in 1986 by reallocating at least 10% of our military expenditure to fund environmental repair programs.

(b) Implementing National Recycling Programs to reuse water, and to compost into hygienic humus all presently wasted organic garbage and sewage-sludge mixed with fine ground powder from mineral-rich gravels and rocks, to use as a natural fertiliser in revitalising impoverished soils;

(c) Developing National Employment Programs to give priority to irrigation systems and the planting and growing of healthy forests, food-producing trees and other crops and vegetation to assist the greening of Australia.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Identity Cards
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:

The Hawke Labor Government's ID card proposal is the most far reaching and intrusive piece of Australian legislation ever, and that on all the evidence available will not tackle in the most cost-efficient and effective manner tax and social security fraud.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Reject Labor's ID card proposal to prevent a gross waste of taxpayers' money and a significant infringement of civil liberties.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Capital Gains
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:

Labor's Capital Gains Tax is standing in the way of economic development on the Far North Coast, a region with great potential for further growth and renowned for the enterprise and initiative of its local community.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Repeal its anti-business anti-farming and anti-individual Capital Gains Tax.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Regional Stations
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Federal Division of Maranoa respectfully showeth that:
The ABC proposes to abolish certain country programmes from regional stations.
Such action will disadvantage those country listeners who only have the benefit of one radio station.

Regional stations broadcast entertainment and topics of local interest and any reduction in these programmes will undoubtedly inconvenience those listeners in the more remote and isolated areas of the state.
Talk back shows and the Hospital Hour are only two such programmes which it is thought are to be abolished.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Approach the ABC requesting that they reconsider their proposal to adopt the above and that commonsense prevail in ensuring that those listeners who reside in country areas are not disregarded.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax on Wine
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. The petition of certain residents of the State of Western Australia draws to the attention of the House that the Government has increased wholesale sales tax another 10% under the 1986-87 Budget, resulting in a 20% Sales Tax on wine.
This tax was introduced at a time of a record trade imbalance between our wine imports and exports and will further exacerbate that problem.

Your petitioners therefore ask that the Government cancels the 20% Sales Tax before it causes a further contraction in our wine industry, with consequential loss of exports, and employment in the wine and tourism and retailing industries which are currently operating in Western Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament:

The petition of certain residents of the Northern Territory of Australia draws to the attention of the House that the Fringe Benefits Tax Legislation recently passed by Parliament is unfair and will prejudice the current working conditions of all Territorians.
1. It will increase both personal and company taxation.
2. It will undermine employment levels through reducing profitability and international competitiveness of industry.
3. It will result in price increases.
4. It will force employers to withdraw voluntary incentives to employees paid over and above existing payments.
5. It endangers stable industrial relations because of the potential for forced withdrawal of Fringe Benefits.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House take such action as is necessary to rescind the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act 1986, the Fringe Benefits Tax Act 1986, the Fringe Benefits Tax (Application to the Commonwealth) Act 1986 and the Fringe Benefits Tax (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1986.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education Administration Fee
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable Speaker and the Honourable Members of the House of Representatives in the assembled Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia.
We the humble petitioners at Warrnambool Institute Student Union, in the Federal electorate of Wannon respectfully showeth:
That the introduction of an Administration Charge of $250 for higher education students in Appropriation Bill 1986-87 (Volume-1, Page-98) is a regressive step for the Education system;
That the introduction of an Administration Charge will force students to withdraw from studies and thereby destroy the opportunity for them to complete their education;
That the Administration Charge is a form of Tuition Fees and as such destroys the principle of free education for all;
We the humble petitioners hereby request you to amend the Appropriation Bill 1986-87, so that the system of free education for all students will continue.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Staff Elected Director
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The petition of the undersigned who are staff of the ABC and the SBS respectfully showeth that: The proposed legislation to amalgamate the ABC and the SBS, together with certain existing provisions of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act 1983 (as amended), would have the effect of removing the present Staff Elected Director of the ABC from office before the end of his elected term, and of barring him from standing for re-election. This offends basic democratic principle.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that: The Government will remedy this situation by either, continuing the current Staff Elected Director in office until the normal expiration of his term on 15 December 1987 or, making such amendments as are necessary to the Broadcasting and Television Legislation Amendment Act 1986, to enable the current Staff Elected Director to contest an early election after amalgamation, whilst preventing him from seeking a further term immediately following the one for which the early election is held.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Capital Gains
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Federal Division of Fisher respectfully showeth that:

The proposed capital gains tax penalises small business, discourages long-term investment, hinders capital formation and will freeze existing investment patterns and limits the investors' ability to adjust to changed market conditions.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Immediately abandon its ill-considered capital gains tax proposal.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Ayers Rock
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the electorate of Fisher respectfully showeth that:

Whereas the present Government of the Commonwealth of Australia has purported to present the Title Deeds to Ayers Rock in Central Australia, in reality the joint property of the people of the Commonwealth to an Aboriginal Land Council on 26 October 1985.

Whereas opinion polls and statements of representative groups, Members of Parliament and respected individuals show clearly that the Commonwealth Government had no mandate from the citizens of the Commonwealth to act in such a disgraceful manner.

Whereas the present Government claims to be totally opposed to apartheid (separate development) in South Africa but purported to hand over Ayers Rock to an Aboriginal Council in support of a policy of apartheid (separate development) which has been shown to be detrimental to the Aboriginal people of Australia.

Whereas it is pursuing this policy making it a crime for most white and many Aboriginals to enter, without permit, large areas of the Commonwealth designated apartheid (i.e., set aside for separate development), contrary to our democratic traditions and experience of freedom of movement for citizens of all racial origins within Australia.
Whereas Australian citizens have no present means available to them to prevent this violation of their natural rights to unfettered common ownership of, and access to, a treasured natural asset.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Seek means available for the protection of the people's interests to reverse this outrage and preserve the democratic traditions of Australia.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Home Loan Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of the Federal Division of Fisher in Queensland respectfully showeth:
that the current policy pursued by the Hawke Government is causing an intolerable increase in home loan interest rates beyond the capacity of families to pay.
that consequently this policy is causing grave hardship throughout Australia and is contributing to social problems and the breakup of the family unit.
that unless the Government act urgently the Australian dream of home ownership is fast becoming shattered for many of our citizens.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray: That the Government make home loan interest rates tax deductible therefore alleviating the present crippling burden of current high interest rates on home owners and home buyers.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Federal Division of Fisher in Queensland respectfully showeth:

That the proposed Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985 will endanger the Federal system of Australia, the State and Federal criminal justice systems, the State and Federal Police Forces, the State and Federal education systems, the independence of the churches and religious associations, marriage and the family, children, the unborn, the handicapped, the aged and the infirm, employer and employee relationships and Australian society generally.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Repeal the Bill of Rights legislation forthwith.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Federal Division of Fisher respectfully showeth that:

The Government's actions in changing levels of pharmaceutical benefits will adversely effect the infirm and elderly and that it will cause further unnecessary economic hardship and suffering among all people who are currently dependant on existing benefits.
The Government's actions are little more than yet another burden placed upon our Australian citizens.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Restore pharmaceutical benefits to their former level, therefore lifting this inequitable burden now being placed squarely on the infirm throughout Australia.
Give a firm undertaking not to further desert those citizens in need of medical support.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Public Funding of Projects
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Federal Division of Fisher respectfully showeth:

1. That we, the undersigned, are totally opposed to substantial Federal Government funding presently being wasted on undesirable, inefficient and incompetently run Government projects that are unacceptable to the vast majority of decent Australians.
2. That Government grants should not be directed toward projects that are of no, or dubious, worth to the improvement of Australia.
3. That public funding should not be used in encouraging lifestyles contrary to the Australian family way of life.

4. That public moneys should not be given to minority groups to support projects that are of a direct political nature. Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Halt forthwith the public funding for the abovementioned purposes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the State of Queensland respectfully showeth that:
The legislation to tax fringe benefits is iniquitous, inequitable and unfair;
It will severely disadvantage both employees and employers;
Employees will clearly lose many fringe benefits as a direct result of the additional heavy taxation burden being imposed upon employers;
Employers will be forced to pay even higher levels of taxation to provide fringe benefits for employees.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Immediately abandon the Fringe Benefits Tax.
And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Compulsory Unionism
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Queensland respectfully showeth:

That the actions of trade unions have gone beyond their traditional goals of protecting workers conditions and rates of pay and have reached the point where they are seriously affecting the economic health of the nation and the people.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:
1. That all Governments throughout Australia acknowledge and protect the Right to Work on behalf of all Australians.
2. That the total sovereignty of individual governments be recognised as a fundamental requirement of a workable, balanced Federal system of government.
3. That all necessary steps be taken to protect the citizens of Australia from any inducement, compulsion, threat or intimidation to join any trade union.
4. That there should be no preference in employment for people who are members of trade unions.
5. That the supremacy of elected governments over the sectional interests of trade unions be recognised, and
6. That the provision of essential services be maintained, free from industrial disruption.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium Sales to France
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned, respectfully showeth that we, the people of Victoria would like to remind you of your moral duty in regard to your decision to sell Uranium to France, against ALP policy.
The French are still nuclear testing in the South Pacific, despite world wide protests. We therefore call on you to reverse the decision to sell uranium to France.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of certain citizens of Queensland, Australia, respectfully showeth that we are totally opposed to any change in the Australian National Flag as declared in the Flags Act (1953).
Your petitioners humbly pray that Parliament in its wisdom will take no action to change the Australian National Flag.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government's use of the ID card proposal to camouflage its failure to effectively utilise existing resources to maintain the integrity of the social security system.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday in this place the annual report of the Director of Public Prosecutions was tabled. That report confirmed what we on this side of the House have been saying and what all the Australian people know; that is, that the Australian Labor Party is the friend of the welfare cheats. The report exposed the inadequate, totally unrealistic policies of this Government towards social security. It exposed the permissive and tolerant approach of this Government to the cheats on the welfare system. It condemned the Labor Party for what it really is-the friend of welfare cheats. We said that the Government does not do enough to catch the cheats. Mr Temby said that when the Government does catch them it does not prosecute them-damning evidence from the Director of Public Prosecutions. I would like to quote briefly from the report. Mr Temby, in his report, said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . welfare fraud is not being effectively controlled . . . many serious cases are not being referred to the DPP simply because they have not been investigated . . . less serious matters are investigated by DSS, but more serious cases are referred to the AFP for investigation.

Unfortunately, the Australian Federal Police does not have the resources to cope with the task. Mr Temby went on to condemn the briefs prepared by the Department of Social Security as not always being of good quality. He said:
. . . officers . . . have little or no experience or training in conducting criminal investigations . . .

More damning than that, he said that the Department of Social Security `does not see investigation as the primary function of its field officers'. If it is not the primary function of field officers, whose responsibility is it within the Department of Social Security to ensure that the checks and the tests that should operate within our social security system are in fact applied? Of course, under this Government field officer numbers have been reduced. What really happened yesterday was that the cover-up that this Government has been running on social security fraud was exposed. It is not the first time that it has been exposed. Never before has it been exposed in such great detail by someone of such high standing in the community as the Director of Public Prosecutions. Previously it has been exposed by other people, who have been attacked by the Minister and this Government because of what they sought to do-to draw to the attention of the Australian taxpayer the rorts and the rip-offs that this Government has allowed to go on.

I do not believe that there is a member in this chamber who is not aware of the work of Mr Peter Sawyer, a former officer of the Department of Social Security, who actually wrote a book on the inadequacies of this Government's social security policy. That book documented chapter and verse the ways in which the system was being rorted and ripped off. What happened to Mr Sawyer for his efforts? The Minister persecuted him. Without any hesitation, the Minister immediately acted to prosecute him and to stifle debate on the matter. The matter went to court. What happened then? This cowboy who masquerades as the Minister for Social Security was so quick to fire off charges against Mr Sawyer. What happened to those charges? They were thrown out of court. That was how good his case was. Of course, the motive in charging Mr Sawyer was to silence criticism of the inadequacies of his policies. The judge dismissed the charges totally.

Everybody knows that the Australian social security system is being milked and ripped off. In fact, the public knowledge of that is so widespread that we have even seen articles appearing in foreign newspapers detailing how to come to Australia and rip off the system. Such articles do not appear in just English language newspapers. They have even appeared in Chinese language newspapers. Of course, the Minister stands up and defends his position. He maintains that there is no fraud and no rip-off. He claims that there is no need for any further changes. The fact is that this Government has opened the floodgates to the cheats, the rip-off merchants and the people who are prepared to rort the Australian taxpayer.

Since coming to office, this Government has virtually abolished the work test. It did not enforce registration with the Commonwealth Employment Service. The Minister can raise his eyebrows as much as he likes, but the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, said that there were 116 people on unemployment benefits for every 100 people registered with the CES. How could that happen if the Minister were enforcing his manual which says that an unemployed person must be registered? Of course, the Government did away with the requirement for personal lodgment of the 19b forms, the continuation forms for unemployment benefits. The Minister will be quick to tell us later today that in the last Budget the Government changed all that. He was dragged screaming to make those changes by his colleagues-by the Treasurer (Mr Keating), who said that there were rip-off merchants on unemployment benefits, and by the Minister for Finance. The Minister for Social Security was dragged screaming into the Budget session of this Parliament to make those changes. Of course, they are only superficial changes. The Government changed the legislation but did nothing to give the Department of Social Security the human resources, the field officers and the other people necessary to enforce those changes.

Quite frankly, the Minister has a blind eye when it comes to people ripping off the system. He did nothing about Kiwi dole cheats until he was forced to do so by a massive weight of public opinion. He allowed prisoners in New South Wales and Victorian gaols to continue receiving unemployment benefits. Initially, he said that that was not happening, but after conclusive evidence was produced he acted to do something about it. He has perpetuated the supporting parent rip-off and turned a blind eye to the transfer of unemployment beneficiaries on to sickness and other benefits to which they are not genuinely entitled. Also, the Minister is as aware as I am that the Australian Medical Association is extremely concerned at pressure coming from some regional offices of the Department of Social Security for medical certificates to be produced for people who have no medical entitlement to certain categories of social security benefit. That is the attitude of the Minister for Social Security to the payment of benefits in this country and the protection of the integrity of the system.

This Government has virtually done away with all the checks and balances and the tests that should be applied within the system. Not only has it done that, but it has reduced the number of field officers. It does not believe that field officers should investigate and it will not give them legislative authority to ask questions of clients of the Department of Social Security. There is a high level of vacancies in field officer positions in the Department and the Government has done nothing to fill those vacancies. Not only has the Government reduced the number of field officers, but it has taken them out of the field. These field officers may be on the staff as field officers, but what are they actually doing? They are sitting behind desks, where they are involved in payment procedures.

The Government will not allow the system to operate in the way in which it should. As a consequence of that, the social security system in Australia has fallen into contempt and disrepute. Australian people react daily against those people who genuinely need social security. We have asked him to give us a commitment to stopping fraud and to doing away with rorting and rip-offs in the system. Of course, nothing has happened, but as one part of its desperate campaign to build some credibility in this area the Government has reached for the ID card. The Minister himself does not support the ID card. I defy any member of this House to find an unequivocal statement from the Minister for Social Security saying that he supports the ID card. Quite frankly, the Minister is prepared to sell out his principles in order to save his political credibility as the Minister for giving away benefits. He is quite prepared to run around this Parliament and around Australia quoting my views on the ID card.

Let me state here and now exactly what my views on the ID card are. Last year I said that I supported the ID card. We had a joint parliamentary select committee. I spent four months on that committee and looked at about 20,000 pages of evidence. I say categorically now to the Minister for Social Security that I do not support ID cards simply because they will not work, they will not do the job, they are superficial, they are ineffective and there is a much better way of addressing the problem. In fact, the officers of his Department know that there is a much better way of addressing the problem. Mr Temby knows that there is a much better way of addressing the problem. He himself knows that there is a much better way of addressing the problem. Let me say now that, if the Minister again misquotes my views on the ID card, we will know exactly--

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: The quotation that I read in Question Time from 8 June 1985 was a quotation. There was no misrepresentation involved.
—There is no point of order. I call the honourable member for Richmond.
—Order! Honourable members on my left might be silent so that they can hear their colleague the honourable member for Richmond. I call the honourable member for Richmond.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I thank my colleagues for their support. Let me say again for the Minister's benefit: I do not support ID cards just as he does not support ID cards, and if that is not an accurate representation of his personal position he will have an opportunity in a minute to stand up and say categorically what his personal position is. Mr Temby said yesterday in his report that the Department of Social Security actually catches more welfare cheats than it prosecutes. Not only has it wound back the tests and the checks within the system; it has given those people virtual immunity from prosecution. It is an absolute disgrace. Yet those opposite come into this Parliament and argue the need for an ID card. They know that there is no net revenue gain to the Department of Social Security from ID cards. They know that the Department has said that it will not be relying on it. The Minister himself has said in answer to questions in this place that it will be only a principal form of identification and that the Department will still use other ways of identifying people seeking unemployment and other social security benefits. Perhaps more importantly, and germane to Temby's comments yesterday, is that the Government knows that less than one per cent of social security fraud is based on false ID.

SPEECH.PARA: Categorically there is no justification for introducing an identification system for 16 million Australian men, women and children in order to catch 2.8 million people who have the potential to rip off the social security system. The Minister knows it, his Department knows it and the Government knows it. But they know that they are in trouble on the ID card and will resort to any argument to justify their position. The ID card will not work for social security fraud because the problem of social security fraud relates to changed circumstances-not to a person's name or his identity within the community but to his entitlement to social security benefits, and that entitlement of course is based on his income and circumstances. Knowing someone's identity categorically will not help one know whether he has a job, whether he has extra income, whether he is no longer living alone or whether he has support from another person; and they are the major problems faced by the social security system in Australia today. The Minister knows it, the Department knows it, the Government knows it. The Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) knows it. Everybody knows it. When will we see the Government adopt an honest approach to ID cards and to the control of social security fraud? When will the Government recognise that the only way to handle the rip-off merchants is to provide the resources to the Department to enable field officers to investigate fraud in the field and to provide those field officers with the authority to ask questions of the clients of the Department?

Right now there is no legislative authority within the Social Security Act for a field officer or any other officer of the Department of Social Security to ask a question of a client. All questions have to be put in writing. How can Mr Temby, as the Director of Public Prosecutions, expect effective investigation to be conducted and effective briefs to be prepared when field officers not only are not trained in the area and do not have the experience to go ahead and conduct those investigations but also do not have the authority to do that? Of course, that is common knowledge among people who are prepared to rip off the system. As soon as they are questioned by a field officer they suggest that he or she does not have the authority to ask the question, so the investigation can go no further. It is perhaps the most effective block to investigation of potential rip-offs of the system that we know about.

Earlier this year I asked the Minister what he was going to do about it and when he was going to amend the Act to provide genuine authority for field officers. We got no answer and no action, nor is any amendment to the Act proposed, yet we have a proposal to spend $1 billion to employ 2,100 public servants and introduce the ID card system, which will not touch social security fraud and will cost the Australian people their freedom and the way of life they are used to. The Minister knows that he is responsible for the greatest haemorrhage in the social security system in Australia's history and the worst run system in the Western world. Yet he is prepared to sell out his principles and go ahead with this ID card proposal, knowing it will not work and does not have the support of his Department, his faction or a lot of his ministerial colleagues, not to mention the back bench of the Australian Labor Party. They do not support the ID card because they know it is superficial, ineffective, will not work and will not help stop social security rip-offs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard one of the less distinguished efforts on behalf of the Opposition. If we are to talk about standards in relation to the control of social security fraud as between this Government and the former Government, we need go no further than to the report of the Commission of Inquiry into Compensation Arising From Social Security Conspiracy Prosecutions 1986, the report of Justice Roma Mitchell, and read the story of how it has cost this Government, and to some extent the previous Government, $20m to make up for the fact that in March 1978 a series of dawn raids were carried out in a blaze of publicity in which 181 people were arrested and charged with conspiracy to defraud the Commonwealth. Those 181 people, mostly Greek people living in inner city Sydney, were the subject of possibly the most massive assault on the civil liberties of Australian citizens in the history of this country. That is what the attempts of the previous Government to deal with fraud were about. I believe that in many ways the events of 1978 have coloured the whole approach to the integrity of the social security system ever since. The responsibility borne by the previous Government on that occasion is one which has made it extraordinarily difficult for subsequent governments to act effectively in this area. It is all very well for people to come into the Parliament and make the kinds of statements that were made by the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt), but those statements are made relying on people having no sense whatever of history and the record of the Liberal and National parties when they were in government.

SPEECH.PARA: This exercise today supposedly relates to evidence contained in the annual report of the Director of Public Prosecutions which was released yesterday. It was suggested by the honourable member for Richmond that this report represented some kind of damning indictment of the Department of Social Security in terms of its efforts with respect to welfare fraud. It was suggested further by the honourable member for Richmond, without any quotations in support, that this report provided the evidence that there was no need whatever to move in the direction of the Australia Card. The honourable member for Richmond gave extraordinarily selective quotations from the report. He did not quote from page 59 of the report, which deals with the case of Wayne Thomas Patterson, alias Jansenberger. The report states:

Between April 1984 and July 1985 Patterson obtained approximately $380,000 using his own and 53 fictitious names to claim unemployment benefits in Victoria and Queensland. He pleaded guilty to 34 counts relating to offences in Victoria and had 20 charges relating to Queensland offences taken into account. The scheme was implemented using relatively simple artifices. Patterson was very skilful in investing on the stock exchange and in fact made a substantial profit from the amounts which he had defrauded from the Commonwealth.

At the heart of the Patterson case is the question of identity. Mr Temby reports on that case at page 59, but does not make any reference at all on pages 18 or 19 to the question of identity cards. There is no suggestion at all that he has a view about that, but his views were misrepresented by the very dishonest member for Richmond, who could not find a skerrick of evidence to support what he was suggesting.

The honourable member for Richmond took a couple of quotations out of context, but the crucial paragraph in that section on welfare fraud prosecutions is the third paragraph on page 18, where suggestions are made about the lack of resources for the Australian Federal Police to cope with more than a few of the large number of cases reported to it. It suggests that the result is that minor cases and very serious cases are investigated and that the Department of Social Security properly investigated the majority of minor cases. The honourable member for Richmond knows that the manuals of the Department of Social Security impose an obligation on field officers to investigate cases that come to the attention of the Department. What we are talking about here is an interface problem in terms of where the Department of Social Security investigations should cease and the Australian Federal Police investigations should commence, and which cases ought to be dealt with completely within the Department of Social Security and which cases ought to be dealt with primarily by the Australian Federal Police. As I have suggested, that matter has been under investigation. The Government is aware of that problem and revised guidelines will be issued to cover it.

Other quotations from the report were made by the honourable member for Richmond, but beyond that there is no evidence whatsoever in terms of what the honourable member for Richmond has suggested. There is not a skerrick of evidence to suggest that the Department of Social Security does not investigate cases which come to its attention of people seeking to misrepresent their circumstances to the Department or to rip off money. Indeed, there is an obligation on the Department to pursue and investigate those cases. As the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) has said, in a very large number of cases we are talking about very small payments.

In terms of social security fraud, let me make it clear that in my view the question of identity is extraordinarily important. It is important not because hundreds of millions of dollars are involved, as was suggested by the honourable member for Richmond on 10 August when he referred to the $350m welfare bill-a figure plucked out of the air-but significant money is involved. Approximately $36m was involved in prosecutions over the past five years. In terms of new overpayments raised, as at the September quarter of 1986, we were talking about $22.9m. That is significant money and it is important that prosecutions be carried out where significant fraud occurs. More prosecutions have been carried out. For example, there were 161 prosecutions under the Crimes Act in 1984-85 and 245 in 1985-86-an 85 per cent increase in fraud prosecutions over $30,000.

The bulk of what the honourable member for Richmond had to say had nothing to do with the Director of Public Prosecutions and nothing to do with any sentence. Let me make it clear that certainly since I became Minister the Government has taken the question of overpayments very seriously. We have introduced a great number of measures. When we came to office in 1983 the social security system administration was on its knees and on the verge of a major breakdown. Technology-prior to the investment which this Government had carried out at a cost of more than $200m in Stratplan-was not simply essential to help in overpayments; people were not going to continue to be paid if that investment had not been made. I believe the Government has been prepared to put that kind of money into technology. It has also been prepared to put resources in to ensure that steps are taken to eliminate fraud. For example, a more rigorous identity test has already been introduced by the Government. Direct credit to bank accounts has virtually eliminated problems of stolen cheques or fraud involving cheques. In terms of the overpayment strategy announced on 12 February this year, a number of steps have been taken involving more attention being given to collecting as much debt as possible to prevent overpayments in future. During Question Time I referred to the amnesty which was dubbed by the honourable member for Richmond as utterly irresponsible. The honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron), the acting shadow Minister on 22 July, stated:
The police, welfare rights organisations and an outraged public slammed this hasty and ill-thought out response.

In fact, the amnesty has been a major success. More than $20m has been saved and it has had widespread support amongst welfare groups, clients and the community. The honourable member for Richmond today and on a number of other occasions has talked about the power of field officers. A question without notice on 19 September alleged that field officers have no legislative authority to investigate fraud and overpayments. Field officers do have the authority to investigate all relevant matters, but do not have the power to require their questions to be answered. They do not have power to make a determination under the Social Security Act. Where questions are not answered, a delegated social security officer may require a client to answer by formal section 135 notice. It is not appropriate that field officers have specific powers to require questions to be answered. Every refusal would constitute an offence under the Social Security Act. Clients ought to have basic legal rights. We are not operating as, indeed, I believe the Opposition would like us to operate. This is reflected in the Greek conspiracy case. We are not operating in a police state and we do not intend to.

To understand the great value of Government initiatives they need to be compared to the system that was left to us by the previous Government-the Fraser-Howard team. The White paper on tax made it clear that the effects of avoidance and evasion had destroyed the tax system. People earning between $50,000 and $100,000 managed to hide about 10 per cent of their income through evasion and avoidance. Those on $100,000 and above were allowed to keep 22 per cent of their income from being brought into account. This was done by receiving fringe benefits instead of cash; disguising income as capital gain; and through tax exploitation measures such as negative gearing. On average, someone on $100,000 was allowed to rip off the tax system to the tune of $12,900. That is the equivalent to almost three aged pensions at the married rate.

We have heard an apologia from the honourable member for Richmond today on the Australia Card. Let me quote what he said again on 8 June 1985. We are not interested in the individual, the honourable member for Richmond; we are interested in the spokesman on social security on the opposite side of the House. What did he say? He stated:
The introduction of a national identification system using ID cards, offered benefits to the Australian people.

The use of plastic cards as a means of identification would streamline the collection of tax-imposing greater accountability on that small minority who seek to evade their responsibilities to the community by not paying taxes.
Another majority benefit would be a reduction of fraud affecting government outlays, especially social welfare payments.
I think honest taxpayers are sick and tired of the restrictions which tax and social security fraud impose on their own liberties.

I know that there have been some shifting views on the Opposition side of the House with respect to the subject of the ID card. But let me say that no one on the opposite side of the House has any compunction in coming into this House and hopping into anyone, particularly in the social security area, who might be ripping off the Government system. Members of the Opposition are a little more sensitive when it comes to the taxation side of the equation. People can rip off tax through fringe benefits, negative gearing and capital gains, but when it comes down to receiving an unemployment benefit illegitimately for a week or two, the full force of the police state will descend on them.

Let us not avoid the full force of what members of the Opposition are about. They are not saying that the Australia Card is a draconian measure-they are not saying that at all-they are saying that the Australia Card has to be rejected because they prefer police state methods which they want to use. The honourable member for Richmond suggests that the precedent of the 1979 Greek conspiracy case ought to be repeated, that field officers ought to be given much stronger powers and that they ought to be able to clamber their way into people's houses and ask any questions at all that they might choose to ask. They have no concern with civil liberties whatsoever.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The community and the coalition are deeply concerned about the explosion of social security fraud under this Government's incompetent and inefficient administration. The level of social security abuse is as high as it is today because the Government has run an open door policy for welfare benefits. Until recently the Hawke Labor Government did not require the personal lodgment of the 19b forms which were required to be lodged for the continuation of unemployment benefits. No wonder under Labor 116 people were on unemployment benefits for every 100 people looking for jobs; no wonder prisoners were getting unemployment and sickness benefits whilst in gaol. The gross incompetence of the Hawke Government's administration is starting to catch up with it and it is casting around for a way out, an excuse, a smoke-screen. It has latched onto the identification card. It says that the ID card will stop welfare fraud. The plain fact of the matter is that it will not. The Department of Social Security knows that the card will not stop welfare fraud; the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) knows it as well.

SPEECH.PARA: The allegation was made by the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt), that the Minister for Social Security did not support the ID card. The Minister was given 15 minutes in which to explain his support for the card and he failed to do so. The Minister for Social Security clearly does not agree with the Government. He opposes the ID card-he always has and he still does. He had 15 minutes to clarify his position and he failed to do so. He is not the only one. The Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card stated unequivocally that the card failed to combat tax evasion, failed to reduce welfare fraud and failed to identify illegal immigrants. I remind the House that the Joint Select Committee was made up of members from all parties of this Parliament-Labor, Liberal, National Party and the Democrats. All parties were represented.

TALK.START.PARA: —How did they vote?

—They all voted. All parties were represented in the majority report which opposed the card. The Joint Select Committee does not believe that the card will resolve the problems of welfare fraud, and neither does the Department of Social Security. The Department of Social Security, in its evidence to the Select Committee, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that in our experience the main problems within the departmental portfolio are not with identity as such, but a failure to notify change of circumstances.
It went on:

. . . by way of information the overpayments file for the Department shows that 0.6 per cent is attributable to identity and 61 per cent is due to income variations. Those are the issues which make us believe-
that is, the Department of Social Security-
that it is of minimal relevance in the identity area which is of course the primary initiative that the card would help address.

In other words, the Department of Social Security is saying that only 0.6 per cent of welfare fraud will be impacted by the card and it does not believe that welfare fraud will be stopped by the card. That is a clear statement by the Department to the Joint Select Committee. This Government is trying to dupe the Australian public and it is running around the country endeavouring to create the myth that the card is the answer to welfare fraud. It is not. Its own arguments indicate that the card is not the answer. Its own submission states that the cost of implementing the card will be the same as the likely savings. So there will be no savings from reduced welfare fraud as a result of the introduction of the ID card. The ID card will not work. The Government says so in its own submission, the Department says so, the Joint Select Committee says so and now the Director of Public Prosecutions says so. The DPP is saying that the problem is not identification; the problem is the will of this Government to prosecute those who have defrauded the Department of Social Security. It is not identification; it is a lack of will and government incompetence.

The Government is seeking to shift the blame. It wants to shift the blame to the ID card and say: `This is the way out'. We do not need a bureaucratic answer to a bureaucratic problem. We need a government with the will and the determination to implement tight controls. We need a government that is prepared to ensure the efficient administration of its departments. The Hawke Government has clearly failed to do just that. In the past three years it has shown no resolve whatsoever to get to the root of the problem, which is its own policies and its own administrative incompetence.

There are fundamental reasons why the ID card will not stop social security fraud. As I have already indicated, the Department makes it quite clear that the greatest area of fraud is not in the creation of false identities but rather in the failure of welfare beneficiaries to report their earnings of other income which would impact on the eligibility or the level of social security benefit to which the individual would be entitled. So it is the non-declaration of income rather than identification which, according to the Department of Social Security, is the cause of welfare fraud. That is the first problem.

The second problem is that the ID card fails to attack the cash economy where the welfare rorters gain their other income. For example, in those cases where a person on the unemployment benefit gets a job with a householder to do some gardening, to cut the lawns or perhaps do some painting, the householder pays the person on the unemployment benefit in cash. Of course, the householder does not know that that person is on the unemployment benefit. There is absolutely no way in which this major area of the cash economy will be impacted by the ID card. There are hundreds of examples of collusion between employer and employee where both get an advantage by the payment of cash. The employer gets the job done cheaper and the employee gets more take home pay. The point is that the ID card will not impact on that area and, therefore, it will be of no assistance to the Department of Social Security in identifying welfare rorters who are obtaining other income.

The third significant reason why the ID card will not resolve welfare fraud is the integrity of the card. Two Federal government organisations have questioned the integrity of the ID card. The first is the Department of Social Security. Mr Trevor Murphy, Director of Benefits Control, said, in relation to some tax officers, that they were:
. . . having trouble working out why the Department of Social Security would not accept the card at face value, even with a photograph.
Mr Murphy said:

We do not find it difficult to understand. It is a very simple point. I draw your attention to the fact that the Health Insurance Commission people went overseas, visited countries that have cards with photographs, came back and reported that the biggest single problem facing those countries was the problem of impersonation. I do not see that the Department of Social Security should be any less concerned about the integrity of the system in Australia. I would also make the comment that I noticed in the Press yesterday that one of the major banking institutions feels exactly the same way.

In other words, the Department of Social Security questions the basic integrity of the Australia Card. It will not accept the Australia Card as proof of identity. If it is not going to accept it, why on earth should anyone else in this country? Mr Frank Costigan, his senior counsel, Mr Meagher, and the Australian Federal Police have all attacked the Australia Card proposal because of its lack of integrity. Overseas experience, especially in the United States of America, indicates that organised crime can be assisted by an ID card system. Once people break the system they get false identification under that system and that gives them some legitimisation within the system. Only this morning the Federal Police contacted me and told me that people were already preparing to set up their false identities. They were generating false Medicare records and false Australian Taxation Office records so that they would be able to establish false IDs under this Government's ID card proposal. We need a government with will and determination to crack down on welfare fraud. We are prepared to do it. We will tie in the unemployment benefit to community service. This Government ought to act and not talk.

Has the honourable member for Richmond had a Damascus road type conversion against the card? From what he was saying today, I think he may have been another of those members of the Opposition on the road to Damascus. It must have been quite a crowded road over the past couple of weeks.
