DEBATE.TITLE: BROADCASTING AMENDMENT BILL 1986[COGNATE BILL:TELEVISION LICENCE FEES AMENDMENT BILL 1986]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 November, on motion by Mr Duffy:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
upon which Mr Macphee had moved by way of amendment; that all words after ``That'' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

``whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House expresses its concern at the equalisation of regional television services by way of aggregation of viewing areas, especially the `one-in all-in' trigger mechanism and believes that equalisation would best be achieved by the immediate issue of supplementary licences to existing licencees subject to specified conditions''.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the House that it has been agreed that the house have a general debate covering this Bill and the Television Licence Fees Amendment Bill 1986.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate on the Broadcasting Amendment Bill 1986 and the Television Licence Fees Amendment Bill 1986 is being resumed from yesterday and I will take this opportunity to set out for those listening the framework of the Government's approach to these matters. Before doing that, I commend the work of some members on the Government side of the House, including the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby), the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay), the honourable member for Aston (Mr Saunderson) and the honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Charles), who have been very active in representing their constituencies on these matters, as has the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons), and also the appropriate Caucus committee and the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy). The fact that we have before us sensible proposals largely reflects the work of back benchers, the Minister and Cabinet. People living in the regional areas of Australia will recognise that a lot of sensible work has been done on these matters.

SPEECH.PARA: What are these matters? Let me speak specifically. At present in the capital cities of Australia, with the exception of my city of Perth, people can enjoy three commercial television stations and two national stations. I will speak in a moment about national television stations and the Australian Broadcasting Corporation-Special Broadcasting Service merger. Nevertheless, people who live in those capital cities can enjoy three commercial and two national services. We believe that is a very good way to operate within a market, and I am looking forward to the occasion when the third commercial service in Perth comes fully into operation. My electorate of Stirling is currently the home of Channel 7 and Channel 9, and it certainly benefits from the activities of those two television stations.

That leads me to the next question, the question of the two nationals. Currently there is considerable discussion in the community about the ABC-SBS merger. This Government has taken a position on that and it is important to recognise that there is considerable support, especially in today's Press, including Il Globo, representing the Italian community, for that merger and I am confident that people in capital cities will enjoy the value of having two national television services in those cities. I will speak shortly about the transmission of cricket and golf, and that will show the benefit of having two national services.

However, our goals must be to help those in regional areas. What is the picture for those in regional areas? We are talking about something like five million people. They are represented by a variety of members in this place, from the National Party of Australia, the Liberal Party and our own governing Australian Labor Party, as well as, obviously, senators in the other place. Those five million people largely enjoy one commercial service and one ABC service. That is the general picture. Clearly it has been the view of this Government that we ought to have some strategic goals in terms of our broadcasting policy. The first of those strategic goals is equalisation-in other words, providing services in most regional areas comparable to those of capital cities. The second strategic goal is aggregation-to provide larger, more viable markets in regional Australia. I am one who has a very strong feeling about regional Australia because by and large people in regional and remote areas have been underserved in regard to both radio and television broadcasting and it is a source satisfaction to me to know that people in those areas are getting, with the advent of the satellite, improved services. The third goal is to encourage competition. Clearly it is our view that there is benefit in having competitive services in the market-place. So they are our three strategic goals-equalisation, aggregation and competition.

As far as aggregation is concerned-this is where we get to the centrepiece of the debate-there are two paths down which we might proceed in regional areas. One is what we might call direct aggregation; that is, existing markets or services can be combined in order to provide a sufficient population base for three competitive services. In other words, we take regional areas and group them together, we aggregate them, so we can provide an economic base and also a competitive base for commercial services, and people have more choice. The second option is multi-channel services. In other words, an existing licensee in a regional area can provide two extra non-competitive services in its existing market; it can simply provide a television service in its existing market and, in addition, two other services. The goal is clearly to try to increase the service available to those in regional Australia. I know that the honourable member for Aston, who will follow me from this side in this debate, will be having something to say about that.

The options we are putting before the industry are these: We would prefer direct aggregation, where licensees will seek to aggregate directly into market-places and provide a viable market and competitive services. However, the other option is to provide multi-channel services on the way towards that aggregation. The point of this legislation is in a sense to provide a direction for the industry by way of a framework, while clearly giving choices to the industry. So that is the framework within which we have come to discuss those matters. It is important to set that in place because this debate is resuming today.

There are some specific points that ought to be made about broadcasting. Honourable members have many views about broadcasting. One matter that is very clearly of concern at the moment is the coverage of the test cricket in Brisbane. Because the ABC already had the rights to cover the Australian Open Golf it was unable to provide a comprehensive cricket service for many people in regional areas. From my inquiries I understand the reason for that is that the ABC had, at a much earlier date, secured the rights to the Australian Open golf, and the first cricket test in Brisbane was brought forward so that it clashed with the Australian Open golf. I make two observations. First, very clearly, the ABC must be encouraged to be as competitive as possible, and I am pleased to see that it is seeking that sort of sporting coverage. Secondly, the whole question of exclusive rights is one that must be debated because very often parts of Australia are denied services because a particular commercial channel seeks exclusive rights and is then unable to provide a service across Australia. It is unfair for people in certain rural and remote areas of Australia to be denied, for example, coverage of the Melbourne Cup. I might add in passing that Australia's performance in the first cricket test is not as good as we had hoped.

TALK.START.PARA: —They might prefer not to see it.
—Some people might say they prefer not to see it. My colleague opposite suggests that, but clearly we would like them to have the choice.

SPEECH.PARA: Incidentally, it is a point of contention that whilst the Parliament is on air-I know that our debate is very erudite and has everyone in this community on the edge of their chairs-the reality is that a lot of people would prefer to be listening to the cricket today on the ABC rather than Parliament. That is a matter we will have to look at very seriously. Interestingly, when I recently surveyed the population of Perth who listen to the ABC as to whether or not they preferred parliamentary broadcasts, a majority did prefer that Parliament be covered. They wanted Parliament to be broadcast, but when I asked them whether they would prefer it to be on their existing radio 1 station-6WF in Perth, 2BL in Sydney, 3LO in Melbourne or 5AN in Adelaide; I do not know what the station is in Brisbane-they said no, they would prefer us to move parliamentary broadcasts to some other channel so they can listen not only to cricket but also to the regular ABC programs. That is a matter of some concern to us here. Clearly, I am in favour of parliamentary broadcasts, but I am also in favour of people out there being given choice. I think that is a subject for another debate because there is a report on that before the Parliament.

I conclude by making one other observation, and that is that a matter of considerable concern to the people in the community when we talk about service and competition is what I would call the ratings farce in Australian commercial television. Why is it that children, at the age of five, can tell us when the ratings are being conducted? It is very easy. When the ratings are on, all the commercial channels run A grade movies. When the ratings are not on, they run repeats of movies that were produced in, say, 1951. It seems to me that no other industry in this country is allowed to produce two grades of product and market them as if they were the one product. No brewery can turn out A grade beer one week and next week drop it back to B grade beer and not tell anyone. No motor vehicle manufacturer can turn out what one day is an A grade vehicle and the next day is B grade. Mr Deputy Speaker, can you think of another industry that is allowed deliberately to produce two grades of product but market them as if they are continually the same high standard product? Yet all the consumers know it is a B grade product. I would have to say that the advertisers clearly suffer a disadvantage because when the B grade product is being put to air not as many people are watching. Why is it that we in this country have let television stations get away with this ratings farce?

We might look at what was on offer in Perth last Saturday night. Despite the fact that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was in town attending one or two good functions, not everyone was there. There were 660 people at the function that I attended, but some people might have wanted to watch television. In Perth there are only two commercial services. On Saturday night Channel 7 showed a movie which was made in 1971 called Bedknobs and Broomsticks. At 9 o'clock it had a movie called Arthur which was not too bad, I suppose. At 11.05 it had a movie called Gaslight. On Channel 9 there was absolutely riveting stuff-Superman the Movie, followed by something called the Comedians, and then it had a cricket replay which we did not really want to watch on Saturday. That was the offering on Saturday night in Perth. Is it ratings period? I think one can probably get the drift that it was not a ratings period because they had those programs on offer.

So that we can keep a balance in relation to this, on Sunday night we had the farce where the ABC put on the Sunday Stereo Special at 8.30 so that people could have watched a simulcast, the ABC-FM, of Andre Previn conducting the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra playing the Brahms Symphony No. 4. If a person had decided to turn to the other national station, SBS, one could have watched Janacek's Sinfonietta from Yugoslavia. What choice is that? That is absolutely ridiculous. It is not choice; people were being served the same diet. If people happened to switch over to the commercial stations they did not have very much on offer there either-a Night of Opulence in Design was on Channel 7 at 7.30, which is a peck time, and the Apprenticeship of Buddy Kravitz at 8.45. On Channel 9 60 Minutes was on-that is a good rating program-but the Dream Merchants came on after that, which does not seem to have any particular criteria.

I am saying to the listeners and to my colleagues in the House that we have a situation in which, very clearly, the television stations have exploited the market-place. They have not served that market-place properly because they choose to produce two qualities of product. In the ratings period they produce A grade movies and top quality product; in the non-ratings period they produce a product that is barely up to standard. I am not talking about the coverage of sport because I think it is outstanding, particularly cricket on Channel 9 and tennis on Channel 7. They deserve great applause for their absolutely outstanding coverage. What else do they offer? They offer the Australian community a substandard product. So that I keep balance in this argument, I am also saying that I think the ABC and the SBS have to look at their acts as well. Serving up of two music programs on a Sunday night to viewers in one capital city does not serve the market.

With this legislation we are trying to provide to the Australian community more effective services to country areas. I am a strong supporter of that; I believe it is very important. The second thing that I have to say is that I think we have to look also at the quality of services being provided to metropolitan areas. In the relicensing hearings for Australian television stations the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal might well have to see whether we can have a ratings system that is applied 52 weeks of the year, the same as quality control is applied in every other industry. Why should they be able to get away with a substandard product? Accordingly, in the light of this discussion I am pleased to commend this legislation to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Millar Mr P.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join in the final stage of this second reading debate on the Broadcasting Amendment Bill and the Television Licence Fees Amendment Bill which are designed essentially to restructure regional television. I have listened to the debate with more than ordinary interest, and I have come to the conclusion that nothing illustrates more clearly than these Bills the folly of placing an issue in legislative form prior to a thorough canvassing of all its considerations. We have had virtually a total roundabout from where we started. As a consequence of the lobbying of the regional tele- vision interests, but more particularly because of the diligence and insistence of some Government members-the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby) and the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) come to mind immediately-the Government was prevailed upon to have a second look at this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Now, happily, as a consequence of that review and substantial changes, the regional television industry is somewhat mollified, even to the extent of being rather relaxed, knowing that the immediate threat contained within the original legislation no longer looms over it. The indicative plan laid down by the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) gives it a keen appreciation of what will face it in the future over an extended period so that it can adjust to the realities of this change in our television station propagation pattern within Australia.

I have often wondered where this proposal took its rise. Was there a Sir Humphrey somewhere who prevailed upon the Minister that it would be a nice idea to have three commercial channels throughout Australia to accord to those people out in the bush that which might arguably be described as their due? I am prepared to say that, by and large, the people out in the bush, to use the familiar and fond description, had no hypersensitivity to that which was looming over them-three television channels. Indeed, I venture to say that their first question would have been: `How the deuce can you watch three television screens simultaneously?'. Somebody decided that it would be a rattling good idea. Those out in broader Australia do not necessarily see themselves as being disadvantaged in comparison with the great metropolis. It may be argued that those in the concrete canyons and the serried ranks of suburbia may need accommodating with things which are not altogether essential but which would be regarded as desirable. I have no recollection of a clamour from the bush for these additional services. Naturally, in the nature of the human creature, if it is offered to them of course they will say yes. That is only to be expected.

It took its rise, and it descended upon this Parliament. I wonder whether, in taking its rise, it was not motivated to a considerable extent by some philosophical, even pathological, vendetta against monopolies and anything that smacks of profit. I note that the Minister, in his rather puckish way, in his second reading speech, if I recall correctly, said something to the effect that in the race of life one can count on self-interest being a starter. I could not agree more with him, but there must be some balance in these things. If we start off to remedy a situation on the wrong motivation, without thinking it through, we generally create more problems than we had in mind in the first place.

Self-interest is certainly something to be addressed. The highly profitable, multi-channel services, which might have been established under the initial legislation, occasioned some anguish among those who, hitherto, with the single-channel service have done very nicely. They were particularly agonised-aggravated, indeed-by the proposition that they should find their feet under the new regime within a very limited approved market of 450,000. I do not know why 450,000 was chosen as a suitable approved market. It is significant that under the new future aggregation schemes the market in Queensland approximates one million. Adelaide-a completely contained city with a population of a million-supports three commercial television stations. That was exquisitely pitched to the market. But somehow or other in broader Australia we were going to require existing television stations to increase the number of their channels, or go into aggregation and share a market which by any measurement was only half that which has eventually been established as a market consistent in size both with the ambitions of government and the reasonable expectations of those in the regional television business.

TALK.START.PARA: —They could have gone broke faster.

—My friend the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) makes the point that they could have gone broke faster but, in ultimate terms, there is really no hurry; we arrive there soon enough. But it now appears-and I have made inquiries from those regional television interests within my electorate and its surrounds-that there is a greater confidence in contrast to the dismay that first grabbed them. I am quite satisfied that this, in no small measure, is attributable to the sense of responsibility possessed by the Minister for Communications, who commands the respect of the House. I think it is a tribute to him and to the way that this place can be made to work in the end.

SPEECH.PARA: But the point I initially put remains salient. We embarked too far down the path before thoroughly canvassing all the issues and educating ourselves adequately to anticipate if not confront those matters which eventually came before us which required a change to the original proposition. So, all in all, we move into a new era of television. Some may say that there is still an unseemly urgency about it. Whether or not optic fibres or new techniques and technologies may, in hindsight, prove that we were a little impetuous in embarking on this course of action remains to be seen. But certainly we cannot luxuriate in the option of waiting indefinitely for the ultimate to arrive in any field of human endeavour. So one might say the steam has gone out of the debate. A few weeks ago we were poised here-certainly the honourable member for Bendigo, the honourable member for Herbert, the honourable member for Aston (Mr Saunderson) and perhaps one or two others-to engage in a death struggle for reasons that related not altogether to the technology of the art of television, but which had a more urgent relevance.

TALK.START.PARA: —It woudn't be a political consideration, would it?

—I would hate to think that it was a political consideration but this, of course, unhappily, is one of the features that determine the character of debate in this place all too often. I rather lament that circumstance. I think somehow or other we should be able to utilise the talent on each side of the House to achieve a better result than we usually achieve, and to do so in half the time. I am aware that again time is at a premium and the Whips are keen to proceed with the debate and get to the Committee stage. So I will not place a demand on the time of the House any further. I thank the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Saunderson Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in support of the Broadcasting Amendment Bill and the Television Licence Fees Amendment Bill. As the previous speaker, the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Millar) was saying, I think the fact that we debated yesterday the Bill to bring about the merger of the Special Broadcasting Service and the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and the fact that we are debating these Bills now is a credit to the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy), who is at the table, because he has, in the three short years that he has been the Minister for Communications, brought about a total revolution within the television industry. We are seeing the ABC and SBS merger creating a new image for public broadcasting in Australia and really bringing it into readiness to go into the next century in a much healthier and more enlivened way. The Broadcasting Amendment Bill, of course, is associated with the ownership question, which is currently before the Government, and we will be bringing views into the House on that issue. This Bill will bring about a situation whereby virtually all of Australia will in fact have equality of choice.

SPEECH.PARA: In the major capital cities for quite some time-I am sure honourable members and the community know this-there has been a great diversity of choice. Most of the major capital cities have had three commercial television channels and one ABC channel. In more recent times, of course, there has been the additional SBS channel. In many rural areas there has been just the ABC and in others, of course, there was only one commercial channel. Whilst there were the restrictions of the two-station rule and the development of television broadcasting in a more localised way, we saw in the rural areas the creation of broadcasting regions which were in themselves very small and, in the long term, probably not capable of providing greater choice than one channel.

It seems to me that any rational examination of what has been proposed with this Bill will demonstrate that it will achieve two things. As I said, it will bring about a greater choice of programs for people in country areas. The other important thing is that it will bring competition with it. It will break down the existing monopolies that have occurred in regional television over virtually all of regional Australia. I think that is where the Opposition has failed to pick up the real intention behind our Bill. It is not just equalisation in the sense of bringing programs; it is also the creation of competition. The Opposition is moving an amendment whereby it wants to go back to supplementary licences. While it is true that supplementary licences can give greater choice, they do not bring with them competition. I would put to the House that it is competition which will provide better programming-the very thing the Opposition says it wants. The Opposition says it wants more local production, better sport and entertainment and programs of cultural significance. I put to honourable members opposite that we are more likely to get that out of competition, because there is a need to do better, if one wants to have the greater share of the market, when one is in competition with two others, as will be the case in the future. When one is running a regional monopoly but has two channels, that is not competition; it just means that one has to buy more programs. They do not have to be good programs or great programs; but there must be programs. I am sure it is possible to get that programming, but it does not mean that the broadcasting quality will be any better from a supplementary licence system.

I think that that really is the crunch of what we are doing. We are providing not just a greater choice for people in the country; we are in fact providing competition which should ensure that there is a better quality of programming. I have travelled around Australia a lot in the country areas and I have watched a bit of television. I must say that sometimes when one turns on the television in some regional areas and sees some of the old programs that were shown in Melbourne-where I live-10 years ago or whatever, one starts to think that one is travelling back in time. I understand that there are obviously problems in some of these areas. They are small regions; there is not a lot of advertising that these broadcasters can get; they are therefore restricted in the amount of money they have to buy their own programs.

It seems to me that the other aspect of this Bill, the indicative plan which has come in, has increased markets. It looks at, basically, a market of a million people, while still ensuring that there is a sense of localism and that it is still regional television. Regions are not being tied into any other area such as the capital cities. So it is still a regionalised area, but it is in a market area of a million people, which ensures that there is a greater audience. This means that broadcasters can go to advertisers and say: `We have a million people within our broadcasting region and it is important that you advertise with us'. As that occurs, as they get a greater say in obtaining advertising, that will give them a capacity to get better programs. It is clear that a larger audience will make each of the stations more important in terms of the percentage of people reached.

I believe that the rationalisation that will occur in the industry with the aggregation and the fact that we will have greater choice of programming are very important. I was reading the speech of the Opposition spokesperson, the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee), yesterday, and I noticed that he said that he thought equalisation was a gimmick. I do not think that people in the country regions of Australia will think that it is a gimmick. The honourable member for Wide Bay was probably more accurate when he said that people were after greater choice. They were not necessarily arguing for three channels; they were arguing for greater choice.

Now that we have introduced a Bill which will give them three channels, I am sure that they will not stand up and say: `Look, we really didn't ask for three channels; we just wanted a greater choice. We would rather you didn't give us three channels. We will just cop a supplementary licence, thanks, and have the fellow who is providing the television now-it is not very good quality television because he hasn't any competition-put up another channel so that we will have two channels of the same stuff'. I am sure that people will not accept that line, which is what the Opposition is advocating. People will say that they were asking for greater choice and they will think it is terrific that they will have the same range of choice as people in the cities. They will have the opportunity of having three organisations in competition with each other, striving to provide them with better programs throughout the year. Yesterday the Opposition tried to get the ethnic vote by trying to con those people into believing that they were--(Quorum formed) As I was saying, we have seen two tactical mistakes by the Opposition. Here we are coming forward with the most progressive changes that have been made in television broadcasting since television was introduced to Australia. The Opposition is trying to convince people that it will give greater choice simply by giving supplementary licences. It has been said that that was done because some of our back benchers were worried about what was going on in their electorates. The reality is that the indicative plans that were published in the first place were there for discussion and consideration. Certainly, honourable members responded as they should have when people in the industry came to them and said that they did not think the plans were really as good as they could be. Those people claimed that a number of changes should be made and that it was important that they be made. Those honourable members quite rightly took up those points of view and those points were taken into account in the indicative plan that has been tabled. I believe that the overwhelming response from the industry is one of satisfaction. I congratulate the Minister on his effort in this area. TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) quite rightly said that people in regional Australia-I think I have paraphrased his words accurately-should be entitled to see on television major sporting events which their city cousins are able to see. As I understand it, unfortunately at present the Australian Broadcasting Corporation is set on a course to equip itself with policies and equipment which will preclude people in regional Australia and in the remoter areas from obtaining access to sports transmissions which are the exclusive property of commercial channels which do not service those regional areas but which might be prepared, in other circumstances, to allow free access by the ABC to these sports transmissions. I would hope that the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) would look very carefully at these proposals that are coming forward as they particularly affect areas such as my electorate where people are particularly disadvantaged in respect of not only commercial services but also ABC services. SPEECH.PARA: Today I wish to speak principally on a matter which affects the whole philosophy of regulation and licensing of broadcasting in Australia. Two months ago the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal awarded a commercial television licence to a publicly funded company. For the first time in Australia a commercial licence has gone to a community group which has raised its initial capital entirely from the Australian taxpayer. This is despite the fact that there is a commercial bidder for the licence ready and willing to provide a service at no cost to the taxpayer. Further, for the first time in Australia a commercial television licence has been awarded on racial grounds; and for the first time in Australia a commercial television licence has been given to a group which happily professes the aim of putting the interests of a small minority of its audience first. This combination of factors should give members of this House something to think about. A precedent has been set which throws into question the entire issue of commercial television and broadcasting licensing in this country.

I am speaking, of course, of the Tribunal's decision to award the fourth and final remote area commercial television licence in Australia to Imparja Television of Central Australia. The charge has been made that this is nothing less than social experimentation. I had expected that Imparja would deny this charge but-and I believe that this is indicative of the sort of thinking that is on the ascendancy over this issue-Imparja agrees. Chairwoman Freda Glynne told an Australian Broadcasting Corporation Countrywide reporter:
I think it's very good that Australia has been-and the Tribunal has been-brave enough to allow this social experiment to happen.

And we know what is said about brave or courageous decisions on the program Yes Minister. In this case the brave decision has been taken at the taxpayers' expense. Imparja has received some $5m in government grants and loans, including $1m from the South Australian Government and $2.5m that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) managed to wheedle out of bicentennial funds. It may be that this Government has decided that there should be an Aboriginal television licence awarded in Central Australia. By `Central Australia' I mean that part of the middle of Australia south of Darwin and north of Port Augusta. I would have my doubts about that but, if that is the case, the Government should declare that intention publicly and make special provision for it to happen, because the management of this affair to date has been a history of interim arrangement, taxpayers' funds scrabbled from various coffers and none too subtle pressure on the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal.

Let us look at the facts. We have just been debating the amalgamation of the Special Broadcasting Service and the ABC. The Government says that this is a necessary cost saving arrangement. On the one hand, the Government argues that it must save money on radio and television broadcasts aimed specifically at a multicultural audience. On the other hand, it argues that one small group of people in Central Australia-in this context that means everywhere north of Port Augusta and south of Darwin-an audience of around 25,000 people of a single ethnic background should have total control of their own television station. And total control by a single racial group is what it is. The articles of association of Imparja state that `at all times the majority of shareholders of Imparja shall be Aboriginal organisations or Aboriginal persons or persons of Aboriginal Descent'. Effectively there is no room in this television company for anyone of any other origin than Aboriginal. That is the exclusive requirement, and this is a television station to service an area in which 80 per cent of the audience is non-Aboriginal.

Further, the Government agrees that, although this is to be a commercial television licence, taxpayers' funds should be diverted from other projects to support this station. Do not think that the $5m to date will be sufficient. Estimates are that this television station will need to find another $22.5m over the next few years to stay on air. In the budgetary context, of course, $30m or so over several years is not a great deal. But it is a great deal of money to give 30,000 viewers an anticipated half an hour a week of personalised viewing in their own language, which is what Imparja says it will be able to provide initially to the six Aboriginal language groups in its area. In fact, if we do our arithmetic it amounts to personalised television broadcasts to individuals subsidised at the rate of about $40 per person per hour from the taxpayers. I certainly hope that every single viewer of this particularly favoured audience is tuned in and attentive.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. The relevance of the remote commercial television service to this Bill totally escapes me. It has no relevance.
—The Minister has made his point. I ask the honourable member for the Northern Territory to be relevant to the Bill.

—I have said virtually all I have to say, quite frankly, about this matter, but I will be pleased if the Minister can answer what I have said here today because this commercial licence is not a specially funded television licence with an ethnic slant. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robinson The Hon I.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Regional television in Australia has been developed over two decades to provide a technical standard and a program content unsurpassed by any other country. Regional licensing and conditions of establishment and the introduction in the early 1960s of regional television set a pattern which has been singularly successful in providing to the community a service which has been highly motivated in serving each community under the umbrella of the originating station or, in many places, translators or, in some places, second transmitters. Regions throughout Australia have during this period been provided with a commercial channel and an Australian Broadcasting Corporation channel and some localities have been fortunate enough to be able to receive more than one commercial channel as well as the ABC.

SPEECH.PARA: Earlier in the debate the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby) and later this afternoon the honourable member for Aston (Mr Saunderson) were critical of the development of regional television in Australia. I believe that their criticism is quite unjustified. Really they have no precise knowledge if they claim, as the honourable member for Aston did, that regional television programs are not much good. I think his words were that they are bad programs and the solution is competition. Obviously he knows little of the history and the development of regional television in Australia.

The legislation which we are dealing with proposes the introduction of additional channels to give the five million viewers in regional Australia equity with the metropolitan area. That is the claim, of course, of the Government in this matter. My assessment of metropolitan television leads me to wonder what country viewers and people in regional areas-that is, five million viewers-have been missing. Quite frankly, I think that there is not a standard and not a field of alternative programming quite to the extent that one might expect from the enormous conglomerate metropolitan television media in Australia.

On the other hand, I want to say in the brief time available that I am sure that many of us appreciate the effort that the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy), who is at the table, has put in to arrive at the present plan that came into the House yesterday-the indicative plan known as the plan for the creation of new regional television markets. We are well aware that earlier a very tough proposition was being put, one that would certainly have crucified many of the television stations in regional Australia which are not enormously viable, which do not have huge reserves of capital and which would have to face up to enormous outlays to meet what was proposed. The plan we now have is certainly more reasonable than the one that was around the corridors of this place some weeks ago. Certainly there is a need to ensure that, whatever comes of this legislation, regional television is not forced to bow down to the metropolitan media magnates of this country.

There has been a complex and confusing process from the early announcement of multi-channel services until the legislation which came before us last week. Multi-channel services and supplementary licensing were proposed, of course, quite some time ago-certainly supplementary licensing was. Many of the regional stations, or their companies, proceeded to provide capital and, in many instances, even buildings to accommodate the proposal for supplementary licensing. Then of course came the major move-aggregation. It is as a consequence of that that we are debating this legislation this afternoon. I want to say briefly that in my area, northern New South Wales, there is a history that is worth remembering. In the early 1960s two commercial stations were licensed. One of them was put on to a frequency that was technically incorrect, so its signal had to be changed and it had to get another number on the dial within two years of launching. That was a commercial disaster for that company, but it recovered and then subsequently found that things were so tight that amalgamation with the adjoining company was necessary to provide a viable service for the northern coast of New South Wales, from Port Macquarie to the Gold Coast. I believe that the history of what occurred in that region should not be overlooked in the administration of what is proposed under this legislation. Viability is absolutely essential. Of course, it is easy to claim that those companies which are licensed to operate television stations have a status of commercial wealth. That is not always the case; it depends on what the station is doing, how it is doing its job, the standard it is providing and what the community is receiving as a consequence of the operation that is carried on by the regional station.

I know that the Minister has taken some heed of localism over a long period, yet in his second reading speech he said that he wanted to comment on that aspect. He said that assessment had shown that an average of only 7 per cent of the time of regional stations is devoted to regional interests, regional programming and so on. I presume that he was referring to such things as news programs, public affairs programs, sponsorship for charities and the like. So far as my area is concerned, the extent of localism has been enormous-there is a half-hour news program for five evenings a week. The extent of localism is borne out on the basis of facts that can be stated. For instance, one-third of the journalists employed in all television networks in Australia are employed by regional television stations. Of 310 journalists engaged in the business of television news gathering, 102 of them are employed by regional stations. If one looks at the ratio of outlays, income and communities served, on those statistics alone there is no doubt that there is a very substantial contribution to localism by regional television stations. Yet the Minister said that competition will ensure that there is emphasis in this direction. This immediately raises the question of market viability, because if we are to proliferate, taking northern New South Wales as an example, under aggregation each of the three stations would have to set up studios and engage staff in at least two additional major centres. The outlays on additional staff, for example, could run to a very substantial figure to ensure that there is localism over each of the stations as a consequence of aggregation.

Time does not permit me to traverse all of the aspects that are so important in this field, but I want to say that whilst on the one hand the plan is one of substance and one which the industry is able to see clearly and to assess, some assurances are still required-the Minister referred to them in his speech-on the availability of certain channels. The very high frequency situation in northern New South Wales is such that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation is not able to introduce a frequency modulation service north of Port Macquarie because of the failure so far to gain clearance of VHF channels.

The community at large was invited to comment on the Green Paper on the development of the ABC service. The time for comments ended in January or February of this year, but to my knowledge there has been no response from the Government in respect of comments on the proposals. If we look at the detail of that matter, we find proposals to split regions, involving an enormous capital outlay and additional ongoing cost. The Government has found it tough going to do this. I believe that some of it could be staggered over a longer period because of the existing fairly satisfactory services, but what is lacking on the part of the ABC is something effective in the FM field. That is where there is a real demand. On the question of viability, one must always be mindful of what the proposal for aggregation will mean. It will mean that a very substantial capital outlay and cost will be involved. That cost, under any commercial operation, must be recouped, so straight away we find that there is another element of very great significance so far as localism is concerned. There is the consequent cost of advertising for local advertisers in regional areas. It is all very well to say that major national advertising is available for television stations, but if we are to be honest in the matter of regional television, we must ensure that the cost of advertising is not pushed beyond the means of the small businessmen or communities which require the use of a local regional television station. Local regional television stations provide news services, public affairs services and related concessions that a station can give, but the rest of it is a commercial operation. However, this seems to have been lost sight of by the many people who have spoken so glibly about providing competition.

Another aspect is the matter of multi-channel services. If the existing operator is to provide a program through a second service-in other words, through the licensing of a service that gives a parallel operation-the operator will see to it that the program is so split that an alternative program is available to the community which accords with what is on the other channel. On the other hand, if we go straight into aggregation, that will mean that a program will be designed so that there is sport against sport, news against news, drama against drama or movie against movie. I suggest one analogy. There is a lot of argument about the provision of effective schedules for air services in this country. We find ourselves facing parallel flights on airlines because that is the time everybody wants to travel. Likewise with television-everyone wants to watch at a particular time. So there is a limit to competition; there is a limit to the reality of what can be achieved in respect of competition. It is vital that the economic aspects be taken into account fully in the administration of the proposal before us in this legislation.

In conclusion, I strongly support the amendment proposed by the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee). I recognise the effort that the Minister has put into this matter and I hope that, as a consequence, there will be reality rather than what can only be described as a pie in the sky-a pie in the sky that could be damaging for the viability of regional television unless very great care is taken.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The legislation before the Parliament is the culmination of many years of discussions and consideration so far as the Government and the community are concerned. I want to say a few words about this legislation as it affects commercial television in country areas, in particular in northern New South Wales. We have to appreciate the fact that we in regional Australia are very lucky indeed to have a service that is comparable with the service anywhere else in Australia and certainly throughout the world. I personally believe that and I am sure honourable members join with me in that belief. So far as regional commercial television is concerned, the programs and services available are comparable with any that we will find on national television screens. I do not concur with the honourable member for Aston (Mr Saunderson) who said earlier in the debate that we are ten years behind. We are not ten years behind. Today, with satellites, commercial stations, in most cases, are able to get their programs and get them very quickly. Country viewers generally throughout Australia have received a service of which commercial television and the Australian Broadcasting Corporation can be very proud. We are making great strides on television.

SPEECH.PARA: I, like a previous speaker in this debate, have not seen the evidence of where country people, covered by commercial television, have sought extra television programs and services. Nevertheless, I appreciate the attitude of the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) and the Government. We will all go along with the fact that there should be more equality or more opportunities for people throughout Australia to view as much television as they possibly can. It is very difficult to compare commercial television in country areas with national television systems simply because national television has so many listeners and viewers throughout the country.

The area that I want to refer to is the area covered by Newcastle into the west of the State and north to the Queensland border. The Minister has announced that there will be a duplication of the three commercial services available. The honourable member for Page (Mr Ian Robinson) spoke about northern New South Wales television. There are also Channel 3 Newcastle and NEN 9-8, which covers Tamworth and Taree. There will be a duplication of the three services over a period. The aspect that concerns me is the one-in all-in attitude under aggregation at the moment. I know that there will be a multi-service available. The opportunity will be there for the Government to bring this in over a period. I understand that this will be done. The fact of the matter is that it is very strange that a government can turn around and say to not only these three stations but also the other television stations throughout Australia: `If one of you three says that we should aggregate, you have to do it'. Surely in a democratic society the majority should decide that. I am extremely disappointed to see that this is part of the legislation before the Parliament.

What matters is not so much equality but the quality of the programs that are available today to the people of Australia. I want to say something, briefly, about the services-I will emphasise the local point of view-that are available typically from NEN 9-8. This is a tremendous service over a very wide area of northern New South Wales. Undoubtedly a similar service is also available through the other two commercial stations and maybe through the rest of the commercial stations throughout Australia. The local news takes up half an hour a day. This is so important. At Taree we may see something that is occurring up in the tablelands at Moree, Narrabri, Muswellbrook or somewhere else but at least we are in close touch and naturally in close proximity to what is occurring throughout the region. Little items matter a lot to local people living on farms, villages and towns.

NEN 9-8 has won a number of awards for the services and the programs that have been available to viewers. Current affairs programs are based on local identities and on the local area. We tune in to Tamworth and often hear about the music festival, the same as we hear about the aquatic festival in Taree. This service covers these local events. When the three commercial stations have the cost of extra duplication, will they be able to continue this excellent local service that we are receiving? We see a nature series there. I know that NEN 9-8 has produced some of these programs. They have been sold to other television stations throughout Australia and throughout the world they have been made available to people.

Let us look at employment. NEN 9-8 alone has eight journalists and six cameramen. These stations have raised tremendous funds for local charity groups-$1.2m has been raised for the handicapped and is to be spent within that area. From a viability point of view, will they be able to continue with this service on such a local basis? I ask the Minister this because I want him to visualise for a moment the three commercial stations covering each other's areas, the costs that will be involved and the tens of millions of dollars that will take them down the road to acquiring the material and the facilities. It is a gigantic undertaking. The honourable member for Page made the observation a while ago that this money must be raised somewhere-either from banking, financial facilities or from members of the public who wish to invest in shares. These commercial stations have to be a commercial proposition for investors. These matters are most relevant. It is not only a case of what we are going to view on television. I have confidence that the programs we want will be there if the station is viable. The foundation of over 20 to 30 years that has been laid for commercial television throughout Australia has to be maintained. If it is maintained I have no doubt that the Minister will be correct in what he says.

In conclusion, I want to touch on the advertising side. It is terribly important that the smaller businessman is able to advertise on television. He wants to be able to compete. He will have to compete with our national television programs and the national advertisements that we see. We sometimes get tired of seeing them time and again. But we love to see our local tyre service or our local furniture man spending his--

TALK.START.PARA: —Or butter factory.

—That is right, a butter factory. We love to see the small businessman earning his hard-earned cash in order to be able to advertise and to promote his business in the community in which he lives. These are the fundamentals of the legislation that is before the Parliament. The people in country areas are concerned about these matters. They want their programs. They will accept that we must have a coverage of three stations. They may think that is very good. Having a little knowledge of the subject, I am saying that the important fact is that commercial television must remain viable and be able to give these programs and services to people-a service that is already there. And I suppose many others would love to know what the Minister is thinking on ownership control.
—Wouldn't we all?

—This is important to commercial television. It is important for us to know the opportunities the big boys have. Although the Government might not say this, it is the government of monopolies. There is no doubt about this.
—And cronyism with Packer and Murdoch.

—The Government is setting up legislation of monopolies and cronyism. I have sat in parliaments for a number of years. I have heard Labor members get up and talk about the poor little fellows. But there are more poor little fellows now than there were before. What about the bigger boys? I congratulate the Minister for his stand. He has been strong in what he has tried to do against the wishes of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). I believe that this is very important indeed. What should the viewing percentage be throughout Australia? Should one company control 35 or 40 per cent of the viewing level throughout Australia, or should it come back to 30 per cent?

SPEECH.PARA: What should the ownership control be? What rights have one or two of these bigger companies to move into our smaller country commercial television stations. We have to consider these facts. If this legislation provides that one or more of our smaller commercial television stations are not viable, my word, there will be a takeover by the bigger hawks. They will want to move in and they will want to tease the others who are in competition with them within that region. These are the realities of life that we want to think about.

I know that the Minister has done his best and I commend him for that. I have never criticised him because I think he has a very sound approach in many respects to many of the matters within his portfolio. All I am asking is that common sense prevail. If changes are necessary in the future to look after commercial television in country areas I just ask that common sense prevail, based upon the ability and the viability of those companies concerned to be able to supply the viewing public with what we, in the country areas of New South Wales, have been accustomed to in recent years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I will dispose of the only unpleasant aspect of what I think has been a very interesting debate, that is, the contribution by the honourable member for Northern Territory (Mr Everingham), in which he said that this Government may have decided to have an Aboriginal broadcaster. No such decision was taken. Imparja Television went before the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal with the other applicant. The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal determined that Imparja would be the successful applicant. I note that the honourable member for the Northern Territory said that-these are his words-`there was a none too subtle pressure on the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal'. I suggest to the honourable member for the Northern Territory that it is about time that he decided to name the persons who he alleges brought the none too subtle pressure on the ABT. Preferably, he ought to go outside this House and say it and face the consequences of what he says. It is also an outrageous slur on the ABT to suggest that it could be subjected to pressure in the way that the honourable member for the Northern Territory has mentioned. His contribution was almost beneath contempt but I think it was necessary to answer at least those couple of points.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to thank all those honourable members who took part in this debate last night and this afternoon, with the exception of the honourable member I have just mentioned. I think it is reasonable to say, with respect to the contributions today, that the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Millar)-yourself, Mr Deputy Speaker-the honourable member for Page (Mr Ian Robinson) and the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan) put forward a considered view on the position of regional television. I do not agree with all of what they said but they put forward a view on behalf of regional television and I accept the sincerity with which it was put. I thank them also for their comments in relation to me. I suppose that I should enjoy it while I can. We have tried fairly hard to reach what has now been referred to as a reasonable compromise and that has been the attitude of regional television to the final position that has been reached. Mr Deputy Speaker, the same applies to you. I have had the opportunity of saying on other occasions that I think the quality of debate in this House would be greatly enhanced if there were more people like you and more contributions such as the one that you made from honourable members on both sides of the House.

I go now to some of the matters of substance that were raised by members of the Opposition. I will deal first with the ones that were raised last night and I will then attempt to cover some of the matters raised today by the honourable member for Wide Bay, the honourable member for Page and the honourable member for Lyne. I think they all had one thing in common-that is, they preferred the supplementary licence scheme to the Government's aggregation policy. That view was put by the shadow Minister for Communications, the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee), last night. I will deal with his comments in a moment but at this stage I take the opportunity of thanking him for the way in which the debate has been handled, particularly in relation to Government amendments. He facilitated that in a way which will save a lot of the time of the House, and that is greatly appreciated. I thank him also for his general attitude to this whole debate. Yesterday he went through a period of irrational behaviour on the amalgamation of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and the Special Broadcasting Service and I was delighted to see him return to his normal, urbane approach during the latter part of the debate. On reflection, he may also look back on that as being a rather unfortunate experience that he went through earlier in that day.

The supplementary licence scheme was a creation of the previous Government. We inherited it in 1983 and made a genuine attempt to make it work. However, it was a scheme that had so many complications built into it that it proved to be quite unworkable; there is no doubt about that. That is not just the Government's view, it is the view of industry itself. Regional Television Australia has not suggested, as an industry, that we return to the supplementary licence scheme and the multi-channel service permits-the MCSs-are mark 2 of the supplementary licences. We have removed the unproductive clutter in the legislation and the effect for the viewers is exactly the same as if supplementary licences had been granted. Three services have been provided by the same licensee. In addition to streamlining the legislation we have provided, for the first time, a clear timetable for the next decade-1986-96-during which time everyone in the industry knows exactly what he is required to do.

I noticed that the honourable member for Goldstein mentioned that well-known comment of the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) when he referred to one of my proposals for regional television as being Sunday Too Far Away. He was not referring to aggregation. In fact, he has missed the point. His reference was not to the timetable for providing extra services-it is much the same under any approach-but to the fact that competition was unlikely to occur for a very long time. The reference to Sunday Too Far Away was a reference to the question of competition. Of course, competition does occur as soon as aggregation takes place.

Last night both the honourable member for Goldstein and the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) alleged that the Government was not utilising new technologies and they referred to fibre optics and satellite delivery systems. Anyone who knows me reasonably well will realise that I cannot fail to comment on matters of technology as it is an area with which I am so well acquainted. I think those honourable members again missed the point in this area. In fact, the whole equalisation policy hinges upon the use of new technologies. I really do not know what they were on about. It is interesting to note that the satellite program service report of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal in July 1984 was the first official publication to recommend aggregation. It agreed that satellite delivery of signals provided the Government with an historic opportunity to review the basis on which television services have been licensed. We have reached this day by changing the legislation to a service area base instead of a technical base and by planning for the aggregation of service areas in a way which is highly compatible with satellite delivery of signals.

Their comments portray a very scant knowledge of long term planning. It should be noted, firstly, that aggregation does use the satellite system and, secondly-another point which I think was missed-there may never be a second generation satellite system. The Board of Aussat Pty Ltd has not yet decided on that issue, nor has the Government as a shareholder of Aussat. Telecom Australia's plan for fibre optic cables addresses the links between main capital cities, central business districts and then urban centres. It is unlikely to address the cabling of cities, making signals available to houses during the currency of this indicative plan-the next 10 years, 1986 to 1996. Even then, I think it is likely that broadcasting will involve a combination of satellite delivery, terrestrial and cable transmission from head ends and direct broadcasting into the home. So it is a combination of all of those and I do not think that we missed out on addressing those issues.

It has also been argued that the Government's relaxed ownership and control plans should have been made known before the indicative plan was decided. The honourable member for Lyne said that he would like to know what my thinking was on the ownership and control issue. The honourable member for Goldstein interjected: `Wouldn't we all?'. They will not have very long to wait for that because it is likely that there will be a Government decision on that issue at a very early date; by that I mean probably within the next fortnight. As I have said, it was argued that the relaxed ownership and control rules should have been known before the indicative plan was decided. The Government is well aware that relaxed ownership and control rules provide an important trigger for aggregation and it has consistently made this point over the last 12 or 18 months of public discussion. For the same reason, we have freely foreshadowed a relaxation of the two-station rule. There is no doubt that that will go. I must say that I was interested in most of what the honourable member said. I could not disagree with him because he was expressing genuine concerns.

The honourable member for Page made two interesting points that I would like to take up. He talked about the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's failure to be able to provide an FM service. Of course, that is because of the need for the band 2 clearance, which this Government has been the only government prepared to face up to. We are proceeding with the clearance of band 2, which will allow the expansion of FM radio-something that the Liberal and National parties did not ever face in the 1960s. That assigning of a frequency in the 1960s which sent some stations to the wall in the area represented by the honourable member again had nothing to do with this Government. Unfortunately, as honourable members will recall, the 1960s was a period of domination by Liberal-Country Party coalitions.

The two-station rule is something that honourable members opposite have tolerated since 1960 or 1961. It is absurd that they equated a person owning two licences, one in Melbourne and one in Sydney, serving 43 per cent of the population, with someone who happened to own a licence in Port Pirie or Broken Hill and was serving 0.4 per cent of the population. The same position applied; they could not go any further. That was tolerated over a period of more than 20 years of Liberal-National Party government, with three years of the Whitlam Government included in that period. But the two-station rule will go. That has been clearly stated by this Government. So existing or new licensees will be able to invest in many more stations than is at present possible under the ridiculous rule known as the two-station rule.

The only question is about the maximum level of ownership to be permitted. That has yet to be decided. It is hard to say how the Government could be expected to make ownership and control decisions before deciding the indicative plan. I take the point that it may have been useful for people to have known. But, until the indicative plan was decided and a system for aggregating and consolidating existing licences was in place, what would the new ownership and control rules really have meant? They would not have meant a great deal until we reached the stage that we have now reached in this debate. They could not be given a precise form when the size of the markets to be covered by them was not known. That was not known until yesterday.

The other matter raised by the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) was about the 28 days for election. That matter has also been raised again with me by the honourable member for Goldstein, as the shadow Minister for Communications, on behalf of the industry. The election period has been shortened to compensate for delays in introducing legislation, while meeting the Government's objective of maintaining the aggregation completion date. There has been considerable public consultation and debate over aspects of the draft indicative plan. This has put licensees in a good position to be able to respond quickly to the questions about whether licensees are opting for aggregation or multi-channel services. In addition to that, they have a full three months after the election date to submit implementation plans. I can put this matter to rest at this stage by saying that, in light of those representations by the honourable member for Goldstein, on behalf of the industry, we can delay the gazettal until at least the end of December. In addition, that will take the election date to at least the end of January. That probably meets the genuine concerns that have been expressed in that regard.

Last night the honourable member for Goldstein also raised the question of sales tax on transmitters. I think the honourable member for Bass also raised that matter and the extent of the sales tax exemption proposed. Licensees who choose to use the MCS path to aggregation will be eligible for sales tax exemption on the purchase of their transmitters. The Government's decision to restrict the sales tax exemption to transmitters is deliberate as their equipment can clearly be identified as being purchased for aggregation. If that is not the case, it is not our view that that equipment should be so exempted. It is aggregation that is being encouraged. The other equipment suggested as coming within the exemption can be used for a variety of purposes. The same situation applies to licence fee rebates. The rebate is designed as a commercial incentive to encourage licensees to opt for aggregation instead of utilising the MCS option. The one-in all-in rule is another policy reflected in the Bill which is weighted in favour of aggregation.

The honourable member for Lyne, the honourable member for Page, and I think you, Mr Deputy Speaker, expressed concern about localism and employment consequences. The honourable member for Goldstein and the honourable member for Fadden also raised that issue last night. However, I must repeat that on average over 90 per cent of programs already come from major networks. The demand for local news and programming is well established in regional areas and will continue to be. In a competitive environment, it is our view that those operators who maintain or increase local content will be the ones likely to attract a greater viewing audience, with beneficial commercial implications. Larger markets will provide additional programming, advertisement production opportunities and resources to draw on, with economies of scale which will allow larger regional operations to develop increased and innovative local programming. This has positive implications for employment, given that additional sales, news and production staff will be required in a wider range of regional centres. I do not share the concerns expressed on that issue, for the reasons outlined. They are genuine concerns but they are not well founded. In that regard it has been acknowledged that there is concern. I have always had concern for localism and the retention of regional television.

The honourable member for Page mentioned employment by regional television operators. Of course, regional television in Australia employs more people than the whole of the networks put together. There is no question about that. This Government's decision in not allowing direct broadcasting, not allowing that to start in the back door way by allowing the networks to have the remote commercial television services, was the crucial step in that area. Points were raised about technology. It is very difficult to predict what will happen in the future. One thing that will happen is that regional television will have the chance to provide the diversity of programming and the choice that people in country areas demand. The honourable member for Lyne indicated that he had not seen a great deal of evidence of that. In looking at that issue and in moving around regional Australia, I must say that that has not been my experience. It is my view that people in regional Australia do want more programming. They want diversity and more choice. This proposal gives regional television a chance to provide that type of programming and thereby stave off what would otherwise be inevitable-the demand for direct broadcasting in Australia. It may come one day because technology will probably take it over. As I have said on many occasions, no government can rule that out in the long term. Certainly regional television deserved a chance to restructure, and it has been given that chance.

In closing, I thank members of the Opposition for their contributions and I also thank members on the Government side, particularly all the members of the infrastructure committee, including the honourable member for Aston (Mr Saunderson) and the honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Charles), as Chairman and Secretary. I thank also my personal staff for their assistance in what has been a long haul. I thank officers of my Department for the enormous amount of work that they have done, and particularly Mr Peter Westaway, with whom of course I have worked very closely. I also thank members of Regional Television Australia, some members of which were present today. I noticed that the Secretary, Mr Ken Stone, and Mr Bill Rayner were present in the House. We have had a lot of disagreements over the last three years but we have gone a long way and I thank them for their courtesy and co-operation over that period.
