When the Opposition talks about the Department of Communications' record in spectrum allocation not being good, it should remember that the Department could not carry out a policy while a government sat on its hands and said that it was all a bit difficult politically, that it would cause some problems here and there and so it would have to be put off.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that the VHF frequency spectrum is at a stage where it will not be able to cope with the new services that are now being provided. This is a matter that the honourable member for Goldstein will have to examine a little more closely. I think he is wrong on that issue. There is no doubt in my mind that what we are doing here is right. The problem is that we are doing it much too late; but we cannot be blamed for that, and nor can the Department be blamed when I have no doubt that if I had access to the Liberal Government's minutes-and I do not, because the Public Service operates very strictly in that regard-I would see plenty of advice to the then Government that it was about time it got off its hands and did something about the issue. There was no response; so there is no point in the honourable member criticising the Department. He can go back and criticise the continual failure of Liberal and National Party governments to face up to this issue.

The second matter that was raised by the shadow spokesman and also by the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles) was the question of Tasmania. As the honourable member for Braddon will be aware-he drew attention to this fact-the Tasmanian licences are, of course, controlled by the one company. Nevertheless, the Tasmanian licensee is the only one designated to lose market without any compensatory gains at all; there are no others whatsoever. The Government had to consider that issue. Tasmania was identified in the statement I made on 20 May and in the draft indicative plan as being likely to require separate attention. The reason for that was the point I made earlier, namely, that both commercial licences are controlled by the one company. Secondly, Tasmania is an island and therefore it is not contiguous with some other area in the sense of other areas in the approved markets to be aggregated. Thirdly, the population is relatively small. When one looks at the market in Tasmania one sees that it may be a long time before there are three services in that State. The important thing at this stage is to get two.

The current Bill makes special provision for the current licensee to do one of two things: To sell one of his licences, whereupon each licence will have to have its service area expanded to include the other area; or to consolidate the two licences, with the Minister inviting applications for another independent service to serve the consolidated service area. The Government's objective is to provide two competing services as soon as practicable. That is important in considering Tasmania, and that is why the Government has decided to go for the first option-that is, that the present licensee be given the opportunity to sell one of those licences, whereupon each licence will have its service area expanded to include the other area.

There has been some criticism of that and some people say that we should have opted for the second option of calling for a second licence by having an independent and then have the whole State aggregated. That argument has some substance; but on balance we have decided to go the other way, and the second service will be in Tasmania a lot more quickly as a result of adopting that approach. There is no question about that. The concern which seems to be expressed and which is a strange one, namely, that somehow or other the licensee will sell the licence to someone friendly-I think the imputation has been made that it could be someone too friendly-is somewhat odd when one considers that the transfer of shareholdings will have to be approved by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, which will look at all the aspects about which some people may be concerned. Probably that is a most unfair imputation, but some people have expressed it and have expressed concern about it. However, it is not something that can be done in the way about which some people are worried. The arm's length transaction must take place. On balance the Government opted for that proposal because it is our view that it will result in a second service in Tasmania more quickly-and that is very important to Tasmania-than would be the case if we called for an independent. I quote the example of what happened in Perth when an application was made for another licence and the existing licensees were clinging very hard to what they have. There could have been a very extended hearing for an independent licence had we gone down that track.

The honourable member for Goldstein and the honourable member for Braddon raised the question of VHF and UHF in relation to Tasmania. What will happen there is that each one will have a VHF station because the current stations in Launceston and Hobart are both VHF. The two new services will be UHF. They have both been treated fairly in that way; they will have one UHF and one VHF. If 85 per cent, or at least 80 per cent, of television sets in Tasmania are not now UHF compatible I will be extremely surprised.

Another matter raised by the honourable member for Goldstein was the Minister's power to revoke or suspend MCS permits. The provision in the Bill, proposed new section 94y (1), has been criticised by him for not including criteria to apply when the Minister is exercising the power to suspend or revoke an MCS permit. In relation to that I would just say that the wide discretion with the Minister to suspend or revoke an MCS permit was deliberately included-it was not something that slipped through-to ensure that no proprietary rights are attached to MCS permits. That was not intended at any stage and the position is that no proprietary rights are attached to MCS permits. This provision also balances the amendment made at the request of Regional Television Australia and the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations to allow for the automatic transfer of MCS permits with the head licence. That new provision is to be put into the Act deliberately for those two reasons.

Another matter raised by the honourable member for Goldstein was how an AM service could include a three-station metropolitan market. He was referring to proposed new section 94k (3) (a). The query was that this is a question of ownership and control and not aggregation. Of course, what that relates to is that where in the States an approved market will need to include the metropolitan area-we have said that is likely to be the case in South Australia, Western Australia and possibly Tasmania further down the track-it will be necessary to provide a mechanism for three competitive services to be extended over the whole State without infringing the rights of either the metropolitan stations or the regional stations. This reconciliation can be achieved only by using a mix of techniques, that is, relaxed ownership and control measures, consolidation of licences and aggregation. It is precisely this flexible mix of measures which the Government is creating with this legislation. Whether the licensees involved are able to negotiate a successful transition to three competitive services is in their own hands. I sometimes have doubts about free market forces operating as well in this area as some people think they will, but that view would be a bit odd coming from those opposite, the great free enterprise operators. It is really in the licensees' hands, but if the free market forces do not lead to a solution the government of the day will have to decide whether to impose a process. I do not propose to pre-empt that at this stage on the basis that the free market forces will probably solve the problem.

Another question was whether the Minister would refuse to approve an implementation plan until the Minister was satisfied with all the other implementation plans for the approved market. While I think that only some aspects of the implementation plan will have a bearing on the implementation plan of other licensees, if the implementation plans of licensees conflict on such an aspect as, for example, the timetable for transition to aggregation from MCS, the Minister may have to hold up all implementation plans until a broad decision is reached on that aspect. As far as possible, however, it would not be intended that approval of implementation plans be delayed because approval had not been given to others. For example, if in Queensland all agreed except one who wanted to delay building transmitters the Minister would probably go ahead, approve the others and continue the debate with that licensee. If that failed, of course, firstly, one could refer the matter to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal for recommendation and public inquiry; secondly, direct a new implementation plan from the licensee under guidelines; or, thirdly, impose an implementation plan.

I think the only other matter that was raised was whether I would explain the need for proposed new section 94ze and the `Objects of Part' in proposed new section 94. This is the situation where there are only two licensees-for example, Tasmania. Proposed new section 94ze provides a mechanism for the Minister to invite applications for a third competitive service and for the Tribunal to grant that licence without consideration of commercial viability. Of course, that is a new type of criterion in this Act. It is well known that sections of that Act relating to commercial viability have delayed inquiries into competing licences. The prime example is the one I referred to earlier, the Perth inquiry.

The shadow spokesman also referred to video and audio entertainment and information services. The Government does not consider that VAEIS will affect the projections of real revenue growth in the indicative plan since they are not broadcast to the general public and, therefore, do not compete for advertising revenue with conventional television. The Government does not intend to review the question of pay television for at least four years and it has not been built into the projections. It should be recognised that, even if the government of the day decided in 1991 to move to pay services, there would be a lead time of at least three years before the services could be introduced.

The last question has been the subject of on-going debate for a long time, that is, the query on the 4 per cent growth, and I can add nothing more to it than to say that the 4 per cent real growth in revenue is an assumption made for the purpose of financial projections supporting the indicative plan. It is an industry average, like the actual industry average of 8 to 13 per cent in the previous 10 years. The fact that particular approved markets choose to move along the MCS path to equalisation rather than aggregate directly does not significantly affect the projections of revenue growth.
Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report-by leave-adopted.
