SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the members of the Government who have attended to listen to my speech and to support the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen). We all know that the Attorney-General needs supporting and I am glad to see that loyalty has compelled honourable members to turn up.

SPEECH.PARA: The Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill (No. 2) 1986 continues, as the Attorney-General said in his second reading speech, the practice of presenting an omnibus Bill in each sitting of the Parliament as an expeditious way of making a large number of non-contentious amendments to legislation not otherwise being amended. It is perfectly true that many of the amendments in the Bill are non-contentious and the Bill is not opposed, but it would not be correct to say that some of the amendments are not of major importance. One amendment, to which I will come, deals with sending drugs through the post. Before I come to that, I refer to one or two of the amendments which are distinct improvements in the law.

The work of the Attorney-General should be acknowledged. For example, in the case of bankruptcy, amendments will be made to the Bankruptcy Act 1966. The general effect of the amendments which will be made under the Bankruptcy Act will be to improve the efficient administration of bankruptcy courts and to delegate a lot of the minor, day to day matters to officers of the bankruptcy courts, other than judges. As the Attorney-General said in his second reading speech, the amendments proposed are designed to improve the administration of bankruptcy. The Official Trustee will be restructured in a certain way and the performance of his trustee functions as Official Trustee will be more effectively managed. I think that probably will be so.
In the family law area a small but important amendment will be made, which was described by the Attorney-General in these words:

Australia presently has reciprocal arrangements for enforcement of maintenance orders with 29 States of the United States of America. However, those arrangements apply only to final orders of United States courts. The scheme which operates within the United States of America by virtue of the enactment by all States of the Uniform Reciprocal Enforcement of Support Act does not allow for the making of orders if the respondent is not present within the jurisdiction. Instead, a `petition for support' is obtained from a court in the claimant's State and remitted to the respondent's State for hearing. This amendment will enable the regulations to make provisions for courts having jurisdiction under the Family Law Act to accept petitions for maintenance remitted by courts of the US States that conclude reciprocal arrangements with Australia, and for the Australian courts to make orders in respect of such petitions.
It is sensible that in that area reciprocal arrangements should be promoted as far as is possible.
I come to the Postal Services Act 1975. The amendment which will be made to that Act provides:
A person shall not, without lawful authority, send by post or by courier service a postal article that encloses or contains a prescribed narcotic substance within the meaning of the Customs Act 1901.

That simply means a drug which is declared to be illicit on public policy purposes. The penalty provided is $5,000, or imprisonment for two years, or both. The amendment goes on to deal with the question of an offence against a law of a State or the Northern Territory and says that the validity of that law is not affected by reason only that the act-that is, the act of sending drugs through the post-also constitutes an offence under this amendment. Honourable members will understand that we are there dealing with an amendment to the Postal Services Act of some five or six lines. It is a very simple amendment and I commend the Attorney-General for bringing it forward, but I ask why has it taken so long.

The Attorney-General in his second reading speech referred to the drug summit of 2 April 1985. We recall that that summit was promoted by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) as an occasion when people would get together for the purpose of lending credence to the policy, or lack of policy, of the Government in the area of control of drug abuse and the education of people not to abuse drugs. This is, of course, a matter of great concern to the Government. Since it is a matter of great concern, it was treated as a matter of great urgency. I would be very glad if the Attorney-General would tell me why it has taken since 2 April 1985 to put before this Parliament an offence which deals with a very important matter-that is, making illegal the sending of proscribed or illegal drugs through the mail. Anybody with any sense knows that that is something which happens. On 2 April 1985 the Government proposed that this amendment should be made, because even the Government understood that that was a problem in our society-a society which is riddled with drug abuse promoted by organised crime. Well over a year later we have this amendment. What did the Attorney-General say of it? He said:
This amendment will provide another weapon in the Government's fight against drug trafficking.

As usual, we have delay after delay. We have confusion and we have no answer to the very simple question: Why did the Government not act quickly? What was so difficult? There was nothing difficult about this amendment. It was a perfectly straightforward change to the law which any competent draftsman could have drawn up within half an hour. I would not think that the work that has gone into it would have taken more than half an hour late in the afternoon. I say that not to criticise the draftsman but simply to point to the fact that what we are dealing with is a very simple but very necessary amendment to the law.

If the Attorney-General was going to seek to close the loopholes in the Bill, there are quite a few others that could have been closed. Whilst it would have stretched the general basis of the Bill, we would have supported action to close the loopholes that presently exist. Again, I ask him: Why the delay? What has happened is that this Government has gone to the Australian people and has said: `We oppose organised crime. We are committed to stamping out organised crime. We are committed to stamping out drug trafficking'. Words are fine, but what about actions? If this commitment exists, one would think that somewhere there would be the hint of an overall strategic plan to deal with organised crime. But of course there is not. We have dribbled out bit by bit changes to the laws and always compromised by delay after delay.

Let me just direct the Attorney-General to some other areas which could have been the subject of quick, decisive government action. Mr Taillon came to this country in July 1985. He was in transit from Bombay to Canada. Eleven kilos of hashish, worth an estimated $300,000, was found in his suitcase. It was not in his hand; it was, as I understand the facts, separately stowed in the hold of the plane. A question arose as to whether he should be prosecuted and the opinion formed in the Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions was that a prosecution should not be brought because there was a deficiency in the law. I am not criticising those who formed that judgment although, for my part, I would have prosecuted and let the law sort out the problems. If somebody comes into this country in transit to another country with 11 kilos of hashish, it is perfectly plain that he intends to use that hashish for the purposes of sale and that he is going to be breaking the laws of another country. If he is not breaking the laws of this country he is, most certainly, breaking what we would think to be the intent of the laws. So, for my part, I would have said: `Let us charge this man. If the charges don't stand up, we will amend the law'. But he was not charged. I understand that people can come to a conclusion of that kind and I make no criticism of the Director of Public Prosecutions or the person whose job it was to make the decision.

But what would one do? The first thing one would say is: `We cannot allow this state of affairs to continue. We cannot allow Australia to be known as being a safe transit point for the smuggling of drugs'. What would one do? One would act quickly. What has happened? Nothing has happened.

Let me refer to the Weekend Australian of 26 September 1986. In it there is a report of this case and of concerns, amongst other things, expressed in November last year by the Australian Federal Police Association which, it is said, wrote to the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) asking what action was planned to prevent a similar incident occurring. The Special Minister of State can be an amusing man but, when it comes to being effective, he is not the man to write to. However, he got into the act and the article states:

Mr Young assured the AFPA that he had referred the matter to the Attorney-General who said it had been passed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, because it concerned a likely amendment to the Customs Act.

So we have the Australian Federal Police going to the Special Minister of State, the Special Minister of State going to the Attorney-General and the Attorney-General sending it off to Senator Button. It is not a particularly difficult matter. All we have to do is to amend the law to make quite sure that people cannot transit through this country carrying hashish, cocaine or anything else for the purposes of sale in the streets of the other drug capitals of this world, for the purposes of promoting addiction and the debasement of those who become addicted. We know how deeply, how sincerely, how profoundly this Government is concerned that drug enforcement should be effective, but nothing has happened. Yet we did get some understanding of the efficiency of this Government earlier this year. In late September this year Senator Button was asked about the review of this loophole. His answer, in part, was:
The matter is in the hands of the Attorney-General and I will obtain an answer to the honourable senator's question from him.
Some days later, in early October, the Attorney-General was asked a question about it. What did he say? He said:
Because the importation aspect is not a matter within my portfolio but one for the Australian Customs Service, that opinion-
I interpolate by saying that he was referring to an opinion that had been obtained since July 1985 from a Sydney Queen's Counsel as to the effect of the loophole, if it was a loophole-

and advice has been forwarded to my colleague the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button. I understand that arrangements are now in place to amend the Act to ensure that, whether a case relates to importation and or possession, prosecution can be launched.

It can be said again and again of this Government's handling of the matter that it is an appalling state of affairs. When we are dealing with problems of this kind, with effects of the magnitude that these kinds of problems have, law enforcement and the drafting of laws to close loopholes can be handed over to these Inspector Clouseaus of the Labor Government-Senator Button, the Attorney-General and the Special Minister of State. If there is an answer, let us have it. Would honourable members not think that from July 1985 until November 1986 was time enough to draw a small but vitally important amendment to the Customs Act?

Let me move on in the spirit of the way the Attorney-General has approached this matter. One part of the omnibus Bill now before the House is the amendment to the Postal Services Act, an amendment that took the Government from April 1985 until now to draw up. I remind the Attorney-General of some other things to which he can be directing his attention. In the 1984-85 report of the Director of Public Prosecutions, the Director of Public Prosecutions referred to deficiencies in the Crimes (Foreign Incursions and Recruitment) Act 1978. He said, and I quote from his report:

In a number of matters referred to the DPP over the past year it has been apparent that there are deficiencies in Commonwealth criminal law. In some cases these have required that charges be withdrawn, or not laid, in quite serious matters.
This is not just some minor matter, this is the Director of Public Prosecutions saying that charges cannot be brought in serious cases because of deficiencies in the criminal law. He continued:
In all cases the defect in the legislation has been drawn to the attention of either the Attorney-General or the appropriate area within his Department with a recommendation that the law be changed.

For example, in one matter arising in Queensland, charges that had been laid against 4 persons under section 6 of the Crimes (Foreign Incursions and Recruitment) Act 1978 were withdrawn because of a perceived deficiency in the provisions of that Act. It was alleged that the defendants had accumulated arms and munitions in Australia with the intention of illegally importing them into New Caledonia to arm white settlers against pro-independence Kanaks. There was no evidence that the defendants intended that the weapons be used against the French authorities-
that, of course, is the critical point-

as opposed to pro-independence forces, and no evidence that any person who might use the weapons in New Caledonia had sufficient connection with Australia for the defendants' conduct to fall within the provisions of the Crimes (Foreign Incursions and Recruitment) Act. Accordingly, the only action that could be taken against the defendants were proceedings under the Customs Act 1901 to recover a pecuniary penalty in respect of their alleged intention to export the weapons and munitions from Australia.

We are talking about the trafficking in arms for the purposes of violence-a serious matter one would think. What has happened? Nothing at all. We find in the 1985-86 report of the Director of Public Prosecutions which was tabled in the House yesterday that precisely the same complaint is made. He said this about law reform:
No action has been taken, for example, to overcome the deficiencies in the Crimes (Foreign Incursions and Recruitment) Act 1978 highlighted in the Annual Report for 1984-85.

Why? Arms trafficking is a deadly serious matter. This Government is allowing people to deal in death, yet nothing has happened to overcome this major deficiency in our laws. The Director of Public Prosecutions, in his 1984-85 report, complained of another matter. He said:

Among other matters, the Office has also recommended that section 12a of the Crimes Act 1914, which enables certain indictable offences against that Act to be dealt with summarily with the consent of the defendant, be amended to apply to all offences against Commonwealth law.
It is of less magnitude but still important. What does the Director of Public Prosecutions say in the 1985-86 report? He said:
. . . no action has been taken on the proposal, also referred to in last year's Annual Report, that section 12a of the Crimes Act 1914 be amended to apply to all offences against Commonwealth law.

In the same report, that is, the 1985-86 report, he refers to banking and financial controls. There has been a lot of talk by this Government about its concern to deal with organised crime to prevent people from opening bank accounts in false names and to prevent the laundering of money. What do we get? This is what we learn from the report of the Director of Public Prosecutions:
In 1984 the Costigan Royal Commission made seven recommendations designed to reduce the potential for participants in organised crime to misuse financial accounts with banks and other institutions.

In fact, the original recommendations had been made in a report by Mr Costigan in July 1983. So the Government has had since July 1983 to consider those recommendations. We learn something else from this report. The Director of Public Prosecutions said:

The DPP participated in a Working Group set up by the Government to report on the recommendations by the Costigan Commission. The Working Group presented its report in June 1985. No action has yet been taken.

Let me remind honourable members again of the chronology of events. In July 1983, Mr Costigan made his original recommendations. In his 1984 final report, seven recommendations were set out. A working group was then set up by the Government to report on the recommendations of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. The Director of Public Prosecutions participated in that working group. It reported in June 1985 and still no action has been taken.

There are areas of law where it is very legitimate to argue as to what should be done. For example, we can have a view that telecommunications should not be intercepted under any circumstances. We could have a view against that. I believe that the view against that is overwhelmingly strong but we must come to a view. One thing that the Attorney-General and this Government should have done, if the Government had any commitment at all to its paper war against organised crime, is to have gone through the recommendations of Costigan and others. It should have looked at the loopholes as they were revealed and it should have acted one way or the other and said, very simply `We do not agree with Mr Costigan; we will not implement those recommendations', or `We think those recommendations should be implemented', or it should have expressed some third view. But at least let us have a view so that we know what this Government intends and so that we know that it has a plan. But the fact of the matter is that there is no evidence of a strategic plan. The only way that organised crime can be combated is by the development of a strategic plan which will deal with the use of resources, the upgrading of personnel and, in the Attorney-General's own area, legislation designed to close loopholes and designed to give effect to recommendations made by people expert in the area of organised crime, such as Mr Costigan, Mr Justice Stewart, Mr Redlich, of Queen's Counsel, Mr Gyles, of Queen's Counsel, and others. But what has happened? When they are dealt with it is a bit by bit process dragged out over an inordinate period. Far too often recommendations are buried, problems are forgotten and the public is disregarded.

When the Attorney-General winds up the debate I would be very glad to hear from him whether the Government has an overall strategic plan to deal with organised crime and, if it has, where this plan is hidden, why it has not taken the Australian people into its confidence about this plan, at least as to its broad outlines, and why we are greeted so often with delay and indecision when it comes to dealing with the appalling problems of organised and quite ordinary crime which confronts this nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maher Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are dealing with the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill (No 2). It has been my experience that, about once a year, this House has a similar piece of legislation to cover a lot of different amendments to separate Acts. As the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) has said, this is an omnibus Bill. On a previous occasion that I had an opportunity to speak a constituent of mine berated me and said: `Why are you not speaking in Parliament about unemployment, housing and something that is relevant to people?' Nevertheless, we are restrained to speaking on the legislation before the House.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight there are 15 or 20 amendments to Acts of parliament, some important and some of lesser importance. One that I want to touch on is the amendment to the Postal Services Act 1975 which makes it an offence to send a prescribed narcotic substance, as defined by the Customs Act, through the mail. It is a fact that, at the Concord Post Office in my electorate and at several other post offices in Sydney small quantities of a narcotic substance called crack were recently discovered. I had never heard of it previously but I am informed that it is some sort of a mixture of cocaine which is particularly lethal and dangerous. Small quantities of this drug, crack, were discovered at two post offices in Sydney. So the Government is honouring a commitment given in 1985 that it would make it an offence for illicit drugs to be sent through the mail. It has attached to that offence a maximum of two years imprisonment and/or a fine not exceeding $5,000.

The legislation includes several amendments to the Migration Act. They are of considerable importance to people coming to this nation who want to settle down but not just yet. Older couples being brought here by perhaps a son or daughter may think that their house back home is sold. They enter Australia on a residency visa and then find that the sale has fallen through. As recently as Saturday I had two young German nationals come to see me at my constituency interviews. They have residency and they want to bring their parents here. There is a problem with the sale of the home because prices are depressed in West Germany or in the region where they live.

More and more people are coming to Australia on what we might call business visas. They come here with the intention of establishing a company and bring with them half a million dollars. Some 400 or 500 of these visas to enter Australia were issued to families throughout the world last year. As from 1 January 1987, this new form of visa will allow migrants multiple re-entry into Australia during the first years of settlement. They will be given a three-year re-entry visa so that they can come and go. These visas are all covered by the migration fee of $150 per head. If the visas are issued in Australia to people who are already here and who want a multiple entry visa, the fee is $50 per head. If people are overseas, winding up a business or trading in a business, they can have a visa for a fee of $60. If they have an existing return visa, there is no charge.

Many people who have come to Australia to settle here from Europe, Asia, America or the United Kingdom have business interests which add to their capacity to look after themselves financially and will add to the wealth of this nation. These people also have the capacity to increase Australia's trade overseas. The quaint notion of people coming, settling down and never leaving Australia because it is the best country in the world is very good, but in practice many people wish to trade and to develop contacts that they left behind. This is a very important amendment to the Migration Act. It concerns a matter on which I have made numerous representations over the years to Ministers for Immigration. Of course, if a migrant is not bona fide and comes to Australia and does not really have an intention to reside here, the provision will not apply and the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs will make an assessment. If the migrant is literally out of Australia for three years, there will be no renewal of the visa.

There is another problem for people coming to Australia from other countries and wanting to settle here. They come on their passports. To obtain Australian citizenship, they have to have had at least two years residency, for one year of which they must have actually resided in Australia. Problems do arise. One family in my electorate came here from South Africa. The family are all Australian citizens except one of the children, who is a sportsman. He travels the world, participating in his sport, and he just cannot remain in Australia long enough to qualify for citizenship. Naturally he has problems because he has a South African passport. I am trying to help him to get Australian residency. There is the guarantee that, if people come to Australia and keep moving backwards and forwards- (Quorum formed)

As I have said, the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill (No. 2) contains a number of important amendments to a number of important Acts. The one with which we are dealing at present is an amendment to the Migration Act which will allow migrants multiple re-entry to Australia during the first years of settlement. That is important to all members of this House who handle migration matters. In my case, such matters represent 70 or 80 per cent of my work. In fact, when somebody comes in with a taxation problem, I say: `Hallelujah!'. Migration work in Sydney and Melbourne is enormous. I know that the honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh), the honourable member for Sydney (Mr Baldwin) and all honourable members fully support that. I know that we are all experts on migration matters and not just education matters. The honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) also assures me that he is an expert in handling migration matters.

The legislation also contains an amendment to the Family Law Act 1975. It deals with the enforcement of maintenance orders in various States of the United States of America. Twenty-nine of the States have entered into reciprocal arrangements with Australia. The amendment is designed not only to enforce the maintenance provisions under the United Nations Convention on Recovery Abroad of Maintenance, which Australia acceded to in 1985. It also gives the Australian Government and the Australian courts the right to enforce those maintenance provisions. As all honourable members know, there are difficulties for constituents when a husband or wife has returned to the United States, England, Ireland or any other country and is working but not paying maintenance. I am informed that reciprocal agreements exist with all the provinces in Canada except Quebec. This amendment to the Family Law Act will allow reciprocal agreements with 29 of the American States. They are already listed in the schedules and regulations of the Family Court of Australia.

It is not my intention to delay the House but this legislation contains other important amendments. There are amendments to the Bankruptcy Act which will allow the Federal Court of Australia to delegate certain of its powers under that Act to the registrars of the court. There are also amendments to the Commonwealth Places (Application of Laws) Act dealing with offences under State law and allowing the taking over of offences by the Director of Public Prosecutions when they have been launched by Commonwealth police officers. There is an enormous variety of amendments to the Insurance Act, the Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Act and the Insurance Contracts Act. The Ombudsman Act of 1976 is being amended to clarify the existing powers of the Ombudsman to decline to investigate certain complaints. So everyone gets to the point where matters cannot be taken any further. Of course the Bill of Rights of 1689 provides that constituents shall have access to parliament, and it provides that we shall have the right to say what we feel without fear or favour. The Ombudsman does not have any such tradition and that office came into existence perhaps because members of parliament were not doing their job. I shall not go through the rest of the amendments to the Trade Practices Act and the Wheat Marketing Act but I do commend the Bill and hope that it receives the support of the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As previous speakers have said, the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill (No. 2) contains a number of amendments to Acts brought before this House for second reading debate. Some of the amendments are not significant in themselves, nevertheless quite important pieces of legislation are laid open by this process. I hope you will agree, Mr Deputy Speaker, that we should treat the legislation as inviting the same parliamentary pro- cedural and debating treatment as legislation would in the normal way.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill proposes changes to section 110 (2) of the Family Law Act concerning petitions for maintenance remitted by courts of the States of the United States of America. One of the major questions now and in the future is the consistency with which decisions of the Australian courts are followed through. There is no reason to assume that United States courts are more proficient. We know the terrible trouble which arises with maintenance orders in respect of children. In a previous debate on a statute law Bill last year I raised a concern I felt about the predicament of custodial parents who had been left to find the extra money to maintain children who had been financially abandoned by their non-custodial parents despite court orders. There is no explanation with this Bill about the impact of the differing systems of administration between countries, but it must be assumed that maintenance, once granted, could open up a problem for US petitioners. Last month the Government put out a discussion paper on child maintenance entitled `Child Support'. The paper opens with the statement:
There is widespread agreement that Australia's current system of child maintenance is in need of reform.

How very true that is. The paper goes on to note that, as things stand, the payment of maintenance is voluntary in Australia. Whether this is so in the United States I do not know. This voluntary arrangement is not working because, as the Government says, those who do not want to pay need not do so. Further-I believe this is an interesting observation-the Government finds that the amounts that are paid are often low in relation to the non-custodial parent's capacity to pay. The problem is that there is a heavy burden falling on the law abiding citizen, the taxpayer. I am saying that a parent who disregards his or her obligations as set out in a court order is in conflict with the law. The weight of our sympathy must go with those who are making the effort to sustain their legal obligations and to those most affected by maintenance lapses-the children.

The Government has the job of coming up with a viable proposal to enforce court orders, and I assume the effect will travel internationally. Between 1974 and 1985 the number of sole parent families increased by 73 per cent, from 183,000 to 316,000. Less than 20 per cent involved births to mothers who have never lived with the father. This is a major point. It demonstrates that by deliberate choice children on social security maintenance result from people deciding to live together and create a family. It is a decision which carries obligations to the children that arrive and it is a very unhappy situation that people can walk away, leaving the taxpayer to meet those obligations. I believe the issue is not just one of finance and economics. The social standards are lowered by the easy tolerance that now exists if people are permitted to pass on these parental maintenance obligations to others. The size of the welfare cake is not unlimited. The community has to balance out the claims for humanitarian assistance that are unavoidably present in a modern complex society. We cannot run up an international debt, as we are doing, and at the same time over- indulge people who choose to neglect their fundamental obligations to the children they have brought into the world.

I recognise that, whatever enforcement provisions the Government decides on, there is bound to be suffering. Some children have benefited from a situation of transferred loyalties as the natural children have suffered. There will be individual cases of difficulties in the transition period. I say `transition' because there is a situation where fresh obligations to another family are accepted in the course of abandoning the natural obligations. However, a sensitive process should be instituted whereby children caught up in this mess are not victimised in the process of returning non-custodial parents to their primary obligations. Thus it seems to me that there is a need for a declaratory change from a situation which accepts failure of non-custodial parents who enter into future obligations by discarding the obligations of natural parentage. Such a change of direction is essential for the welfare of all concerned, including the taxpayer who has to fund close to $2 billion for class A beneficiaries.

It was on a similar debate last year that I raised this matter, while the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) was at the table-as he is now. He felt that he should reply to my remarks by indicating his opinion that the time was ripe for a revised approach to this crucial question. We know how sincere he is on this and we are glad the Government is proceeding to a new position. There is wisdom in the sensitivity that the discussion paper has disclosed. The problems of how to deal with second families, joint custody and substantial access and the indebtedness of non-custodial parents are bound to feature as genuine problems in the transitional phase. The obligations spelt out in the reform should carry the element of notice to those who are setting about new family ventures, and intending partners should be brought face to face with the problems that may exist from a previous relationship. So in this transitional phase let firmness with compassion be the mark of the reforms. That seems to me to be both desirable and essential.

It is doubtful whether the measures for amending the Dried Fruits Equalisation Act of 1978 fall within the concept of the Bill. This Bill is intended to dispose of pieces of legislation which are limited in their scope. It is supposed to tidy up, to correct or to update. One can hardly put the amendments to the Dried Fruits Equalisation Act in that category, appearing as they do during a period of considerable controversy in relation to the management of the industry. This is not to say that the amendments, by facilitating levy payments to individual producers, are not badly needed. It is an important industry with quite special problems and it is difficult to see that the Government will improve its reputation with the industry by not exposing the whole legislation to a more emphatic debating treatment. The amendments are not trivial, and one is allowed to conclude that the Government is a little scared about its relationship with the industry. One can understand that. It is sad that we have not had the opportunity to debate the entire industry in a more substantial way, rather than whizzing in an important amendment in this omnibus Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a significant current problem.

—As my colleague says, it is a most significant current problem. A very important amendment to the Migration Act allows for multiple re-entry without having to reside in Australia for 12 months. The 12 months rule gave a certain force to the notion of permanence implicit in a decision to migrate. Clearly it is difficult to tell at a distance how this will affect the commitment of intending migrants to make a go of it here in Australia, but the reasons for the change owe much to the rules which are intended to couple migration and investment. Clearly there are many in the category of migrant investor who would be unable to decouple their overseas commitments with sufficient finality to meet the 12 months rule. One can imagine that this change will remove what may be a factor inhibiting migrant investors. It is to be presumed, with good reason, that a person with multiple investments overseas is not likely to be able to walk away from them for 12 months in order to serve his time for re-entry status. The change on these counts seems to me both sensible and desirable. However, we do need to monitor the situation so that people are not seen to be using Australia as a bolt hole, as a place of last refuge, without any semblance of a desire for permanent and meaningful settlement in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Another matter that has been raised by a previous speaker is the use of postal facilities for the transmission of illicit drugs. Under this legislation such use will meet heavy fines. The problem is, of course, to discover the contents of a package or to technically bring a narcotics distributor before the courts. We know how difficult it has been to nail narcotics distributors. Part of the problem, and an important part at that, has been the way in which the judicial processes have been manipulated to evade the full impact of the law. We know from that notorious case, the Cessna-Milner case, that great efforts are made by narcotics traffickers to provide for situations when things go wrong and they get caught.

It is difficult, I believe, to imagine the circumstances in which this amendment will prove a deterrent or provide the basis for a technical charge to be laid. One can understand how pornography, so limited, can be restrained. The advertising for mail order pornography and magazines could be stopped efficiently. It is sad indeed that the post office does not use this option. The same forces that benefit from pornography benefit from drugs. These are the big cash crops for all those liaisons between crooked lawyers, indulgent judges, standover men and the like. There is a good case for the post office withdrawing its services from the video-porn industry, which is such a concern to parents and responsible citizens.

This legislation demonstrates the point that what is in a package may be a private matter for the recipient but for the dispatcher it is a matter for public concern. As it is a private matter to have things sent in the mail without interception, there are important public obligations on those who use the mail. The question is that the mailing of narcotics, vital as it is, may not be the only area in which public policy is deficient. Certainly there is a case against the transmission of pornography which, as I have said, is a big money spinner for the crime syndicates that operate under a protective veneer provided by the argument of individual liberty. Certainly, I believe the big syndicates involved in the use of mails for their special enterprise of moral pollution would find it more painful to have a new policy on mailing pornography than they do in contending with a mild inhibition of a $5,000 fine for using the mails for narcotics.

Having opted for policies which expedite bankruptcies, in this legislation the Government is expediting the procedures by which bankruptcies will be administered. The Federal Court of Australia will be empowered to delegate powers under the Bankruptcy Act to registrars of the Court. There is no doubt that registrars do free up facilities of the Court, but it cannot be lightly assumed that they are immune from pressures. As bureaucrats, they tend to stall and play for time when confronted with difficult decisions. The legal community, I am told, finds it necessary to play up to registrars as they accumulate more and more power to interpret decisions which might have been more carefully construed if that attitude of leaving it to the registrar were not a growing one in legal circles.

No doubt the Government would have been better advised to introduce economic policies which soften the pressures leading to bankruptcies. The huge interest rates, a consequence of the policy approach of the Government to wages and government expenditure, are killing marginally placed businesses. Whatever guidance banks gave in the period when interest rates were much lower, when the coalition parties held power, they are a source of unrelieved gloom and disaster for the small businessman. There can be no doubt that the 1984 Budget is having disastrous consequences and is a direct contributor to the bankruptcies. The ordinary prudent businessman is among those facing bankruptcy. There was no way in which he could have anticipated the huge rise in interest rates. The second mortgagee home owner will understand the problems for the businessman who is caught in a choice between declaring himself bankrupt and going it alone, building into an uncertain future on rising interest rates.

Speeding up the process by which bankruptcies can be cleared is one way of lessening individual and social pain. A much better way would be to have restraint on wasteful government expenditure and the pressures from the Left to spend and spend and spend. These interest rates which are driving small businessmen to the wall are a terrible economic burden on the country, be the borrower a farmer, a businessman or a home owner. There does not seem to be any light on the horizon. Consequently, the nation faces a growing stream of bankruptcies. It is sad to see the enterprise of ordinary battlers treated to these conditions. The Government likes to suggest that mistaken government policies in its early days-wage indexation, inflated welfare expenditures, et cetera-are not a factor. Men face bankruptcy because they could not foresee the disaster which would ensue amid the blandishments of the rhetoric of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). There is cold comfort for a bankrupt driven to the wall by high interest rates which are, of course, a direct result of government policy. There is cold comfort in expedition of his affairs before the courts. It is unavoidable and sensible to recognise the problems and neutralise the social pain as efficiently as possible. Clearly, there is a great reservation which must govern the acquiescence of the Parliament in the measure before it.

I confess that I do not agree that this legislation abides by the promises extended in the preliminaries of the second reading speech. Comprehended in this statute is legislation of sizable interest to particular groups, and I cite again the dried fruits legislation. It would be bad indeed if this process which is designed to save parliamentary time were being used by the Government to escape parliamentary debate on contentious aspects of its legislative program.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Griffiths Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to address my remarks to that part of the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill (No. 2) dealing with the Trade Practices Act and, in particular, the consumer protection sections of that Act. It will come as no surprise to members of this House that in recent times a number of steps have been taken in one particular section of consumer protection; that, of course, relates to the need and the desirability to monitor, in a sensible way, price increases in our community. In the last couple of months my colleague the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) has indicated an initiative that was originally started, I think, in his electorate. Although it perhaps was not confined to that electorate, it certainly was a catalyst for further developments. That initiative was to establish price watch groups, not only in the honourable member's electorate but also in the rest of Western Australia. Indeed, historically a number of these groups have operated in Victoria and elsewhere.

SPEECH.PARA: I raise this issue because obviously it impacts directly upon consumer protection. It is a matter of, I think, bipartisan agreement that price rises in our community which cannot be justified ought not to be allowed to continue. Given that our Constitution has not vested in the national Government control over prices and given that when it has sought those powers the Australian people, confined as they are by the criteria for establishing successful referendums, have not transferred that power to us, the power of the Government is largely premised upon persuasion and public education. I think the public education component is of particular import in this context.

The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has indicated that he is completely behind the price watch concept. An organisation which has now been established, under the chairmanship of the honourable member for Canning, has sent out kits to educate consumers on price movements in the respective regions or locales. For example, with a small group of volunteers checking prices in supermarkets on only a monthly basis, these results can be analysed by a local convenor, whether that be a member of the Government or the Opposition, and those figures can be made available to a person who is involved in that type of analysis at State level. That has two obvious results, the first one being that people who are charging excessive prices in supermarkets and elsewhere are subject to the full glare of publicity. If anything scares people who are trying to abuse the system, it is the fear of publicity.

The second and perhaps the major point that we should make is that this provides not only consumer protection but also consumer choice. Whatever one's views of economic theory, consumer choice in any system is an important ingredient for maximising efficiency and so on. A prices task force has been created at the national level, with committees all over Australia. It is anticipated that there should be something like 100 committees operating in the near future. As I indicated, State co-ordinators are able to collate and analyse information and, if it is desirable and necessary, that information will be forwarded to the Prices Surveillance Authority.

The important point to make is that price trends are not always what they seem, whether at local or, indeed, State or Federal level. There are many reasons why prices may be affected, not all of them, obviously, indicating that someone is profit taking. In an economic environment in which devaluation has been a fundamental reality, I think all of us ought to be on guard for excessive profit taking. As I indicated, no constitutional control is vested in the Australian Government, but there is, by way of suasion and support for initiatives such as a price watch organisation or price watch organisations, the ability for people out in the community-not only governments-to take some initiative to seek to bring about a situation in which consumers are given the widest possible choice and the best possible information upon which to make their purchasing judgments. That inevitably means, of course, that inflationary pressures are reduced and competition-which, I think, on a bipartisan basis, none of us would decry-is increased.

In my own electorate of Maribyrnong we have set in place a price watch organisation which, hopefully, will be commencing in the next few weeks. One of the initiatives that we have taken is to ensure that a whole range of people are involved in the easy process of simply taking down a few prices while doing their Saturday morning shopping. As I indicated, this is only a once a month exercise and the information can then be published in local newspapers. For example, I am not sure about the local newspapers in the electorate of my colleague the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), but I am sure that the honourable member, in the interests of his constituents, will be looking to have this sort of initiative established in his electorate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will it be a cost to small business?

—No. In fact, I think small business, just like everyone else in the Australian community, will benefit from competition between banks. But the reason I indicated that my colleague the honourable member for Gippsland might be interested was really to distract him from looking at the legislation in order to see whether or not he was going to take a point of order on me. (Quorum formed) It is more in sorrow than in anger that I make the comment that, throughout the history of the parliamentary democracies never has there been an Opposition so destructive and so prepared to abuse the processes of the Parliament to ensure that the people of Australia are not given information that is of great import to them.
—We shall fight them on the beaches.

—We shall fight them on the beaches, as my colleague the honourable member for Dunkley has put it. But I am in a less combative mood, so I will go back very briefly in the time remaining to me to the merits of the legislation before us. I know my time is running out. Let me conclude by putting the following proposition: It is important not only for the people of Australia but also for the efficiency of our businesses, that price increases, particularly in the context of the devaluation, are kept to a minimum, and the price watch concept, that is being fought for very hard by my colleague the honourable member for Canning and in Victoria by my colleague the honourable member for Chisholm (Ms Mayer), will be of great assistance to the people of Victoria and Australia respectively. I commend the concept not only to my colleagues on the Government side, but also to my colleagues on the Opposition side of the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer to two sections of the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill (No. 2) 1986-the amendments to the Interstate Road Transport Act and the amendments to the Air Navigation (Charges) Act. I deal first of all with the Interstate Road Transport Act. I am assured by the office of the Attorney-General that the amendments before the House relating to the Interstate Road Transport Act 1985 are simply designed to allow operators of vehicles registered under that Act the maximum flexibility in installing distance measuring equipment if they should opt to determine their annual registration charge on the basis of actual kilometres travelled rather than the annual weight related formula. During the debate on the Interstate Road Transport Bill, I raised the concern of the coalition parties and the road freight industry over the possible compulsory use of monitoring devices in relation to the implementation of the second stage of the legislation concerning operator and truck safety. I repeat: A Liberal-National Party government will not be party to any unnecessary or threatening requirements for such devices for federally registered vehicles.

SPEECH.PARA: Although the only role for the Commonwealth Government relates to vehicles which are federally registered, the New South Wales Government has claimed that it is required to enforce the compulsory fitting of new technology monitoring devices to all trucks because of this Federal legislation. This claim is rubbish. The New South Wales Government is trying to blame the Commonwealth to excuse its own pursuit of the police state objective of enshrining self-incrimination of truck drivers and operators by forcing the fitting of sophisticated monitoring devices to New South Wales registered vehicles. The Federal power is restricted to federally registered vehicles, which will constitute only a comparatively small number of trucks in New South Wales. Not only is the New South Wales claim nonsense; it is also mischievous, misleading and an abuse of the intent of the Federal legislation. I commend the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris), the Federal Department of Transport and the Australian Road Freight Transport Advisory Committee for exposing the New South Wales deceit, for referring the question of monitoring devices to ARFTAC for report in July 1988 and for publishing a pamphlet explaining the facts, which is aptly named `The Facts on Monitoring Devices'.

It is indeed unfortunate that the New South Wales Government is refusing to abandon the idea that it can dramatically improve road safety by continually assaulting the road transport industry, by attempting to restrict the fundamental rights of drivers and operators, and by wanting to foist unproven new technology on the industry. It would do much better to ensure that the outlying areas of the State get a fair share of the road finance which was meant for them by the Federal Government, and to put more State money into rural arterial roads-that is, State highways-and local roads.

The second aspect of this omnibus legislation to which I wish to refer is the amendment to the Air Navigation (Charges) Act 1952. In November 1984, Mr Henry Bosch produced his report on aviation cost recovery in Australia. In that report he found that there were significant reasons for questioning the accounting procedures of the Department of Aviation. It seems that the Department anticipated Mr Bosch's uncomplimentary findings and hurriedly put some discipline into its accounting procedures. The result was the Air Navigation (Charges) Amendment Act 1984, which gave the Commonwealth the power to raise a statutory lien against an aircraft where Commonwealth charges are outstanding on that aircraft for a period greater than 29 days, to deregister it if a statutory lien has been in place on the aircraft for more than six months, and ultimately to seize the aircraft if the lien has been in effect for more than nine months.

It is well worth noting here that, when the original Bill went through the Parliament in 1984 and gave those powers to the Commonwealth, the Opposition, through the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender), moved numerous amendments because the Bill had been hurriedly put together. Most of the amendments were accepted by the then Minister for Aviation because the Government simply had not had the foresight to envisage some of the problems which would inevitably arise. The amended Bill was pushed through in the very small hours of the morning with these amendments and it seems that the Government is still trying to get it right.

After nine months of a statutory lien being in place, the Government is able to seize aircraft, the operators of which have not paid their outstanding charges. One would think that this period of nine months would provide the Department of Aviation with ample opportunity to warn the persons concerned about the consequences of their not paying their debts. One would think that any reasonable government department would use good business sense and not offend its customers by threatening them with a statutory lien at the earliest possible opportunity. One would even expect someone with these significant powers to keep them in reserve, to be used only in the handful of cases across Australia that may require such drastic action as the seizure of an aircraft.

One would certainly be astounded to discover that the Department of Aviation sends out with the first notice a pamphlet warning-indeed threatening-the dire consequences of not paying accounts. This Department's power in this respect is unprecedented in the transport industry and highlights the heavy-handed way in which the Department has tried to catch up on its poor accounting record, unfortunately to the offence of the aviation industry. While one cannot deny that accounts should be paid promptly, one wonders how promptly the Commonwealth, and particularly the Department of Aviation, pays it own accounts.

It seems that the Department, in correctly pursuing better accounting, has gone from one extreme of laxity to the other extreme of unfair collection procedures which, to my knowledge, have no parallel in any other department or industry. I believe that there should be the common courtesy by the Department of assuming that the vast majority of people will pay what they owe, rather than treating everyone in the industry as someone to be mistrusted and a potential criminal. Not only is the Department heavy-handed in its response, but it has gone overboard in threatening users of services with the impounding of their aircraft if accounts are not paid within the prescribed period. If the Department were to adopt a more businesslike, rather than police-like, approach to the aviation industry, perhaps that industry would be more responsive and positive in its dealings with the Department. Already the industry has suggested many viable alternative ways of aircraft registration and operation, such as the use of registration stickers to show the validity of an aircraft's registration. This would significantly reduce the problems associated with aircraft charges and would make unnecessary the Department's draconian measures. Unfortunately, the suggestions seem to have been lost down the `aviation hall of doom' which Dick Smith wrote about.

The amendment before the House supposedly tidies up certain provisions of the Act which relate to statutory liens. It also makes provisions for more exemptions to the rules to be made by the Secretary of the Department or his nominee. The legislation and regulations affecting aviation in Australia are increasingly reminiscent of Swiss cheese. I refer to the holes in the legislation and regulations caused by all the exemptions and dispensations that are necessary to implement them in anything approaching sensible application. If so many exemptions are necessary, and this amendment is just another example from hundreds, when will the Department admit that the existing rules and laws are out of date and too draconian and that they must undergo a complete overhaul by the industry and the Department working together, as outlined in the coalition's aviation policy? If the rules are not appropriate, the Department and the Minister should not continue to patch them or make Swiss cheese out of them with dispensations and exemptions; they should throw them out and the Department should sit down with the industry and start again with legislation and regulations which are up to date and relevant. This approach also increases the potential work for the committee, recently announced by the Minister for Aviation, which is to oversee the plethora of regulations, air navigation orders and so on, which currently blind Australia's aviation industry.

Needless to say, if the Minister is thorough in his work-I believe that he is-he will not rest content with just providing the coalition's widely acclaimed aviation policy with much welcomed advance publicity, as he did; he should now accept that policy in toto and commence its implementation. Already he is moving in that direction with the announcement that the Government has partially accepted the coalition's proposal for a flight standards tribunal which will review Australia's aviation regulations. If he continues in this way, the coalition parties will be happy to commend him and support its implementation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gayler Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my contribution to the debate on the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill (No. 2) I rise in support for the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) on the wide-ranging and somewhat mechanical amendments to some existing legislation. The Bill contains amendments to some 35 Acts and it is certainly not my intention to refer to each of those Acts in my address this evening. However, there are some significant amendments and I wish to refer first to the amendments to the Trade Practices Act. In so doing, I refer to a comment made by the then Attorney-General when the provisions of consumer protection were first introduced in that legislation. The then Attorney-General said:

SPEECH.PARA: Credit cards are a part-in many respects a desirable part-of everyday life for many Australians. A great deal of business is transacted on credit and credit cards are undoubtedly a convenient means of obtaining credit. If credit cards are furnished only to persons who have sought them there is, in general, no cause of complaint. This Bill will have no application in those circumstances. Last year a vast number of credit cards were sent out to persons who had not sought them. That was not desirable. The Standing Committee of Attorneys-General last October expressed particular concern about the matter. The Bill will accordingly prohibit for the future the sending out of such cards on an unsolicited basis.
He went on to say:

A credit arrangement is a personal matter between the person providing the credit and the person receiving it. It should remain that way and should not be rendered impersonal by credit cards that are sent out without any request. Although it is a matter of opinion that is not the subject of general agreement, it is, or has been, claimed that the mass distribution of unsolicited credit cards can create undesirable inflationary influences.

Persons who have not sought credit find it readily available and are encouraged to use it-with a consequential increase in the demand for goods and services. Other countries, notably the United States of America and the United Kingdom, have taken a similar approach to the matter and have banned unsolicited cards.

The amendment to section 63 of the Trade Practices Act prohibits a corporation taking action to enable an existing credit card holder to use it as a debit card and vice versa without a request from the consumer. The amendment to extend the prohibition on the sending of unsolicited debit cards that can be used as both credit and debit cards is timely and is designed to ensure that consumers are not provided with a credit or debit facility unless-I emphasise that word-they first ask for it. In recent times, having regard to the popularity of plastic money, if I can use that term, there have been complaints about the possibility of this provision being circumvented, that is, a customer having access to such facility without requesting it. These complaints deal with distribution of personal identification numbers to credit card holders, unless they elect not to receive them, to enable the use of credit cards in electronic terminals. The provision is timely and is necessary for consumer protection. After all, it falls under Part V of the relevant legislation, which is headed `Consumer Protection'. I commend that amendment to the House.

I will now advert to the amendments to the Family Law Act 1975. I know that this was covered very comprehensively by the honourable member for Lowe (Mr Maher), but I would just like to comment briefly on the amendments to section 110 of the Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —You practised a long time in that jurisdiction.

—As the honourable member for Herbert has indicated, I practised for some time in the family law jurisdiction. It is once again a measure of the competence of our Attorney-General that he has brought before this place a fine tuning of a number of pieces of legislation. I say `fine tuning' because the legislation itself is basically in place. As this Attorney-General sees the need for change and for fine tuning, he is forthright in bringing amendments to this place. Presently the legislation enables Australian courts to deal only with final orders of reciprocal courts. This amendment will enable Australian courts to conduct hearings based on a Uniform Reciprocal Enforcement Support Act petition rather than a provisional order. There is no basic difference between the acceptance of such a uniform reciprocal enforcement support petition and the maintenance remitted to Australian courts by other countries under the United Nations Convention on Recovery Abroad of Maintenance, to which Australia acceded in 1985. The amendment will effect a routine administrative change of minor policy significance to enable more effective-that is the important word-enforcement of maintenance applications coming from the United States.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, may I very briefly refer to a number of other Acts affected by this omnibus Bill. Firstly, I come to the Australian Institute of Marine Science Act 1972. The Australian Institute of Marine Science is very close to my part of Australia and to that of the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay). The Act currently provides for a Council consisting of a Chairman and four members to govern the Institute. It also provides for a Director to manage the affairs of the Institute, subject to the general direction of the Council. The Director is accountable to Council on all matters involving the Institute, including managerial and administrative matters. As chief manager of the Institute, the Director is the executive arm of Council and should, therefore, be an ex-officio member of the Council. These amendments will in fact provide for the Director to be included as an ex-officio member of the Council of the Institute. (Quorum formed) I just round off my submission to the House by saying that anyone with any decency at all in the legal profession-and there are some within that profession who might not have too much of it-must applaud the amendments to the Bankruptcy Act, which introduce a more streamlined approach to the administration of bankrupt estates. For far too long the legal profession has protected itself by convention, by keeping matters such as bankruptcy administration within its province where they do not belong anyway. One need only look at the Family Law Act to question seriously the role of the legal profession in that jurisdiction. These amendments are well timed. They are needed, and I commend the Bill, and the Attorney-General, to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening we are speaking on the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill (No. 2), which means that it is the second Bill of this type in 1986. As the Deputy Prime Minister and Attorney- General (Mr Lionel Bowen) said when he introduced the legislation, the Bill continues the practice of introducing an omnibus Bill into each sittings of the Parliament as an expeditious way of making a large number of non-contentious amendments to legislation not otherwise being amended. He went on to say that some of the amendments made by this Bill tidy up, correct and update existing legislation. I agree that that is the purpose of omnibus legislation of this sort. The Attorney-General then went on to differentiate between those amendments in the legislation which tidy up, correct and update existing legislation and those amendments which are of a minor policy significance. I take the view that some of the amendments in the legislation are of more than a minor policy significance; they are of a major policy significance. I think it was the honourable member for Lowe (Mr Maher) who, when debating the question of the amendments to the Migration Act, said that they were important amendments to an important piece of legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The history of the matter is that until the early 1980s Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bills were seldom introduced. They were introduced only every few years, but from 1981 onwards their introduction has become more necessary, apparently because of the growth of government and the growth of inaccurate drafting. The original purpose-it was a good purpose-was to make inconsequential amendments of a general drafting nature, or the types of non-contentious amendments the Attorney-General mentioned in his second reading speech to tidy up and correct legislation. That is a worthy objective. I believe that this legislation is part of a pattern of increased mistakes and increased cover-ups by the Government. The Government is using the legislation to slip in significant amendments of a far-reaching nature, which ought to be introduced in a separate piece of legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —You blokes tried to do that.

—I welcome the intelligent interjection. I believe that all parties have engaged in this tendency, but it has been exacerbated at the present time. I ask the honourable member who interjected to take an intelligent interest in this legislation tonight, next year and in the future, because it is part of a trend to bypass the existing procedures of the Parliament. All of us in this Parliament-the Opposition, the Government; the back bench and private members-have to be alert to this. The honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) raised an interesting point. This legislation is caused by the growth of government and the increasing power of the Executive branch of the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: What is happening is that there is less and less time for debating issues in this Parliament. Last week the guillotine was applied. We have an increase in the size of the Parliament, but fewer committees and no estimates debates. There is a tendency by governments to bring in this sort of omnibus legislation, because a public servant or department head says: `Look, Minister, there is this mistake in this legislation-it is a bit embarrassing'. The Minister says: `We will not introduce a separate Bill, we will whip it into the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill and she'll be right, nobody will notice. I'll get it through the Caucus, through the party room, hide it away and nothing will happen. No one will notice we have amended it'.

What is happening is that we are getting more and more significant amendments. I hope that my contribution has some attraction to honourable members opposite. I hope that those parliamentary draftsmen who are here today will receive the message that we in the Parliament have had enough and that we believe that pieces of legislation ought to be amended individually when they need amendment. We should not be given in the last week of a session an omnibus and far-reaching Bill of this nature which covers many pieces of legislation. This Bill will amend 35 Acts and repeal 10 Acts. No one can tell me that it is all insignificant and it is just a tidying up or correction, because it is not. If we are to continue with Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bills, we ought to have an intelligent discussion at the Committee stage of the legislation. We should consider having a special committee of the House to consider this legislation in depth. Members of the Public Service departments concerned should come to the committee and explain what they are doing, so that we know what they are doing, because we do not know. No one in this House has had explained to him what the public servants are doing. The Attorney-General's second reading speech is cursory. There is very little explanation of any type of the amendments that are before us.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a good speech, but you never said it when you were on this side of the chamber.

—I am grateful again for the interjection. I like to believe that I have credibility. I assure the honourable member-I put it on record now-that when we are elected to government at the next election I will pursue with the same vigor and enthusiasm the point that I am making now.
—That is your let out.

—It is not a let out, because I believe that the institution of parliament is paramount and all important. We have seen over the years at every level a denigration of the role of the Parliament. The honourable member is a victim of it in his Caucus and we have been victims of it. I encourage members of the Government to take an intelligent interest in legislation of this sort. They should question Ministers at Caucus meetings about what they are doing. There are some amendments to the Wheat Marketing Act.
—How many?

—There is one amendment. It may be a good amendment, it may be there to validate something that needs validating. I have asked a number of people in the private sector and I have asked the Parliamentary Library today, what this amendment does, but no one can tell me. It seems to me that the Wheat Marketing Act 1979 will be amended because there was probably an invalidity in payments for three months of the year from July through to October in each of the seven years since 1979. Those payments were probably invalid. I believe it is right and proper to validate them-I do not argue with that-but we are being asked to approve retrospective legislation in terms of that amendment to the Wheat Marketing Act.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to the proposed amendment to section 50 of the Trade Practices Act. That Act is another far-reaching piece of legislation which ought to be amended by its own Bill in its own time, brought before the House by the Minister in his own way and subject to public debate in the broader community. I believe that many people in the community who are affected by legislation in the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill-we are amending 37 pieces of legislation-ought to be given the opportunity to examine the legislation, to consult with their members of parliament and to take advice on it. I do not believe that that is happening.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am here to advise you.
—Order! I remind the honourable member for Kalgoorlie that he is not free to make his contribution without first receiving the call from the Chair.

—The proposed amendment to section 50 (2) (a) of the Trade Practices Act is a quite far-reaching change. The essence of the present definition is that a body corporate can be in a position to exert a substantial degree of influence over the activities in a market of another body corporate. The proposed change-that is the deletion of the inner market-expands the scope of the test. Therefore by agreeing to this legislation we are agreeing to prospectively more situations in which companies will be associated for the purposes of section 50 of the Trade Practices Act. That may be a good thing, it may be a bad thing, but there has not been adequate discussion or debate in the broader community. When the Government brought this legislation into the House it did not tell us what it was all about.
