TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to speak on a particular amendment within the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill (No. 2) relating to the Postal Services Act 1975. For the benefit of honourable members, I will just outline what this amendment is all about. It provides that it is an offence to send through the mail without lawful authority a prescribed narcotic substance as defined in the Customs Act 1901. There will be a penalty of a maximum of two years imprisonment and/or a fine not exceeding $5,000 attached to the offence. This amendment to legislation is the sort of amendment that any thinking, reasonable person would support. I am quite sure that everybody on both sides of this House will be prepared to support it because it gives the law enforcement authorities in our country the sorts of legal tools that they need in order to come to grips with the ever growing drug problem in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: But, whilst I congratulate the Government on introducing this amendment, I also take a few moments to criticise the Government for taking so long to introduce this legislation into the House. This legislation was first promised to the people of Australia on 2 April 1985. For those honourable members who are interested, that is 19 1/2 months ago that the people of this country were promised that the legislation would be brought into the House and made into law. Nineteen and a half months is an inexcusable and unforgivable delay in the implementation of a very simple piece of legislation. In fact, there is hardly anything to the legislation. It is the most simple, uncomplicated, uncontroversial piece of legislation that any government could introduce. Any government worth its salt could virtually introduce this type of legislation overnight. But no, this Government has taken 19 1/2 months to do it. It really brings into question the sincerity of this Government in its ability to fight the drug problem in this country.

We have heard so often, from the drug offensive in April this year and right through, that this Government is doing all that it can to fight the drug problem. This example of unnecessary delay is coupled with the example of the introduction of legislation last week in the House that tidied up a huge loophole in our drug laws brought out by the Taillon case. That loophole afforded drug traffickers free passage through Australia even if they had narcotics detected upon them. That legislation took 17 months to be introduced into the House. That is yet another example of the sorts of unnecessary delays that this Government and this Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) are responsible for in bringing in legislation that is really necessary to fight the drug problem. It really does bring into question just how sincere this Government is in trying to fight the drug problem. In fact, many people are saying that all this Government is doing is a cosmetic attempt to try to give the impression that it is doing something about the drug problem. It spent $3.2m earlier this year in launching the drug offensive booklet, filming the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and flashing it across the countryside. That sort of money will be proven to have been a waste of money. It would have been far better spent on education, treatment or rehabilitation.

It is amazing to see how slow the Government is at introducing the tougher aspects of the anti-drugs war but it is so quick to spend the taxpayers' money. Over the last couple of years this Government has had piles of recommendations put before it on how it could fight the drug war better. I have 19 pages of recommendations from the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union and from the Special Prosecutor Robert Redlich's report of 1983-84. Those 19 pages contain hundreds of recommendations. In the years since these reports were tabled in this House, only a handful of the recommendations have been implemented. It is not just people on this side of the House who notice the inexcusable delay in implementation of recommendations and in the tidying up of large loopholes. Only yesterday the Director of Public Prosecutions tabled his annual report and he said:
At the time of writing, legislation has not been enacted in any of these areas.

The areas to which he refers relate to legislation dealing with the confiscation by court order of the profits of crime and the development of possible amendments to the Telecommunications Act following the report of the Royal Commission of Inquiry into Alleged Telephone Interceptions. That relates to new and increased powers for telephone tapping. The Director of Public Prosecutions notices the sorts of delays that we are noticing on this side of the House-delays that really are giving those associated with organised crime more than a fair run. While this Government fiddles with the problem, it just gets worse. The Mr Bigs and the Mr Big Enoughs are getting bigger; they are getting smarter. Their web of corruption is weaving its way further into our society. Their financial strength is getting bigger and their methods of operation are getting harder to detect. Like it or not, this Government seems to be dragging the chain in fighting the drug war. While this Government delays implementation of the sort of legislation before the House tonight, it will deny our law enforcement agencies the sorts of necessary legal tools that they need to get to the organised criminals of this country. While this Government is delaying, the crooks of this country are making hay while the sun shines.

Only last week it was brought to my attention that in Shepparton in Victoria a large drug investigation was called off, after it had been carried out for six months, because, I am told, the police there were not able to acquire sufficient evidence to continue with their investigations. I am told that the reason they were not able to was that they did not have the necessary legal tools, such as telephone tapping powers, to get the sort of intelligence and evidence they needed to make the convictions. The reason they do not have those tools is that despite the fact that this Government promised at the Drug Summit back in April this year that it would introduce increased telephone tapping powers, we have seen all the delays possible. We have seen it put before Caucus and we have seen the Caucus object to certain sections of it; so what does the Government do? It buries it in the joint parliamentary committee that hopefully will bring down its recommendations in the next few days. I guarantee the House tonight that, in relation to this Government bringing into any legislative form the new and increased telephone tapping powers, it will probably take something like two years from the time it was promised to when that action is actually taken. That is what this Government is all about in regard to the drug problem. It is all talk and no action.

We talked about the drug offensive earlier. As I have said before, it is just a giant media exercise. The people of Australia thought that $100m was to be injected into the anti-drug war and that we would see new and exciting things happen. It was brought to my attention only in the last couple of days that some of that $100m being spent in New South Wales is being wasted. Some $221,689 of drug offensive funds has been spent on the purchase of things such as sewing machines, blenders, yoga mats, medicine balls, video records and office equipment. These are not the sorts of things that the people of Australia would expect this Government to be spending the $100m on when allegedly it was all to be spent on the new drug offensive.

The whole story of this Government's fight against the drug problem is a very sad and sorry saga. There have been gross and inexcusable delays in introducing legislation that would allow today's police to combat properly today's criminals. The drug offensive has failed in part because money has been wasted, as is clearly evidenced by the examples I have just mentioned. The money is not being directed where there is a real need for it, and we need today a government that is prepared to introduce more legislation, such as that before us tonight, as quickly as possible so that the people of this country have a fair and fighting chance of getting rid of the drug problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members will recall that the Taillon case concerned a person in transit to Canada and narcotics being found not in his direct possession but in his baggage. It ought to be put on the record that a prosecution was launched, but of course it was withdrawn on the basis that apparently the circumstances did not provide evidence of possession. That surprised me at the time and I duly wrote to the Australian Customs Service about the matter. In fairness to the Service, it took a view with which I did not agree-namely, that it might have been appropriate to allow the baggage to proceed to its destination, which was deemed to be in Canada, where people also involved in the transmission and carriage of narcotics could be trapped. That was not a risk I was prepared to take because there would have been no guarantee that the baggage would have arrived in Canada. It could have been offloaded anywhere in transit, and we would not have got the narcotics or had an opportunity to arrest the offender, which in fact we did. That was the view of another organisation. My view-the Director of Public Prosecutions may not agree with me-was that there was evidence of importation. On that basis I sought the opinion of Mr Chester Porter, QC, who agreed with me. That view was sent back to Customs, which was told that it had to amend the relevant Act because there was an opportunity to correct a weakness in it. Customs agreed.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the chronological order of events, and I just put that on the record because there are legitimate arguments put by departments with which an Attorney-General might not always agree, but he has to convince them. What has happened here is in order. The people of Australia expect people who come here, whether in transit or otherwise, with narcotics in their possession to be brought before the courts for an explanation, at least, and if that explanation is not satisfactory, to be dealt with as criminals.

The other matters of note in the course of the debate related to narcotics and drugs dealing. I want to put it on the record that my Department has been pretty busy in dealing with a massive number of loopholes involving particularly our failure to have extradition treaties to get back people who leave this country. Honourable members know some of the names I have mentioned previously. Many of them left in earlier years; some of them we have not got back but some we have. It is a major success of our police forces and law enforcement agencies and a tribute to them that they have been able to do that, because substantial charges are involved.

In the period in which I have been responsible, as Attorney-General, we have completed 22 extradition agreements. We have 22 agreements which did not exist before. I also make the point that following the Milan conference, where Australia led the resolution that there be mutual assistance with all countries, there was a further conference in Zimbabwe where again we were responsible for the adoption by all of the 47 Commonwealth countries of a mutual assistance agreement which will guarantee the investigation of criminal activities in other countries, and those countries inquiring or making investigation. That would also lead to investigations of bank accounts, the freezing of assets, the transmission of money and many other matters. The legislation has now been introduced here. It is legislation that need only be introduced here because, with the model treaty arrangements, it will automatically apply to another 47 countries. So we now have an opportunity to deal with 69 countries in terms of getting criminals back or guaranteeing that they will leave here should extradition under the treaties be asked for. I mention that because narcotics dealing is of an international character and requires the co-operation of all governments.

Other issues have been raised about this legislation. One of the difficulties I find in my portfolio at present is convincing the banks and banking institutions that we need their co-operation, particularly in respect of the transfer of sums of cash. The Americans have it. They are are the only ones who have it at present. The United Kingdom has not introduced it. I want to introduce it as soon as we can get agreement on the fact that the banks are prepared to undertake that, which I do not think is an onerous task at all. We will certainly introduce that legislation in the autumn session.

Another matter which the honourable member for North Sydney raised was the criticism by the Director of Public Prosecutions. I know that he is part of my portfolio and comes within its payroll, but apparently there is not much correspondence between him and my Department. To that extent, let me try to find out what has happened to some of the matters that the honourable member for North Sydney mentioned. He mentioned the Crimes (Foreign Incursions and Recruitment) Act. I am advised that this matter was certainly taken notice of, as soon as there was a weakness in the Act. I pay tribute to the Australian Federal Police and other investigators who had this matter under notice. In one respect the appropriate munitions might have been seized at the wrong time. Nevertheless, they were aware of what was to take place in the way of transhipping those armaments out of Australia. Arrests were made at that time, and the armaments were seized. There was no deficiency in the law enforcement agency. The question is whether there was a weakness in the law, and this is what has been identified. The Director of Public Prosecutions is critical of it, as he can be. The point that I want to make is that the matter has apparently been the subject of some sort of shuttlecock arrangement as to whether the submissions that were before Cabinet in 1985 were strong enough. I am now advised that, after consideration and further comments on more than one occasion from the Director of Public Prosecutions, it has now been agreed that the instructions are in order for the Act to be amended, and those instructions have been given to the Office of Parliamentary Counsel.

The other matter was the question of what happened in respect of section 12a of the Crimes Act, which deals with the problem of being able to handle matters on a summary basis with the consent of the defendant, even though they might have been indictable offences. SPEECH.PARA: Experience not necessary but bilingual nursing, herbal or book keeping skills helpful.

It causes me great concern that an abortion clinic apparently can function in my electorate. TALK.START.PARA: —Over the last three weeks I have had the good fortune to have visited the United States on a program sponsored by the American Council for Young Political Leaders. During that visit I had the opportunity of going to Washington DC and to the states of Kansas, Missouri and California and on every occasion took the opportunity to raise the concerns that Australian farmers have with United States protectionism and subsidies in areas of agriculture. The overwhelming impression I got from that visit was that the Australian primary producer is facing very massive problems in the United States and growing problems in the year or two ahead and that, if Australia is to overcome these problems, a massive lobbying effort will be needed by the Australian Government and by other people in the Australian community.

SPEECH.PARA: I went to the state of Kansas in particular because it is regarded as the wheat bowl of the United States and there spoke with the Governor of Kansas, John Carlin, as well as with the State's Secretary of Agriculture. Of course, they emphasised the collapse in farm incomes in that state and pointed out that some 72 per cent of the incomes of wheat farmers in Kansas come from Federal and State Government grants. Those politicians are calling for more help for those farmers, as were all the congressional candidates in the recent round of elections in states which were in any way sensitive to the farm crisis in the United States, and that is an awful lot of states.

One of the important points in addition to that is that the Democratic Party controlled Senate which is to take over from the Republican controlled Senate from January next year is going to push as its first initiative a trade protection Bill, and that Bill again has the potential to have a very severe impact on the Australian primary producer as well as some other Australian industries. I spoke to administration officials as well and there was not a lot of hope issuing from those people either. They are still committed, of course, to supporting American primary producers through domestic and export subsidies. The only gleam of hope for Australia is for the United States Administration to attempt to veto the protection Bill that the Democrats are determined to introduce.

Through all this gloomy news I came to two very clear conclusions. The first was that it will be vastly important for the Australian Government to lobby as effectively as it can the new, now Democratic Party controlled Senate and to do that not just by traditional methods of diplomacy but also by employing the services of a professional American lobbyist who would have the capacity to understand and to know, through long periods of contact, American congressmen, senators and congressional aides. I do not think that career diplomats, competent as indeed most of them are, have the capacity in just three years of a posting in Washington to have the degree of contacts and influence that a reputable and professional lobbyist in Washington can have. I also think that it is vastly important that the Government agrees to send an all party parliamentary delegation to Washington in the early part of next year to impress on the new Democrat controlled Senate that Australia not only exists but there are foreign policy implications for the United States if it continues to pursue and indeed exacerbate its policies of domestic and, in particular, export subsidies. These are very real concerns for Australia, particularly for Australian primary producers, and I hope that the Government will at least consider this slightly less regular form of approaching the United States Congress because clearly not nearly enough has been done over past years to build our ties with the United States Congress. We must learn the lessons of the past and try to develop those contacts as best we can, using the mechanisms of the United States in the future.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Resources and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question.

It is the Government's policy that changes in the IPP should have a revenue neutral impact. As the IPP fell during March 1986 and following months, the loss in revenue from crude oil excise was offset by increases in petroleum produce excises. Nevertheless, there were net reductions in wholesale prices.

Farmers paid the same lower price as the rest of the community for petrol and diesel used on-road. In addition they received a rebate of the full amount of increased product excise for diesel used off-road. This meant that they received the full benefit of the fall in world crude oil prices for diesel used off-road. This was done to ensure that their competitive position in world markets was not eroded. The effect of this is shown by the following figures:
(a) Maximum endorsed wholesale price excluding State Government franchise fees where appropriate.

Following the 12 September PSA decision, farmers faced the same increase of 2.11 cents per litre as the rest of the community for diesel used on-road. For off-road diesel, however, they had to bear the full increase in cost of 5.81 cents per litre, reflecting the higher costs of supply of crude oil. Since farmers pay no excise at all on off-road diesel, it was obviously not possible for the Government to off-set the price rise by excise reductions, as in the case of on-road use. The 15 October PSA decision further increased the price of diesel used on-road by 0.17 cents per litre and 0.65 cents per litre for diesel used off-road by farmers. The Government receives no additional revenue as a result of these price changes.

The only way in which the Government might have sheltered farmers from the effect of these changes would have been to subsidise them at the rate of 5.81 cents per litre from 13 September and 6.46 cents per litre from 16 October. The annual cost of such a subsidy would have been about $A125 million.

It should be noted that even after the latest adjustment to IPP on 1 October 1986 including an increase of $1.15 in the Bass Strait IPP, and the revised product excise rates, the maximum wholesale price of diesel for off-road use by farmers is 28.7 cents per litre compared with 48.4 cents per litre for the rest of the community, a saving of 40 per cent.

Farmers are currently paying about 10 cents per litre less for their diesel fuel than they did in early March as a result of the decline in world oil prices. These savings are expected to total $175 million between mid-March and mid-November 1986. Farmers will have also benefited to the extent of $250 million in the same period as a result of the full rebate of product excise for their off-road diesel use.

Farmers will continue to benefit after mid-November. Were crude oil prices and product excise rates to remain the same for the next 12 months, product excise concessions would mean a saving of about $370 million in their costs over that period.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, upon notice, on 21 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will he take measures, in conjunction with all relevant authorities, to improve the safety procedures for the transport of radioactive materials.
(2) What is his Department doing to develop guidelines and codes of practices for the transport, disposal and storage of these materials.
(3) Is this Departmental activity in response to new regulations of the International Atomic Energy Commission; if so, what regulations.
(4) Is his Department always notified of the loss, theft or release into the environment of these materials; if not, under what circumstances is his Department informed.
(5) What legal requirements provide for the reporting of such losses.
(6) Does his Department provide advice on dealing with the accidental release of radioactive material into the environment; if so (a) what is the nature of such advice and (b) to whom is it provided.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (3) Extensive arrangements are already in place to ensure the safe transport of radioactive substances in Australia. Radioactive substances represent one of nine classes of dangerous goods. Dangerous goods are transported by air within and from Australia in accordance with the Air Navigation Orders part 33 issued under the Air Navigation Regulations. The Air Navigation Orders in turn adopt the provisions of the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) Technical Instructions for the Safe Transport of Dangerous Goods by Air. For marine transport, dangerous goods are transported in accordance with a determination made under 4.1 of Marine Orders Part 41 issued pursuant to the Navigation (Orders) Regulations. This determination requires that dangerous goods be transported in accordance with the provisions of the International Maritime Dangerous Goods (IMDG) Code issued by the International Maritime Organisation (IMO).

For the transport of radioactive substances, both the ICAO Technical Instructions and the IMDG Code are currently based on the provisions of the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) Regulations for the Safe Transport of Radioactive Materials 1973, as amended to and published in November 1979. A new revision of the IAEA Transport Regulations was published in 1985. The ICAO and IMO plan in due course to incorporate the 1985 edition of the IAEA Transport Regulations in Technical Instructions and IMDG Code respectively.

Regulation of transport, including storage in transit, of radioactive substances within Australia by road or rail is primarily conducted in accordance with the Code of Practice for the Safe Transport of Radioactive Substances (1982) (the ``Transport Code''). The Code was formulated under the provisions of the Environment Protection (Nuclear Codes) Act 1978 after extensive consultation between the Commonwealth, the States and the Northern Territory. The Transport Code essentially takes up the 1973 IAEA Regulations as amended. Implementation of the Code is a responsibility of State and Territory authorities. The Code has been implemented by all States and, in relation to the transport of uranium ores and concentrates, by the Northern Territory, although the means of implementation vary.

The Transport Code is presently being revised in the light of new Regulations for the Safe Transport of Radioactive Material, published by the IAEA in 1985. It is expected that the revised Transport Code will incorporate the 1985 IAEA Regulations and the 1986 Supplement to those Regulations. The revised Code is expected to be published in early 1987 and ultimately to be adopted by the States and the Territories.
Guidelines to the Transport Code and a pamphlet, designed for the worker, on safety rules for enhancing radiation protection are also being revised.

A working group comprising officers of Commonwealth, State, Northern Territory and Australian Capital Territory Competent Authorities for the transport of radioactive substances has been established to discuss matters relating to the administration of the Transport Code such as interpretation of parts of the Transport Code on a uniform basis and co-operation between Competent Authorities.

In the context of the effective regulation of the transport of radioactive substances, it should be noted that IAEA Transport Regulations form the basis of virtually all national and international requirements for the safe transport of radioactive materials, and that these Regulations have led to an excellent safety record for the transport of radioactive substances on a world-wide basis. There have been very few accidents involving the transport of radioactive material in Australia which have had any possible public health consequences. Nonetheless, the Commonwealth Government will continue to ensure that appropriate regulations and codes of practice are developed and encourage their implementation as appropriate.

Management of radioactive waste is, at the Commonwealth level, within the responsibility of the Minister for Resources and Energy. The development of national facilities for the disposal of radioactive materials, arising from the medical, industrial and research use of radionuclides is under consideration by a Commonwealth/State Committee which is convened by the Department of Resources and Energy.

(4) to (5) There is no mechanism for notification to my Department of the loss, theft or release into the environment of radioactive materials. Losses and accidents involving radioactive materials are reported to the Competent Authorities within whose jurisdictions the event occurs (see Table).

Nuclear material within Australia is, however, controlled and accounted for by the Australian Safeguards Office (within the portfolio of the Minister for Resources and Energy) pursuant to Australia's nuclear safeguards policy and international safeguards obligations. (Note: In this context nuclear material has the same meaning as in the Agreement between Australia and the International Atomic Energy Agency for the Application of Safeguards. This definition includes plutonium 239, uranium 233 and 235, natural, enriched and depleted uranium, thorium, mixtures and alloys of these elements, but it does not include ores or ore residues.)

(6) The provision of advice on dealing with the accidental release of radioactive material into the environment is generally a matter for agencies of the States and the Northern Territory. The Australian Atomic Energy Commission and other Commonwealth agencies, such as the Australian Radiation Laboratory and my Department, provide advice as appropriate whenever it is required. Such advice typically relates to health hazards and potential environmental damage.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 25 September 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he aware that on 15 August 1986 the United States Ambassador to New Zealand stated that it was a matter of concern to the United States that New Zealand's ban on nuclear ship visits also applied to aircraft.

(2) Is he able to state whether New Zealand's proposed legislation banning nuclear ship visits will also be extended to include aircraft; if so, is he also able to say whether this action would jeopardise the continuing operation of the US Antarctic program known as ``Operation Deepfreeze'' based at Christchurch.
(3) Has the Government given any consideration to, or entered into negotiations with, the United States to relocate those facilities within Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The United States Ambassador to New Zealand is reported as having said during a radio broadcast on 14 August that the United States had problems with the New Zealand process for approving visits by United States military aircraft similar to those for granting clearances to visiting warships. According to the Ambassador, these problems with aircraft arose from a statement by the New Zealand Defence Minister, Mr O'Flynn, in September 1984 that none of the United States aircraft participating in the TRIAD joint airforce exercises would be nuclear armed; the United States regarded this statement as a violation of its policy of neither confirming nor denying the presence of nuclear weapons.

(2) The New Zealand Nuclear Free Zone, Disarmament, and Arms Control Bill, contains clauses on the entry of foreign military aircraft similar to those for the entry of foreign warships. The main difference is that clause 10 (3) of the Bill provides that, once the New Zealand Prime Minister is satisfied that the foreign military aircraft for which approval is being sought will not be carrying any nuclear explosive device when it lands in New Zealand, the resulting approval may relate to a category or class of foreign military aircraft and may be given for such period as is specified in the approval.

I am not aware that the proposed legislation has jeopardised the continuing operation of the United States Antarctic program known as Operation Deep Freeze based at Christchurch. At a press conference following the conclusion of the Australia-United States Ministerial Talks in San Francisco last August, Secretary of State Shultz said that he did not foresee any shift in the United States operation away from Christchurch.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 17 October 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have the United Kingdom, the United States and Singapore withdrawn form UNESCO.
(2) When were these withdrawals effected and what were the grounds given by each country for their withdrawal.
(3) Has Australia's funding of UNESCO increased from an actual outlay of $2.113m in 1985-86 to an estimated $4.751m in 1986-87.
(4) Is he able to say what formula or criteria are applied by UNESCO in determining the funding commitment of each contributing member country.

(5) Is Australia's increased funding, as suggested by the 1986-87 appropriation, an indication that countries continuing to contribute to UNESCO are required to meet some or all of the shortfall in funding as a result of the withdrawal of the United Kingdom, the United States and Singapore.
(6) Why have there been such large (a) changes in Australia's year by year actual payments to UNESCO and (b) differences between the initial appropriations and actual expenditure over recent years.

(7) Is he able to say whether Australia's Ambassador to UNESCO was correctly reported in the Sydney Morning Herald of 15 May 1986 as saying that it was difficult to defend UNESCO's programs because they were too verbose and too diffuse, and that UNESCO was a mismanaged organisation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) The United States withdrawal took effect on 31 December 1984. In a letter dated 29 February 1984 from Assistant Secretary of State Newell to the Chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, the following reasons were given for the United States withdrawal:
Politicisation of UNESCO's traditional subjects in the introduction of programs, resolutions and debate on disarmament, `collective rights', and other `extraneous themes';
An endemic hostility toward the basic institutions of a free society, especially a free market and a free press; and
The most unrestrained budgetary expansion in the United Nations system.

The United Kingdom withdrawal took effect on 31 December 1985. On 5 December 1985 the Minister for Overseas Development, Mr Timothy Raison, informed the House of Commons that Britain would withdraw due to its continuing concern over
Excessive politicisation and subversion of UNESCO's founding aims;
Inefficient management leading to duplication of effort and vague and meaningless programs;
Serious weaknesses in staff management; and
Excessive staffing and expenditure at the Paris Headquarters.
The withdrawal of Singapore took effect on 31 December 1985. The Singapore Government's decision to withdraw was based on budgetary considerations.

(3) Australia's 1985-86 payment to UNESCO of $A2,112,511 was at an unusually low level due to the fact that two credits were received from UNESCO. There was a credit of $US1,249,344 for currency fluctuations for the 1981-83 triennium, a credit of $US288,339 for budgetary surpluses and a debit of $US40,927 advance to the working capital fund. The Australian contribution of $A4,750,600 for 1986-87 reverts to a normal pattern of contributions.
(4) The scale of member countries' contributions to the UNESCO budget is based on the scale of contributions to the United Nations.

(6) Variations in Australia's annual payments to UNESCO have been caused by changes in Australia's assessment which is related to the UNESCO budget approved biennially by the General Conference, and to credits received due to currency fluctuations. Variations between appropriation and expenditure have also been the result of currency fluctuations.

(7) In an intervention on 13 May, 1986 in debate on the Director-General's oral report during the 124th session of the UNESCO Executive Board, the Australian Ambassador to UNESCO, the Hon. E. G. Whitlam, referred to the major programs of UNESCO as `too verbose and too diffuse'. He did not, however, say that UNESCO is a mismanaged organisation. Following are the relevant extracts from Mr Whitlam's intervention:

`There are problems with the presentation and explanation of the present Medium Term Plan. The 14 Major Programs are simply too verbose and too diffuse. They make it almost impossible for those of us who are required to explain the Medium Term Plan, or more broadly to explain what UNESCO does, to do so by reference to the 14 Major Programs . . .

We shall not in my view be able to justify and promote UNESCO adequately unless and until we concentrate our work under the five main elements in our Constitution: peace and justice, education, science, culture, communication. In order to do so we do not have to reduce or displace any of our 14 Major Programs. We do need to focus and concentrate attention on our Major Programs and all our Programs under these five headings.'

The proposal to concentrate UNESCO's major programs under the five headings in the UNESCO Constitution is one measure Australia is pursuing in the context of the continuing process of reform of the Organisation.
